1-5-4: SOCIAL SECURITY COVERAGE:
   A.   Participation In Social Security System: It is hereby declared to be
the policy and purpose of the governing body of the village to extend to the
eligible employees thereof, effective as of April 1, 1978, the benefits of the
federal old age, survivors and disability insurance provisions of the federal
social security act and amendments thereto 1 . In pursuance of said policy, and
for that purpose, the village president shall take such action with the social
security unit of the state employee's retirement system as may be required by
applicable state and federal laws or regulations.
   B.   Agreement With State: The village president is hereby authorized and
directed to execute an agreement with the social security unit of the state
employee's retirement system to secure coverage of eligible employees as
provided in subsection A of this section.
   C.   Withholdings: Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees for the
purpose provided in subsection A of this section are hereby authorized to be
made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state
and federal laws or regulations and shall be paid over to the social security
unit in such amounts and at such times as are designated by state laws or
regulations.
   D.   Employer Contributions And Administrative Costs: Employer contributions
and administrative expenses shall be paid to the social security unit in
accordance with applicable state laws and regulations from amounts appropriated
for such purposes.
   E.   Records And Reports: The village clerk shall maintain such records and
submit such reports as may be required by applicable state and federal laws or
regulations. (Ord. 78-272, 4-25-1978)
 
Notes
1 2. 40 ILCS 5/21-101 et seq.
1-5-5: INDEMNIFICATION OF VILLAGE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
To the extent permitted by law, whenever any elected or appointed officer or
official, including the village president, village clerk, village trustees,
village treasurer, village administrator and any village employees, full or
part time, including, but not limited to, members of the police department,
commits an act or omission or takes an action while acting within the scope of
his office or employment, and said act or action is done in furtherance of his
duties of office or employment, and the official or employee is thereafter sued
in any civil tribunal or administrative body for money damages or other relief,
the village shall bear the entire expense of defending said village official or
employee before said tribunal and shall indemnify the village official or
employee for and pay any money judgment (excluding punitive damages) entered
against him, whether or not the village official still holds elected office or
remains employed by the village at the time the proceedings are commenced
against him. The elected official or employee may, with the consent of the
corporate authorities, employ legal counsel of his own choosing at the
village's expense to defend his interests. This section shall not be construed
to require the village to pay any expenses of the village official associated
with the defense of a purely criminal charge lodged against him; provided
further, that this section shall not be construed to require the village to pay
any expenses associated with the defense of any disciplinary proceeding to
suspend, terminate or otherwise discipline any village officer, official or
employee. (Ord. 81-329, 9-22-1981; amd. 1994 Code)
1-5-6: ELECTRONIC ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS:
   A.   Rules Statement: It is the decision of the president and board of
trustees of the village of Shorewood that any member of a public body of the
village of Shorewood may attend any open or closed meeting of said public body
via video or audio conference, provided that such attendance is in compliance
with these rules and any applicable laws.
   B.   Prerequisites: A member of a public body may attend a meeting
electronically if the member meets the following conditions:
      1.   The member should notify the clerk or secretary of the public body
at least one hour before the meeting, unless impractical, so that necessary
communications equipment can be arranged. Inability to make the necessary
technical arrangements will result in denial of a request for remote
attendance.
      2.   The member must assert one of the following reasons why he or she is
unable to physically attend the meeting:
         a.   The member cannot attend because of personal illness or
disability; or
         b.   The member cannot attend because of employment purposes or the
business of the public body; or
         c.   The member cannot attend because of a family or other emergency.
   C.   Authorization To Participate:
      1.   The clerk or secretary, after receiving the electronic attendance
request, shall inform the public body of the request for electronic attendance.
      2.   After establishing that there is a quorum physically present at a
meeting where a member of the public body desires to attend electronically, the
presiding officer shall state that: a) a notice was received by a member of the
public body in accordance with these rules, and b) the member will be deemed
authorized to attend the meeting electronically unless a motion objecting to
the member's electronic attendance is made, seconded, and approved by a
majority of the members of the public body physically present at the meeting.
If no such motion is made and seconded or if any such motion fails to achieve
the required vote by the members of the public body physically present at the
meeting, then the request by the member to attend the meeting electronically
shall be deemed approved by the public body, and the presiding officer shall
declare the requesting member present. After such declaration by the presiding
officer, the question of a member's electronic attendance may not be
reconsidered.
   D.   Adequate Equipment Required: The member participating electronically
and other members of the public body must be able to communicate effectively,
and members of the audience must be able to hear all communications at the
meeting site. Before allowing electronic attendance at any meeting, the public
body shall provide equipment adequate to accomplish this objective at the
meeting site.
   E.   Minutes: Any member attending electronically shall be considered an off
site attendee and counted as present electronically for that meeting if the
member is allowed to attend. The meeting minutes shall also reflect and state
specifically whether each member is physically present or present by electronic
means.
   F.   Rights Of Remote Member: A member permitted to attend electronically
will be able to express his or her comments during the meeting and participate
in the same capacity as those members physically present, subject to all
general meeting guidelines and procedures previously adopted and adhered to.
The member attending electronically shall be heard, considered, and counted as
to any vote taken. Accordingly, the name of any member attending electronically
shall be called during any vote taken, and his or her vote counted and recorded
by the clerk or secretary and placed in the minutes for the corresponding
meeting. A member attending electronically may leave a meeting and return as in
the case of any member, provided the member attending electronically shall
announce his or her leaving and returning. (Ord. 07-1407, 2-27-2007)
1-5-7: PAID LEAVE REQUIRED FOR FULL-TIME VILLAGE EMPLOYEES:
The Village of Shorewood shall provide all full-time employees of the Village
with no less than five (5) work days of paid leave per year, to be administered
pursuant to the applicable provisions of the Village of Shorewood Personnel
Manual, bona fide collective bargaining agreement, or other employment
agreement. (Ord. 23-2087, 12-12-2023)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE TREASURER
SECTION:
1-5A-1: Village Treasurer
1-5A-2: Deputy Treasurer
1-5A-1: VILLAGE TREASURER:
   A.   Appointment: The finance director shall serve as the village treasurer.
(Ord. 04-1212, 4-27-2004)
   B.   Bond 1 : The treasurer shall execute a bond in an amount of money that
is not less than three (3) times the latest federal census population or any
subsequent census figure used for motor fuel tax purposes. This bond shall be
filed with the village clerk.
   C.   Authority And Duties: The village treasurer shall have authority and
perform the following duties:
      1.   Be custodian of the police pension fund and all other funds and
finances belonging to the municipality.
      2.   Keep financial records which show separate accounts for each fund of
the village.
      3.   Enter into agreements for the deposit, redeposit, investment,
reinvestment and withdrawal of all funds held by the village.
      4.   Make a monthly report to the village board showing the state of the
treasury as of the date of the report.
      5.   Be responsible for all other duties as set forth in 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3-10-1 et seq. (1994 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3.
1-5A-2: DEPUTY TREASURER:
   A.   Appointment: The assistant finance director is hereby appointed and
designated as the deputy treasurer of the village. (Ord. 04-1212, 4-27-2004)
   B.   Bond: The deputy treasurer shall make bond to secure the faithful
performance of his/her duties as deputy treasurer.
   C.   Duties: The duties of the deputy treasurer shall be coextensive with
the duties, authorities and obligations of the village treasurer. (Ord. 79-288,
2-27-1979; amd. 1994 Code)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION:
1-5B-1: Office Created; Qualifications
1-5B-2: Appointment; Removal; Resignation
1-5B-3: Powers and Duties
1-5B-4: Policy Making
1-5B-5: Salary and Expenses
1-5B-6: Authority of Other Officers
1-5B-1: OFFICE CREATED; QUALIFICATIONS:
The office of Village Administrator is hereby created subject to the provisions
of this Article. The Village Administrator shall be chosen by the Village
President and Board of Trustees on the basis of the Administrator's executive
and administrative ability and in compliance with the personnel policies of the
Village. Special consideration will be given to the Administrator's education,
experience in, or special knowledge of the administration of local government
and of the duties specified herein. (Ord. 19-1940, 8-13-2019)
1-5B-2: APPOINTMENT; REMOVAL; RESIGNATION:
The Village Administrator shall be appointed by and, in all cases, be subject
to the authority and direction of the Village President and Board of Trustees.
The Administrator shall exercise his or her responsibilities as chief
administrative officer in the name and under the supervision of the President
and Board of Trustees and shall be subject at all times to removal from office
by the affirmative vote of the corporate authorities of the Village. (Ord. 19-
1940, 8-13-2019)
1-5B-3: POWERS AND DUTIES 1 :
The Village Administrator shall be responsible to the President and Board of
Trustees for the proper administration of the affairs of the Village and shall,
on behalf of the President and Board of Trustees, direct, supervise and
coordinate the work of all Village department heads and employees 2 . Toward
that end, he or she shall:
   A.    Make a recommendation to the corporate authorities with respect to the
hiring, promotion, or removal of any department head.
   B.    Appoint, promote and remove all Village employees, except department
heads.
   C.   Prepare the annual budget each year and submit it to the President and
Board of Trustees. He or she shall be responsible for its administration after
adoption.
      1.   See Section 1-5C-4 of this Chapter, Administrator may serve as
Building Inspector.
      2.   See Organizational Chart in the office of the Village Clerk.
   D.   Procure from the Treasurer and submit to the President and Board of
Trustees a quarterly report on the finances and administrative activities of
the Village during the preceding quarter.
   E.   Keep the President and Board of Trustees advised of the financial
condition of the Village, of the future needs of the Village, and make
recommendations as appropriate.
   F.   Gather information for the President and Board of Trustees regarding
Village affairs and make appropriate recommenda tions.
   G.   Be responsible for the administration of all personnel and purchasing
activities of the Village, within the limits established by the President and
Board of Trustees, and report regularly on all activities related thereto.
   H.   Be responsible to the President and Board of Trustees for the
enforcement of all Village ordinances, rules, regulations and policies.
   I.   Cooperate with and advise the Village Treasurer and Village Clerk in
the performance of their duties.
   J.   Perform such other duties as may be prescribed, from time to time, by
the Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 19-1940, 8-13-2019)
 
Notes
1 See Section
  1-5C-4 of this Chapter, Administrator may serve as Chief Building Official.
2 2. See Organizational Chart in the office of the Village Clerk.
1-5B-4: POLICY MAKING:
Except for internal administrative matters, the Village Administrator does not
set policy for the Village. Rather, it is the Administrator's responsibility to
see that the policies of the Village President and Board of Trustees are
carried out to the best of his ability. (Ord. 19-1940, 8-13-2019)
1-5B-5: SALARY AND EXPENSES:
The Village Administrator shall be paid a salary as, from time to time, is
provided for by motion or resolution of the Board of Trustees and shall be
reimbursed for his out-of-pocket expenses incurred while in the performance of
his duties on behalf of the Village 1 . (Ord. 19-1940, 8-13-2019)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  1-5-2 of this Chapter.
1-5B-6: AUTHORITY OF OTHER OFFICERS:
Nothing in this Article contained shall be deemed to diminish or detract from
the powers and authority of the elected Village officials and the Village
Treasurer. (Ord. 19-1940, 8-13-2019)
ARTICLE C. CHIEF BUILDING OFFICIAL
SECTION:
1-5C-1: Position Created
1-5C-2: Duties
1-5C-3: Conflict of Interest
1-5C-4: Vacancy in Position
1-5C-1: POSITION CREATED:
There is hereby created the position of Chief Building Official for the
Village. (Ord. 89-519, 10-10-89; 1994 Code; Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
1-5C-2: DUTIES:
The Chief Building Official shall be responsible for securing compliance with
Building Codes 1  and related regulations including inspecting the construction
of buildings, additions and alterations to insure compliance with building
ordinances, reviewing requests for and issuing building permits and conferring
with contractors and property owners to enforce Municipal Building Codes. In
addition, other duties shall include, but not be limited to, interpreting
regulations and codes to builders and property owners and assisting them in
altering construction plans to meet established standards and to recommend and
propose amendments to the Building Code to comply with legislative and
technical changes. The Chief Building Official shall also act as a technical
advisor to various committees, boards and Village officials on matters related
to Municipal building and related codes and ordinances. Other responsibilities
include assisting in court proceedings to enforce Village ordinances,
inspecting businesses and other occupancies to verify compliance, and
performing the tasks that may be directed by the Village Administrator. (Ord.
89-519, 10-10-89; 1994 Code; Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 8, Chapter 1 and Chapter 10, respectively, of this Code.
1-5C-3: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
The Chief Building Official shall not have any pecuniary interest, directly or
indirectly, in any contract, work or business of the Village or in the sale of
any article to the Village or in the purchase of any property belonging to the
Village. (Ord. 89-519, 10-10-89; 1994 Code; Ord. 20-1982, 8- 25-2020)
1-5C-4: VACANCY IN POSITION:
In the event of a vacancy in the position of the Chief Building Official, the
Village Administrator or his designee shall perform or cause the performance of
the duties and responsibilities of said position. (Ord. 89-519, 10-10-89; 1994
Code; Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
ARTICLE D. CABLE TELEVISION LIAISON OFFICER
SECTION:
1-5D-1: Office Created; Appointment; Term
1-5D-2: Duties
1-5D-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
There is hereby created the office of Cable Television Liaison Officer who
shall be a member of the Board of Trustees and shall be appointed by the
Village President with the advice and consent of the Village Board of Trustees
and who shall serve an initial term, terminating on May 1, 1988, and,
thereafter, shall serve a term of two (2) years, terminating on May 1, 1990,
and every other May 1 thereafter; provided, however, such Liaison Officer shall
continue to serve after his term until his successor has been appointed and
confirmed by the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 87-429, 4-14-87)
1-5D-2: DUTIES:
The duties of the Cable Television Liaison Officer shall be as follows:
   A.   To attend such meetings of the local cable television access group
(presently the Shorewood Community Cable Television, Inc.) as he may be
directed by the Board of Trustees and such additional meetings as he may choose
to attend and to report to the Board of Trustees, such actions of the access
group, as he deems appropriate.
   B.   To facilitate communication and cooperation between the Village Board
of Trustees, the local cable television access group and the Cable Television
Committee of the Village Board 1 .
   C.   To make recommendations to the Village Board of Trustees in regard to
provisions for the local cable television access group in the annual Village
budget and appropriation ordinance and in regard to the use of Village
buildings and equipment by the local cable television access group.
   D.   To perform such other like and similar duties as may, from time to
time, be designated by the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 87-429, 4-14-87)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  1-6-7 of this Title.
CHAPTER 6
ADMINISTRATIVE COMMITTEES AND CHAIRPERSONS
SECTION:
1-6-1: Definitions
1-6-2: Finance Committee
1-6-3: Strategic Planning Committee
1-6-4: Annexation Committee
1-6-5: Public Works Committee
1-6-6: Parks And Recreation Committee
1-6-7: Cable Television Committee
1-6-8: Citizens' Advisory Committee
1-6-9: Citizens' Recycling Committee
1-6-10: Beautification Committee
1-6-11: Building Feasibility Committee
1-6-12: Safety Committee
1-6-13: Police Chief Selection Committee
1-6-14: Chairman Of Special Events
1-6-15: Village Hall Expansion Committee
1-6-16: Flood Disaster Committee
1-6-17: Disaster Response Committee
1-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their
derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with
the context, words used in the plural number include the singular number and
words in the singular number include the plural number.
   BOARD: The board of trustees of the village of Shorewood, Will County,
Illinois.
   COMMITTEE: The appropriate committee of the village of Shorewood as created
by this chapter.
   PRESIDENT: The president of the village of Shorewood, Will County, Illinois.
   VILLAGE: The village of Shorewood, Will County, Illinois. (1994 Code)
1-6-2: FINANCE COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee; Membership: The finance committee shall consist of eight (8)
persons: the six (6) village trustees, the village president and a resident of
the village who does not hold any other elected or appointed office in the
village. One of the trustee members shall be the chairman of the committee and
shall call, chair and conduct all meetings held by the committee. Another
trustee member shall serve as vice chairman. The vice chairman shall chair and
conduct meetings in the absence of the chairman.
   B.   Appointment And Terms: The village president shall appoint the chairman
and vice chairman. The term of the chairman and vice chairman shall be four (4)
years or for such shorter term that he/she may hold the office of trustee. The
village resident member shall be appointed by the president with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees and serve a four (4) year term.
   C.   Secretary: The finance director or his or her designee shall serve as
the secretary for the committee.
   D.   Duties: The duties of the committee shall be:
      1.   From time to time, as it deems necessary and convenient, to make
recommendations to the village president and board of trustees in all matters
regarding or relating to the finances and/or financial policies of the village.
      2.   On or before March 1 of each year, to prepare and submit to the
president and board of trustees a proposed budget for the village and each
department thereof for the next ensuing fiscal year of the village.
      3.   On or before November 1 of each year, to prepare and submit to the
president and board of trustees the proposed annual tax levy ordinance for the
next ensuing fiscal year of the village.
      4.   To submit a written report of all committee actions and
recommendations as necessary to the president and board of trustees.
      5.   To investigate any and all financial matters and questions as are,
from time to time, submitted to the committee by the president or board of
trustees for investigation and to make recommendations concerning the same to
the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 11-1605, 1-11-2011)
1-6-3: STRATEGIC PLANNING COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Established; Composition; Residency: Subject to the
provisions of this section, the village hereby establishes a strategic planning
committee, which committee shall continue in existence for such time only as
determined appropriate by the president and the village board. The committee
shall consist of seven (7) members, including the chairperson. Each member of
the committee shall be a resident of the village at the time of his appointment
and during his incumbency. The chairperson shall be a member of the village
board at the time of his service as chairperson on the committee.
   B.   Appointment; Terms Of Office; Compensation:
      1.   The members of the committee shall be appointed by the president of
the village with the advice and consent of the board and shall serve without
compensation.
      2.   The initial terms of members of the committee appointed after the
effective date hereof shall be as follows:
         a.   Three (3) members shall be appointed to a one year term.
         b.   Three (3) members shall be appointed to a two (2) year term.
Upon the expiration of the initial terms set forth in subsections B2a and B2b
of this section, committee members shall be appointed for a term of two (2)
years; provided, however, that all members shall serve until their successors
have been duly appointed.
   C.   Vacancies And Removals From Office: Vacancies occurring on the
committee shall be filled for the unexpired term by an appointment by the
village president with the advice and consent of the board, and the village
president, with the advice and consent of the board, shall have the authority
to remove any member of the committee from office whenever, in the president's
discretion, the best interests of the village shall be served thereby.
   D.   Organization:
      1.   Chairperson: The village president, with the advice and consent of
the village board, shall appoint a village trustee to serve as chairperson to
preside over meetings of the committee. The chairperson shall call meetings of
the committee as may be necessary or convenient to fully perform the duties of
the committee as provided in this section.
      2.   Meetings: Meetings shall be held by the committee at the call of the
chairperson. A majority of all the members appointed to the committee shall
constitute a quorum at any meeting and the committee shall only act with a
quorum present.
      3.   Reports: The committee shall provide reports to the board as, from
time to time, may be necessary to fulfill the functions of the committee.
   E.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The strategic planning committee shall have the following powers and
duties:
         a.   To investigate and report to the president and board of trustees
as to whether it would be beneficial and appropriate for the village to become
a home rule unit of government. The strategic planning committee shall consider
the following in making its recommendation:
            (1)   The relative advantages and disadvantages of home rule status
to the village as a whole.
            (2)   The economic impact of home rule status both in terms of
economic development opportunities and revenue enhancement.
            (3)   The economic impact upon revenues paid to the village by its
residents, its business community, as well as "nonresidents".
            (4)   The probable impact upon real property and other taxes.
            (5)   The information gained from conducting at least one public
forum on the issue of home rule.
            (6)   The information gained from meeting with leaders of several
home rule communities.
            (7)   The information gained from studying the legal impact of
becoming a home rule community.
            (8)   The process for becoming a home rule unit.
            (9)   Any other information which the committee determines to be
valuable in making its analysis.
         b.   To, from time to time, review the progress of the implementation
of the village strategic plan dated September 1998, including:
            (1)   The objectives to be achieved by December 31, 1998.
            (2)   The objectives to be achieved by December 31, 1999.
            (3)   The objectives to be achieved by December 31, 2000.
            (4)   To report such findings and make such suggestions to the
president and board of trustees as are appropriate.
         c.   To, from time to time, investigate and report to the president
and board of trustees on such matters upon which they might direct.
         d.   The powers and duties of the strategic planning committee shall
be advisory and not binding. (Ord. 99-943, 6-8-1999)
1-6-4: ANNEXATION COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Established; Compensation; Residency: Subject to the
provisions of this section, the village hereby establishes an annexation
committee, which committee shall continue in existence for such time only as
determined appropriate by the president and the village board. The committee
shall consist of four (4) members, including the chairperson. Each member of
the committee shall be a resident of the village at the time of his appointment
and during his incumbency.
   B.   Appointment; Terms Of Office; Compensation:
      1.   The members of the committee shall be appointed by the president of
the village with the advice and consent of the board and shall serve without
compensation.
      2.   The members of the committee shall be appointed for a term of one
year and shall serve until their successors have been duly appointed. The
president, with the advice and consent of the board, shall have the authority
to reappoint members.
   C.   Vacancies And Removals From Office: Vacancies occurring on the
committee shall be filled for the unexpired term by an appointment by the
president of the village with the advice and consent of the board, and the
president of the village, with the advice and consent of the board, shall have
the authority to remove any member of the committee from office whenever, in
his discretion, the best interests of the village shall be served thereby.
   D.   Organization: The president of the village shall appoint a chairperson
to preside over meetings of the committee, which chairperson shall be a member
of the board. The chairperson shall call meetings of the committee as may be
necessary or convenient to fully perform the duties of the committee as
provided in this section. The committee shall not meet or conduct any business
without a quorum of its members.
   E.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The annexation committee shall have only the following powers and
duties:
         a.   To collect data and information which can be used to promote the
orderly development and expansion of the village.
         b.   To contact owners of and electors residing on property not within
the corporate limits of the village but within the area of the village
comprehensive plan 1  or service area to ascertain and discuss the feasibility
of annexing such property to the village, realizing, however, that all
decisions on the feasibility of and annexation by the village lies solely with
the village president and board.
         c.   To regularly confer with and advise the village president and
board on matters concerning the annexation, planning and development of such
property.
      2.   The powers and duties of the annexation committee are of an advisory
nature only. (Ord. 88-474, 8-9-1988; amd. 1994 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 9, chapter 1 of this code.
1-6-5: PUBLIC WORKS COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Established; Composition; Residency: Subject to the
provisions of this section, the village hereby establishes a public works
committee, which committee shall continue in existence for such time as
determined appropriate by the president and board. The committee shall consist
of seven (7) members, including the chairperson. Each member of the committee
shall be a resident of the village at the time of his appointment and during
his term of office. The chairperson shall be a member of the board.
   B.   Appointment; Term Of Office; Compensation:
      1.   The members of the committee, including the chairperson, shall be
appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board and shall
serve without compensation.
      2.   The nontrustee committee members originally appointed on or after
January 1, 1991, and prior to November 12, 1991, shall be appointed to terms in
conformance with the following: one shall be appointed as a committee member
for a term of twelve (12) months; one shall be appointed as a committee member
for a term of eighteen (18) months; one shall be appointed as a committee
member for a term of twenty four (24) months; and one shall be appointed as a
committee member for a term of thirty (30) months. The two (2) nontrustee
committee members originally appointed on or after November 12, 1991, shall be
appointed as committee members for terms of twelve (12) months. Each committee
member shall serve until his successor has been duly appointed.
      3.   The appointments made to the committee pursuant to the authority
vested by ordinances 88-481 and 90-572 are hereby affirmed as appointments to
the public works committee for duration of their prior respective terms; it
being the intention of this section to consolidate amendments to ordinance 88-
481 into one ordinance. All prior actions taken by the committee are hereby
affirmed.
   C.   Vacancies And Removals From Office: Vacancies occurring on the
committee shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment by the
president with the advice and consent of the board. The president, with the
advice and consent of the board, shall have the authority to remove any member
of the committee from office whenever, in the president's discretion, the best
interest of the village shall be served thereby.
   D.   Organization:
      1.   Chairperson: The president shall appoint a board member as
chairperson to preside over meetings of the committee. The chairperson shall
call meetings of the committee as may be necessary or convenient to fully
perform the duties of the committee as provided in this section.
      2.   Meetings: Meetings shall be held by the committee at the call of the
chairperson. A majority of all the members appointed to the committee shall
constitute a quorum at any meeting and the committee shall only act with a
quorum present.
      3.   Reports: The committee shall provide reports to the board as, from
time to time, may be necessary to fulfill the functions of the committee.
   E.   Powers And Duties: The public works committee shall have, but not be
limited to, the following powers and duties:
      1.   To investigate and study issues relating to the care, maintenance,
planning and/or development of water, sewer, streets and drainage systems which
currently exist or may exist in the future, not only in the village but in
areas surrounding the village. This shall include, but is not limited to, the
analysis of problems relating to sewage disposal and/or collection, property
maintenance problems affecting the public health or safety, the care,
maintenance and construction of streets, sidewalks and public ways and the
construction, maintenance and extension of street drains and stormwater sewers.
The Public Works Committee shall not have the power or duty to investigate and
study issues relating to garbage and refuse disposal or collection.
      2.   To provide an exchange of information between the public and the
Village Department of Municipal Utilities and Street Department on issues
relating to the care, maintenance, planning and/or development of water, sewer,
streets and drainage systems within the Village and areas surrounding the
Village.
      3.   To cooperate with and provide an exchange of information with the
Village Department of Municipal Utilities and Street Department on issues
relating to sanitation needs not only in the Village but in areas surrounding
the Village, including information necessary to resolve water, sewer and
drainage problems which currently exist or may develop in the future, the
development of innovative plans and programs to ensure that water, sewer and
drainage needs within the Village are satisfied and the formulation of
recommendations, from time to time, to the Board on preserving or expanding
existing water, sewer and drainage services and in making any changes in said
service which may be beneficial to the public.
      4.   To regularly confer with and advise the Village President and Board
on matters relating to water, sewer, streets and drainage issues.
      5.   To perform such other functions and duties as the committee may be,
from time to time, directed to perform by the Board.
The powers and duties of the Public Works Committee are of an advisory nature
only. (Ord. 91-614, 11-12-1991)
1-6-6: PARKS AND RECREATION COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Created; Composition; Appointment And Terms: There is hereby
created a Parks and Recreation Committee which shall consist of, two (2)
members of the Village Board of Trustees, who are charged with responsibility
for parks and recreational activities in the Village, and up to six (6)
residents of the Village. A Trustee member shall serve as a member of the Parks
and Recreation Committee as its Chair. The Chairman of the committee shall
call, chair, and conduct all meetings held by the committee. Additionally a
Trustee shall be appointed to serve as Vice Chair of the Parks and Recreation
Committee and shall preside as Chairman in the absence of the Chair. Neither
the Chairman of the committee nor the Vice Chair shall have a vote on matters
to come before the committee. The Chairman of the committee shall, when a
vacancy occurs or when terms of members are about to expire, submit to the
Village President a list of names of persons who are willing and whom the
Chairman deems well qualified to serve as members of the committee, and the
Village President shall appoint all members of the committee with the advice
and consent of the Village Board of Trustees. The President, with the advice
and consent of the Village Board shall have the right to remove any member of
the committee whenever, in the President's discretion, the best interest of the
Village will be served thereby. The term of the Trustee member shall be four
(4) years or for such shorter term that he may hold the Office of Trustee. The
initial terms of the other resident members shall be three (3) for two (2)
years and three (3) for one year thereafter, their successors shall serve two
(2) year terms.
   B.   Purpose: The purpose of the Parks and Recreation Committee shall be to
serve as an advisory committee generating ideas, suggestions and
recommendations and to otherwise assist in the running (volunteering) of
special events for the Village.
   C.   Powers And Duties: The duties of the committee shall be:
      1.   To assist in the positive facilitation of Village special events by
volunteering for a minimum of ten (10) hours per year at parks and recreation
events throughout the calendar year.
      2.   To make recommendations to the Village President and Board of
Trustees concerning the acquisition of parks, recreational sites and facilities
and equipment and recreational activities in the best interests of the
residents of the Village.
      3.   To review and make recommendations on any updates to Village
planning documents, which affect parks and recreation facilities, including but
not limited to the park facility study and land acquisition plan and Riverfront
Master Plan.
      4.   To periodically forward its ideas, suggestions and recommendations
to the Parks and Recreation Department for consideration, including but not
limited to events, programming, and grant application.
   D.   Meetings: The committee shall meet at least three (3) times per year.
Additional special meetings may be held periodically for planning or debriefing
within the season of each event. All meetings of the committee shall be open to
the public, and shall be conducted in accordance with the Illinois Open
Meetings Act. (Ord. 18-1881, 4-24-2018)
1-6-7: CABLE TELEVISION COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Created; Composition; Appointment And Terms: There is hereby
created a committee to be known as the Shorewood Cable Television Committee
which shall consist of four (4) members to be appointed by the Village
President, one of whom shall be a member of the Village Board of Trustees,
which member shall be the Chairman of the committee whose term shall be to the
end of the calendar year in which he is appointed. The other three (3) members
shall be appointed respectively for one, two (2) and three (3) year terms and
their successor appointees shall each serve for three (3) year terms. In the
event of resignation or inability of any committee member to serve as such
member, the Village President shall, without undue delay, appoint a successor
committee member to complete the unexpired vacant term.
   B.   Organization:
      1.   Meetings: The Cable Television Committee shall meet not less than
once each month during any period of time in which construction of cable
television lines and facilities occur. At the conclusion of the construction,
the committee shall meet at the call of the Chairman.
      2.   Vote Required: Each member of the committee, including its Chairman,
shall have a vote on matters to come before the committee. A three-fourths (3/
4) vote of the entire committee is required for approval of any recommendation
which the committee makes to the President and Board of Trustees. In the event
that such vote is taken at a meeting attended by only three (3) members of the
committee, a unanimous vote shall be required for such recommendation.
   C.   Failure To Attend Meetings: In the event that any member of the Cable
Television Committee shall fail to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the
committee without a valid excuse for the same deemed acceptable by the Village
President, the same shall be deemed to be a resignation by the committee
member.
   D.   Duties: The committee shall perform the following duties:
      1.   Review all applications for cable television franchises and
investigate the ability of the applicant to provide adequate cable television
services and make recommendations to the Village Board in connection therewith.
      2.   Review the construction of all cable television systems and all
monthly reports from the franchisee in regard to the same and make
recommendations as appropriate.
      3.   Review and hear complaints from subscribers to cable television and
attempt to mediate the same.
      4.   Review audit reports furnished by the franchisee and such other
books, documents and records of the franchisee as are submitted to the Village
or required by the Village Board and make recommendations in regard to the
same.
      5.   Review rates and charges to the television system subscribers and
make recommendations in connection with the same.
      6.   Coordinate the franchisee's local programming service to obtain its
best use of public facilities and make recommendations in regard to the same.
      7.   Perform all other tasks as may be required or deemed necessary in
the best interest of the Village. (Ord. 83-341, 1-8-1983)
1-6-8: CITIZENS' ADVISORY COMMITTEE:
   A.   A Citizens' Advisory Committee to the Village Board is established. The
Citizens' Advisory Committee shall consist of a Village Trustee selected by the
Village President and one resident over the age of 18 years who shall be a
voting member and one alternate who shall only vote in the absence of the
voting member from each of the following areas:
   Section 1   Saddlebrook Estates
         Heritage Hills
         Fields of Shorewood
   Section 2   Breckenridge
         Edgewater
         Huntington Village
         Summit Creek
   Section 3   Towne Center
         Towne Center 2
         Fox Bend
   Section 4   Rollingwood
         Brookforest North
         Shorewood Meadows
         Country West
         Robin Hill
         Brookforest
   Section 5   Walnut Trails
         Shorewood Glen
         Hunt Club
         The Vintage
   Section 6   Westfield Village
         River Oaks West
         River Oaks Estates
         Oakwood Manor
         River Bluff
   Section 7   Estates of Hidden Creek
         Kipling Estates
         Westminister Gardens
         Lake Forest
         Lake Forest South
   Section 8   The Manors
         River Oaks South
         River Crossing
         Lake of the Woods
         (North)
   B.   Appointment And Term Of Office: The terms of members of the Citizens'
Advisory Committee prior to the adoption of this subsection are hereby
terminated. The Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees shall appoint all voting members and alternates. The Village
President, with advice and consent of the Board, shall have the authority to
remove any member of the committee whenever, in the President's discretion, the
best interest of the Village would be served. All appointments shall be for a
term of two (2) years. Members shall serve until their successors are appointed
and confirmed.
   C.   Organization:
      1.   Chairperson: The Citizens' Advisory Committee shall be chaired by a
Trustee of the Village.
      2.   Meetings: The Advisory Committee shall meet at least monthly. Other
special meetings may be called either upon the written notice by the committee
Chairperson or a majority of the members of the committee. At least four (4)
days' notice is required to all committee members of any special meeting.
      3.   Quorum: A quorum shall consist of a majority of the appointed
members of the committee who are eligible to vote at the meeting.
      4.   Minutes: The Village shall provide the committee with a Secretary to
take and prepare complete and accurate minutes of its meetings and shall
distribute and make copies of those minutes to the Village Board. The Advisory
Committee shall cause these minutes to be kept and maintained.
   D.   Duties: The duties of the Citizens' Advisory Committee include:
      1.   Provide a forum for the Village and its residents to discuss and
address their ideas and comment upon issues facing the Village.
      2.   Disseminating information about the Village to neighborhood
residents which, for illustration, might include advising residents of Village
projects in their neighborhood.
      3.   Promoting an exchange of ideas between the Village and its
residents.
      4.   Participating in such projects as may, from time to time, be
requested by the Village Board.
      5.   Offering the Village Board suggestions and ideas for the betterment
of the Village.
   E.   Committee Volunteers: The Citizens' Advisory Committee Chair may select
additional committee members who may from time to time attend meetings and
advise or assist the committee on particular projects. These members shall
serve two-year terms. (Ord. 91-585, 6-11-1991; amd. Ord. 93-727, 12-14-1993;
Ord. 18-1882, 4-24-2018; Ord. 22-2032, 1-25-2022)
1-6-9: CITIZENS' RECYCLING COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Created; Composition: A Citizens' Recycling Committee to the
Village Board of Trustees is hereby created. The Citizens' Recycling Committee
shall consist of seven (7) residents of the Village who shall be appointed by
the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The
Village President shall designate one member of the committee to serve as its
Chairperson.
   B.   Village Administrator Serves As Liaison: The Village Administrator
shall serve as a liaison between the Citizens' Recycling Committee and the
President and Board of Trustees.
   C.   Functions And Duties: The mission of the Citizens' Recycling Committee
is to advise and make recommendations to the President and Board of Trustees
concerning the following:
      1.   To devise and develop methods of promoting the recycling of
residential, commercial and industrial waste in the Village.
      2.   To investigate and formalize an Educational Outreach Program to more
fully inform residents of the Village concerning recycling issues.
      3.   To design a brochure to help facilitate the implementation of a
Recycling Program.
      4.   To prepare articles for distribution in the Village Newsletter
concerning recycling issues.
      5.   To develop a recycling slogan.
      6.   To investigate the purchase of recycling bins.
      7.   To make recommendations concerning the expenditure of funds from the
Will County solid waste recycling grant.
   D.   Duration Of Committee: The Citizens' Recycling Committee shall be an ad
hoc committee and shall exist until such time as the mission and duties as
herein delineated are completed or until otherwise terminated by ordinance.
(Ord. 91-592, 7-9-1991)
1-6-10: BEAUTIFICATION COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Created: The Shorewood Beautification Committee is hereby
created, consisting of not more than fifteen (15) members who shall be
appointed by the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees.
   B.   Residence Requirements: All members of the Shorewood Beautification
Committee shall reside within the corporate limits of the Village.
   C.   Term Of Office: The initial committee shall be appointed for the
following terms: one-third (1/3) of the members shall be appointed for a term
of one year; one-third (1/3) of the members shall be appointed for a term of
two (2) years; and one-third (1/3) of the members, including the Chairman,
shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. Thereafter, all subsequent
appointments to the committee shall be for a term of three (3) years.
   D.   Meetings, Officers; Quorum: The committee Chairman shall be appointed
by the Village President with the advice and consent of the Village Board and
shall serve for a term of three (3) years or until a successor is duly
appointed. The committee shall meet from time to time on call of the Chairman.
A majority of the committee members shall constitute a quorum for the purpose
of transacting any business that may come before the committee.
   E.   Duties: The committee shall develop beautification projects including,
but not limited to landscaping, tree planting and flower planting and shall
recommend implementation of said projects to the Board of Trustees. After
obtaining the necessary permits from IDOT, the committee shall be particularly
concerned with the beautification of major roadway intersections, the planting
of trees along major roadways and the planting of shrubs and flowers at the
Village entrance signs and the Village Hall. (Ord. 92-638, 4-28-1992)
1-6-11: BUILDING FEASIBILITY COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Created: A Building Feasibility Committee to the Village
Board of Trustees is hereby created.
   B.   Composition: The Building Feasibility Committee shall consist of nine
(9) members as follows: one Trustee who will serve as Chairman, the Village
Administrator, the Chief Building Official, the Police Chief, the Village
Treasurer, one member of the Finance Committee and three (3) residents of the
Village, all who shall be appointed by the Village President with the advice
and consent of the Board of Trustees.
   C.   Duration Of Committee: The Building Feasibility Committee shall be an
ad hoc committee and shall exist until such time as the mission and duties as
hereafter delineated are completed or until otherwise terminated by ordinance.
   D.   Mission And Duties: The mission of the Building Feasibility Committee
is to advise and make recommendations to the President and Board of Trustees
concerning the following:
      1.   To study the use of existing space in the Village Hall.
      2.   If expansion is deemed unnecessary, to make recommendations for
improved use of space.
      3.   If expansion is deemed necessary, to make recommendations on size
and design.
      4.   If expansion is deemed necessary, to make recommendations on
projected costs and methods of financing. (Ord. 92-662, 9-22-1992; Ord. 20-
1982, 8-25-2020)
1-6-12: SAFETY COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Created; Composition; Duration:
      1.   Committee Created: A Safety Committee to the Village Board of
Trustees is hereby created. (Ord. 92-669, 10-27-1992)
      2.   Composition: The Safety Committee shall consist of five (5) members
as follows: the Administrative Assistant who will serve as Safety Coordinator,
the Village Administrator, the Chief Building Official, the Police Chief and
the Public Works Supervisor and who shall be appointed by the Village President
with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 95-805, 8-22-1995)
      3.   Duration: The Safety Committee shall exist until terminated by
ordinance.
   B.   Meetings: The Safety Committee shall hold regular meetings as often as
deemed necessary by the chairman. Minutes shall be taken and approved by the
Committee and distributed to the Board of Trustees.
   C.   Mission And Duties: The mission of the Safety Committee is as follows:
      1.   Develop and revise as needed a general safety manual setting forth
such items as loss control responsibility, self- inspection programs and
accident reporting, investigation and procedures. This manual shall be
presented to the Board of Trustees for approval.
      2.   Develop and revise as needed a specific safety manual pertinent to
each department. These manuals shall be presented to the Board of Trustees for
approval.
      3.   Bring the Village into compliance with current Illinois Department
of Labor and OSHA requirements.
      4.   Represent management's direction and commitment to safety.
      5.   Implement a self-inspection program with documentation.
      6.   Identify specific safety issues and implement control measures
through recommendations to the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 92-669, 10-27-1992;
amd. Ord. 20- 1982, 8-25-2020)
1-6-13: POLICE CHIEF SELECTION COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Created: A Police Chief Selection Committee to the Village
Board of Trustees is hereby created.
   B.   Composition: The Police Chief Selection Committee shall consist of five
(5) members as follows: one Trustee, the current Chief of Police, a member of
the Police and Fire Commission, one resident of the Village and one member of
the business community. The members shall be appointed by the Village President
with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The President will
appoint one member as chairman.
   C.   Duration Of Committee: The Police Chief Selection Committee shall be an
ad hoc Committee and shall exist until such time as the mission and duties as
hereafter delineated are completed or until otherwise terminated by ordinance.
   D.   Mission And Duties: The mission of the Police Chief Selection Committee
is to advise and make recommendations to the President and Board of Trustees
concerning the following:
      1.   Develop a job description and profile for the position of Chief of
Police.
      2.   Screen all resumes for the Chief of Police position.
      3.   Select ten (10) potential candidates to interview for position.
      4.   Interview the ten (10) selected candidates.
      5.   After interviews have been completed, select three (3) candidates to
be recommended to the Village Board. (Ord. 93-706, 8-24-1993)
1-6-14: CHAIRMAN OF SPECIAL EVENTS:
   A.   Chairmanship Created; Appointment: The Chairmanship of Special Events
is hereby created subject to the provisions of this Section. The Chairman of
Special Events shall be appointed from among the members of the Board of
Trustees by the Village President subject to the advice and consent of the
Board of Trustees.
   B.   Duties: The Chairman of Special Events shall be responsible to the
elected body for the performance of the following:
      1.   Making policy recommendations to the Village President and Board of
Trustees regarding:
         a.   Appropriate occasions or persons to be recognized.
         b.   Appropriate type of event for the occasion or person to be
recognized.
         c.   Annual budget for special events.
      2.   Plan and supervise special events, including:
         a.   Determining date, time and place.
         b.   Arranging for food and refreshments (as appropriate).
         c.   Acting on behalf of the elected body in contractual agreements
for facilities, catering and entertainment (as appropriate).
         d.   Assure that the appropriate persons are properly compensated.
      3.   Chair ad hoc committees appointed by the Village President, with the
advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, as, from time to time, necessary
to assist in special events activities.
   C.   Relationship With Village Staff: The Village Administrator and other
staff members assist the chairman by providing advice and information as
requested. The chairman does not direct, supervise or act as advocate for
Village employees at any level of the organization. (Ord. 87-433, 5-12-1987)
1-6-15: VILLAGE HALL EXPANSION COMMITTEE:
   A.   Creation And Composition Of Committee: A Village Hall Expansion
Committee of the Village of Shorewood be and the same is hereby created.
The Village Hall Expansion Committee shall consist of seven (7) members as
follows: one Trustee who will serve as chairman, the Village Administrator, the
Chief Building Official, the Police Chief, the Village Treasurer, the Trustee
(chairman) of the Finance Committee, and the Superintendent of the Public Works
Department, all who shall be appointed by the Village President with the advice
and consent of the Board of Trustees. The Village President shall serve as a ex
officio member of the Committee.
   B.   Duration Of Committee: The Village Hall Expansion Committee shall be an
ad hoc committee and shall exist until such time as the mission and duties as
hereafter delineated are completed or until otherwise terminated by ordinance.
   C.   Mission And Duties Of The Committee: The mission of the Village Hall
Expansion Committee is to advise and make recommendations to the President and
Board of Trustees concerning the following:
      1.   To study the use of existing space in the Village Hall.
      2.   To make recommendations on size and design of the expansion of the
Village Hall and to oversee the construction of the facility until completed.
      3.   To make recommendations on the expansion, in particular, of the
Shorewood Police Department utilizing the space in the existing Village
Boardroom, and to oversee the construction until completed.
      4.   To make recommendations on projected costs and methods of financing.
(Ord. 95-776, 1-24-1995; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
1-6-16: FLOOD DISASTER COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Created: There is hereby created an ad hoc advisory committee
to be known as the Flood Disaster Committee (the "Flood Committee") to work
with Federal, State, and local officials to advise the President and Board of
Trustees as to problems created by the July 1996 flood and to identify
potential solutions to those problems.
   B.   Flood Committee Membership: The Flood Committee shall be composed of
ten (10) members who shall be appointed by the Village President with the
advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
   C.   Flood Committee Duties: The Committee shall work with Village staff and
the staff of Federal, State, and local agencies to:
      1.   Identify problems created by the flood and suggest possible
solutions to the President and Board of Trustees.
      2.   Explore potential sources of relief which are available to flood
victims.
      3.   Make suggestions to the President and Board of Trustees and Village
staff as to a schedule to implement any and all suggestions.
      4.   Consider any and all other business which relates to the flood and
make recommendations with regard to same.
   D.   Flood Committee Chairperson: The Village President with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees shall name one of the Flood Committee members
to serve as Committee chairperson and to serve as liaison to the President and
Board of Trustees.
   E.   Flood Committee Secretary: The Flood Committee shall select one of its
members to serve as secretary to the Committee to prepare minutes of each
meeting.
   F.   Flood Committee Duration: The Flood Committee shall terminate when its
business is concluded. (Ord. 96-849, 8-13-1996)
1-6-17: DISASTER RESPONSE COMMITTEE:
   A.   Committee Created: There is hereby created an ad hoc advisory committee
to be known as the "Disaster Response Committee" to work with appropriate
Federal, State, and local officials to develop a proposed plan to respond to
future natural disasters which might occur in the Village.
   B.   Disaster Response Committee Membership: The Disaster Response Committee
shall be composed of a total of twelve (12) members who shall be appointed by
the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
Provided, however, that the Shorewood Emergency Coordinator shall be a member
of the Committee and one Village Trustee shall also be a member of the
Committee.
   C.   Disaster Response Committee Duties: The Committee shall work with the
staff of the Village and other local, State, and Federal agencies to identify
appropriate responses to future natural disasters which may occur in the
Village and to recommend to the Village a Natural Emergency Response Plan which
may be implemented in times of emergency to coordinate resources of various
agencies to best serve the Village.
   D.   Disaster Response Committee Chairperson: The Village Trustee member
shall serve as chairperson of the Disaster Response Committee and a liaison
between the Committee and the Village President and Board of Trustees.
   E.   Disaster Response Committee Secretary: The Disaster Response Committee
shall select one of its members to serve as secretary to prepare minutes of
each meeting. (Ord. 96-850, 8-13-1996)
CHAPTER 7
MUNICIPAL FINANCES
SECTION:
1-7-1: Payment Of Bills; Purchases
1-7-2: Checks With Insufficient Funds
1-7-3: Wage Rates For Public Works Employees
1-7-4: Cash Contributions For Library Purposes
1-7-5: Development Application Fees
1-7-1: PAYMENT OF BILLS; PURCHASES:
   A.   The Village Administrator shall have the authority to issue and sign
drafts upon the General Corporate Fund and all other funds of the Village for
payment of supplies, repair bills and other bills that occur in the day to day
operation of the business of the Village.
   B.   The Village Administrator shall further have the authority to issue and
sign drafts upon the General Corporate Fund and all other funds of the Village
for payment for services rendered by any person that occur in the day to day
operation of the business of the Village; provided, that for any purchase of
services where the amount of the purchase exceeds five hundred dollars
($500.00), any such purchase or payment must be approved by the Board. Only
after such submission and approval shall the Administrator have authority to
issue a draft for the purchase of supplies or services set out in this proviso.
Violation of the provisions in this subsection will result in disciplinary
action with a hearing before the Village Board. (Ord. 90-542, 6-12-1990)
1-7-2: CHECKS WITH INSUFFICIENT FUNDS:
A fee in the amount of twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall be assessed against
all persons who present to the Village a check which is dishonored or upon
which payment is refused in attempting to pay for any service provided for or
charge levied by the Village, and such fee shall be assessed for immediate
payment or added to the balance owing of the person presenting the check. (Ord.
06-1341, 1-24-2006)
1-7-3: WAGE RATES FOR PUBLIC WORKS EMPLOYEES:
   A.   To the extent and as required by the Prevailing Wage Act, the general
prevailing rate of wages in this locality for laborers, mechanics and other
workers engaged in construction of public works projects coming under the
jurisdiction of the Village is hereby determined to be the same as the
prevailing rate of wages for construction work in Will County area as
determined by the Department of Labor of the State of Illinois as of September
2017, a copy of that determination being exhibit A on file in the Village and
incorporated herein by reference. The definition of any terms appearing in this
section which are also used in aforesaid Act shall be the same as in said Act.
   B.   Nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply said general
prevailing rate of wages as herein ascertained to any work or employment except
public works construction of the Village to the extent required by the
aforesaid Act.
   C.   The Village Administrator shall publicly post or keep available for
inspection by any interested party in the main office of this Village this
determination of such prevailing rate of wage.
   D.   The Village Administrator shall mail a copy of this determination to
any employer, and to any association of employers and to any person or
association of employees who have filed their names and addresses, requesting
copies of any determination stating the particular rates and the particular
class of workers whose wages will be affected by such rates. (Ord. 18-1887, 6-
12-2018)
1-7-4: CASH CONTRIBUTIONS FOR LIBRARY PURPOSES:
   A.   Contributions Required; Amount:
      1.   Residential Subdivisions And Planned Unit Developments:
         a.   As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision or of a
final plat of a planned unit development, each subdivider or developer will be
required to pay a cash contribution for library purposes to serve the immediate
and future needs of the residents of the development. The amount of cash
contributions shall be four hundred twenty five dollars ($425.00) for each
detached single-family residential lot or parcel.
         b.   For multi-family residential property, the cash contribution
shall be four hundred twenty five dollars ($425.00) for each unit; a "unit" is
defined as space intended or designed as a dwelling for one family (e.g., for a
4-unit apartment building, the contribution is $1,700.00).
      2.   Annexations: The cash contribution required by this section shall
also be required as a condition to the annexation of any land to the Village,
and provisions therefor shall be incorporated in any preannexation agreement
governing such land.
   B.   Time Of Payment: The cash contributions required by this section shall
be paid to the Village at the time of issuance of a residential building
permit. The Village shall disburse such contributions to the library district
quarterly.
   C.   Disposition Of Contributions; Refunds: Contributions received by the
library pursuant to this section may be used as the library deems appropriate.
No party shall have any claim or right to a refund of cash contributions paid
pursuant to this section. (Ord. 17-1839, 3-28-2017)
1-7-5: DEVELOPMENT APPLICATION FEES:
   A.   Application Fee: At the time of any application for annexation
(including an annexation agreement), subdivision or planned unit development,
conditional use, map amendment, variance, site plan, concept plan or other
petition, the applicant shall pay the Village the fee(s) applicable to said
application in accordance with the fee schedule as from time to time are
established by the Village.
Annexation:                        
 Single lot residential          $350.00
 Multiple lot residential        $850.00 plus $50.00 per dwelling unit
 Nonresidential                  $850.00 plus $100.00 per acre or fraction
                                  thereof
Preliminary subdivision plat:      
 Single lot residential          $250.00
 Multiple lot residential        $750.00 plus $50.00 per dwelling unit
 Nonresidential                  $750.00 plus $100.00 per acre or fraction
                                  thereof
Final subdivision plat:            
 Single lot residential          $250.00
 Multiple lot residential        $750.00 plus $50.00 per dwelling unit
 Nonresidential                  $750.00 plus $100.00 per acre or fraction
                                  thereof
Conditional use permit:            
 Including amendments            $400.00
 For a planned unit development, $1,150.00 plus $400.00 for each
  including amendments            additional CUP request embodied in PUD
Rezoning/map amendment            $650.00
Variance:                          
 Single lot residential          $225.00
 Nonresidential and multiple lot $650.00 per requested deviation
  residential
                                  $250.00 for sites up to 2 acres in size;
Concept plan review               $500.00 for sites 2 acres or larger in
                                  size
Site plan review                  $2,000.00 plus $100.00 per acre or
                                  fraction thereof
Site plan amendment               $500.00 plus $100.00 per acre or fraction
                                  thereof
 
   B.   Liability For Fees; Filing Fee: All annexation agreements submitted to
the Village pursuant to the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-
15-1 et seq., and all plats of subdivision, plats of planned unit development,
conditional use permits, map amendments, variances, concept plans, site plans
and other approvals for consideration shall be accompanied by a petition
requesting that the Village take the appropriate prescribed action thereon and
stating that the petitioner is aware of and will abide by the provisions of
this section and pay all fees and expenses required hereby in addition to all
other fees and expenses otherwise by law or ordinance required. All such
applications or petitions shall be accompanied with the appropriate filing fee
in the amount provided heretofore and hereafter in other ordinances of the
Village.
   C.   Additional Costs And Expenses:
      1.   Professional Fee Agreement: Any developer, person, entity,
corporation, association or group filing an application with the planning and
zoning commission or with the village for any approvals as set forth in Titles
10 and 11, Shorewood Crossroads Zoning and Shorewood Subdivision and
Development Ordinances, respectively, or as required by Title 8, Building
Regulations, shall at the time of the execution of said petition or application
or at any time the Village must engage a third-party consultant sign a written
agreement to fully reimburse the Village for any and all third-party consulting
fees and expenses ("Professional Fees") incurred by the Village in connection
with processing and administering said petition or application ("Project") from
the date of the application through the Project's completion, on a form
approved by the Village, and submit a Professional Fee Security in an amount
determined by the Zoning Officer. Professional Fees include, but are not
limited to, third-party attorneys, land planners, engineers, and financial,
traffic and transportation consultants. Professional Fees shall include, but
are not limited to, all expenses associated with review, analysis, discussions,
meetings, inspections, planning and other work or services performed on behalf
of the Village in conjunction with the Project.
      2.   Payment: In the event that there is an outstanding balance for
Professional Fees, the Village may direct staff and third-party consultants to
cease work on the Project until the outstanding balance is paid in full. If the
Project has progressed to the stage where a building or occupancy permit is
ready to be issued, such permits may be withheld until all outstanding balances
are paid to the satisfaction of the Village.
   D.   Fees Are Additional: The fees and expenses required by any other
ordinance of the Village, both now in force or hereinafter adopted, shall not
be affected hereby, it being the express intention that the fees and expenses
herein provided be in addition to and not in lieu of such fees and expenses
provided for in other ordinances. (Ord. 10-1581, 4-13-2010; amd. Ord. 20-1962,
1-14-2020)
CHAPTER 8
MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS
SECTION:
1-8-1: Soliciting for a Candidate at Poll Site
1-8-2: Vehicle Parking
1-8-3: Enforcement
1-8-4: Penalty
1-8-1: SOLICITING FOR A CANDIDATE AT POLL SITE:
No candidate or representative of a candidate shall solicit votes within the
property boundary lines of the grounds of the Shorewood Municipal Building or
any other polling place on election day; provided, however, that this provision
shall not exclude a candidate or his representative poll watchers from being
present at polling places as provided by the laws of the State governing poll
watchers 1 . (Ord. 79-302, 11-27-79)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 10 ILCS 5/17-23.
1-8-2: VEHICLE PARKING:
No vehicle shall be parked in such a manner as to interfere in any way with any
voter or person in transit to or from a polling place, and no vehicle shall be
parked within the boundary lines of the Shorewood Municipal Building grounds or
any other polling place grounds which shall exhibit signs, other than usual and
normal sized bumper stickers, advertising any political candidate 1 . (Ord. 79-
302, 11-27-79)

  8-4-1 of this Code for political campaign signs.

During the hours of polling for each Village election, a Shorewood Village
police officer shall periodically check and patrol each polling place to
enforce the provisions of this Chapter, to keep the peace and regulate traffic
in the parking area of the polling place. (Ord. 79-302, 11-27-79)

CHAPTER 9
DEDICATION OF PARK LANDS OR PAYMENT OF FEES
SECTION:
1-9-1: Criteria For Determining Land Dedication Or Fee
1-9-2: Density Formula
1-9-3: Reservation Of Additional Land
1-9-4: Combining With Adjoining Development
1-9-5: Site Requirements
1-9-6: Prerequisite To Annexation Agreement
1-9-7: Time Of Dedication Or Payment
1-9-8: Method Of Payment
1-9-9: Park Pavilion Rental
1-9-1: CRITERIA FOR DETERMINING LAND DEDICATION OR FEE:
As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision or of a final plat of
planned unit development, each applicant for subdivision approval, subdivider
or developer is required to dedicate land for park and recreation purposes to
serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the proposed
development or to make a cash contribution in lieu of actual land dedication or
a combination of both, at the option of the Village, in accordance with the
following criteria and formula: (Ord. 90-562, 12-11-1990)
   A.   Criteria For Requiring Park And Recreation Land Dedication:
      1.   Requirement And Population Ratio: The ultimate density of a proposed
development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required for
dedication. The total requirement shall be ten (10) acres of land per one
thousand (1,000) of ultimate population. (Ord. 05-1290, 4-26-2005)
      2.   Location: The location of the site to be dedicated shall be
determined by the Board of Trustees considering recommendations of the Plan
Commission and the Parks and Recreation Committee, taking into account the
suitability of the park site for recreation purposes or development and its
relationship to population concentrations. A park site which is not less than
five (5) acres shall be considered a requirement adjoining all elementary and
junior high schools constructed after the effective date hereof. A central
location which will serve equally the entire development is most desirable. In
large developments, these sites may be located throughout the development,
taking into account the Village's Comprehensive Plan 1 .
      3.   Credit For Private Open Spaces And Recreation Areas: When
subdividers or developers provide their own open space for recreation areas and
facilities, it may have the effect of reducing the demand for local public
recreation areas and services. Such private open space, however, is difficult
to develop and maintain, since ownership usually is surrendered to the adjacent
property owners or to a homeowners' association who may not have the personnel
or financial resources to ensure adequate maintenance and improvement of the
facilities. Nevertheless, some instances might exist in which the public is
better served by providing for private open space in lieu of public open space.
Credit for private open space may be allowed only when the Village Board of
Trustees has determined that private open space or recreation areas will, by
reason of the type of development, better serve the interests of the public.
Where allowed, a substitution of private open space for dedicated parks will
imply a substantially higher degree of improvement and the installation of
recreation facilities, including equipment by the developer, as part of his
obligation. Detailed plans of such areas, including specifications of
facilities to be installed, must be approved by the Village. Before any credit
is given for private recreation areas, the subdivider or developer must
guarantee that these private recreation areas will be permanently maintained
for such use by the execution of the appropriate legal documents. When an
adjustment for private recreation areas is warranted, it will be necessary to
compute the total park land dedication that would have been required from the
subdivision or planned unit development and then subtract the credit to be
given for the private open space, the amount of which credit shall be
determined by the Village Board of Trustees and may consist of a credit for the
total requirement or any fraction thereof. (Ord. 90-562, 12-11-1990)
      4.   Stormwater Facilities: The Village shall not permit stormwater
retention or detention facilities to be the site dedicated to the Village, nor
shall the subdivider or developer be given credit for such stormwater detention
or retention facilities as open spaces or recreation areas. (Ord. 94-768, 11-
22-1994)
   B.   Criteria For Requiring A Cash Contribution In Lieu Of Park And
Recreation Land Dedication:
      1.   Requirement And Use Of Contributions: Where the development is small
and the resulting sites would be too small to be practical or when the
available land is inappropriate for park and recreation purposes, the Village
shall require the subdivider or developer to pay a cash contribution in lieu of
the land dedication required. The cash contributions in lieu of park and
recreation land dedication shall be paid to the Village prior to or upon the
issuance of building permits for any building or structure located within the
subdivision or planned unit development. Such contributions shall be used
solely for the acquisition of park and recreation land as hereinabove
classified, which will be available to serve the immediate or future needs of
the residents of that subdivision or development or for the improvement of
other existing local park and recreation land which already serves such needs.
(Ord. 90-562, 12-11-1990)
      2.   Fair Market Value As Basis Of Contribution: The cash contributions
in lieu of land shall be based on the "fair market value" of the number of
acres of improved land that otherwise would have been dedicated as park and
recreation sites. It has been determined that the present "fair market value"
of such improved land in and surrounding the Village is forty six thousand six
hundred seventy six dollars ($46,676.00) per acre, and such figure shall be
used in making any calculation herein unless the subdivider or developer of a
planned unit development shall submit a written appraisal showing the "fair
market value" of such improved land in the area of his subdivision or planned
unit development or other evidence thereof. The final determination of the
"fair market value" per acre of such improved land shall be made by the village
board based upon such information submitted by the subdivider or developer of a
planned unit development and from other sources which may be submitted to the
village board. (Ord. 12-1665, 7-24-2012)
   C.   Criteria For Requiring Land Dedication And A Cash Contribution: There
will be situations in subdivisions or planned unit developments when a
combination of land dedication and cash contributions are both necessary. These
occasions will arise when:
      1.   Only a portion of the proposed park site is located on the property
to be developed. That portion of the park location located within the
subdivision or planned unit development shall be dedicated as a park or
recreation site as herein provided, and in addition thereto, a cash
contribution shall be required for additional acreage which would have
otherwise been required had the entire park or recreation site been located
within the development.
      2.   A major part of the park site has already been acquired, and only a
small portion of land is needed from the development to complete the site. The
remaining portions necessary to be acquired shall be required by dedication,
and cash contributions shall be required for the remaining acreage. (Ord. 90-
562, 12-11-1990)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 9, chapter 1 of this Code.

1-9-3: RESERVATION OF ADDITIONAL LAND:
Nothing herein contained shall limit the authority of the village to require
the designation and reservation of other recreational land, school sites or
other public lands as a condition for approval of any plat of subdivision or
planned unit development where such land is to be acquired by condemnation
within one year from final plat approval as set forth under division 12 of
article 11 of the Illinois municipal code 1  as amended. (Ord. 90-562, 12-11-
1990)
