transfers the ownership or control of the business, except for transfer by
bequest or other operation of law upon the death of the person possessing the
ownership or control. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-3: CLASSIFICATION:
The following are classified as adult oriented businesses:
   Adult arcades;
   Adult bookstores, adult novelty stores, and adult video stores;
   Adult cabarets;
   Adult entertainers;
   Adult massage establishments (prohibited);
   Adult motels (prohibited);
   Adult motion picture theaters;
   Adult theaters;
   Escort agencies;
   Escorts;
   Nude model studios; and
   Sexual encounter centers (prohibited). (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-4: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   Required: It is unlawful for any person to do the following without
first obtaining an adult oriented business license issued by the village
pursuant to this chapter:
      1.   Operate an adult oriented business;
      2.   Manage an adult oriented business;
      3.   Become an employee of an adult oriented business;
      4.   Engage in escort services; or
      5.   Perform as an adult entertainer.
Further, it is unlawful to employ a person to work, or contract a person to
work, in an adult oriented business who does not have a valid adult oriented
business license issued by the village pursuant to this chapter. It shall be
the duty of the operator and manager to ensure that all persons employed or
contracted to perform work at, for, or in connection with the business, provide
proof of current, valid adult oriented business licensure from the village of
Shorewood.
   B.   Application Form: An application for an adult oriented business license
must be made on a form provided by the village and must include all documents
which are required by this chapter to be attached.
   C.   Qualifications: All applicants must be qualified according to the
provisions of this chapter. The application may request, and the applicant
shall provide, such information as to enable the village to determine whether
the applicant meets the qualifications established in this chapter.
   D.   Operator: A person who wishes to operate an adult oriented business
must complete and sign an application for a license. If an entity, or person
other than an individual, wishes to operate an adult oriented business, then
all individuals who own the entity, and all other individuals who would be
legally responsible for the operations of the adult oriented business and/or
who would have ownership and/or the power to control or direct the operations
of the adult oriented business, must sign the license application as an
applicant. Such persons include, but are not limited to, general partners,
corporate officers, corporate directors, and controlling shareholders. Each
application must be qualified under the following section and each applicant
shall be considered a licensee if a license is granted.
   E.   Information Required On Application: The completed application for an
adult oriented business license for an operator, manager, employee or
entertainer shall contain the following information and shall be accompanied by
the following documents:
      1.   If the applicant is:
         a.   An individual, the individual shall state his/her legal name and
submit proof that he/she is eighteen (18) years of age or older;
         b.   A partnership, the partnership shall state its complete name, and
the names of all partners, whether the partnership is general or limited, and a
copy of the partnership agreement, if any;
         c.   A corporation, the corporation shall state its complete name, the
date of its incorporation, evidence that the corporation is in good standing
under the laws of its state of incorporation, the names of all officers,
directors and controlling stockholders holding five percent (5%) or more
interest, and the name of the registered corporate agent and the address of the
registered office for service of process; or any other type of entity, the
entity shall state its complete name, the type of entity it is, the names of
all persons with ownership interest; and the name and address of the registered
agent for service of process.
      2.   If the applicant intends to operate an adult oriented business under
a name other than that of the applicant, or intends to perform entertainment in
an adult oriented business under a name other than that of the applicant, then
he or she must state:
         a.   The adult oriented business' fictitious name; and
         b.   Submit the required registration documents; or
         c.   The name under which the applicant will be performing, whichever
applies.
      3.   The classification of license for which the applicant is filing
(example: operator, manager, employee, entertainer or escort).
      4.   The location of a proposed new adult oriented business, proposed
place of employment or proposed place where adult entertainment or escort
services will be offered or provided, including the street address and
telephone number(s) for the business.
      5.   Brief description of the products and/or services which will be
provided by the business.
      6.   An operator applicant must provide a sketch or diagram showing the
configuration of the premises, including a statement of total floor space
occupied by the business. The sketch or diagram need not be professionally
prepared, but it must be drawn to a designated scale or drawn with marked
dimensions of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six
inches (±6").
      7.   An operator applicant must provide a certificate and straight line
drawing prepared by a registered land surveyor which was prepared within thirty
(30) days prior to the application. It shall certify:
         a.   That there are no properties containing other adult oriented
businesses, residences or residentially zoned districts, religious
institutions, schools, daycare or childcare businesses, cemeteries or public
parks or recreation areas within three hundred fifty feet (350') of the
property line of the property to be certified. This measurement is to be made
by measuring from the closest points of one property line to the other property
line; or
         b.   The location of property lines of any properties within three
hundred fifty feet (350') of the property line of the property to be certified
which contain any other adult oriented businesses, residences or residentially
zoned districts, religious institutions, schools, daycare or childcare
businesses, cemeteries, or public parks or recreation areas.
      8.   The application shall be sworn to be true and correct by each
applicant.
      9.   It is the duty of each licensee to provide the village with updated
information should there be a change in any of the information printed on the
application, or depicted in any diagrams or other exhibits provided in
connection with the application, at any time.
   F.   More Than One Business: If licensee wishes to operate or conduct more
than one adult oriented business on the premises, then licensee must have a
license for each business, except that a business which combines an adult
bookstore and/or an adult video store with an adult novelty store may operate
under a single license for an adult novelty store so long as it complies with
all regulations which apply to adult bookstores and/or adult video stores, or
both, whichever is applicable.
   G.   Posting Of License: The license for each adult oriented business must
be conspicuously posted near the front entrance.
   H.   Preexisting Adult Oriented Businesses: Any adult oriented business in
existence on the effective date hereof need only comply with the requirements
of subsection
 3-17-14D of this chapter. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-5: ISSUANCE OF A LICENSE:
   A.   Upon the filing of an application for a manager, employee, or adult
entertainer adult oriented business license, the village shall conduct a
preliminary application review and if no disqualifying issues are discovered
relating to the applicant, then within ten (10) business day from receipt of
the application, the village shall issue a temporary license to the applicant
which shall be effective during the application review and investigation
process. The application shall then be referred to the appropriate village
departments for an investigation to be made on such information as is contained
in the application. The village shall issue a license or issue a written letter
of intent to deny the license within thirty (30) days from the date the
completed application is filed. After the investigation, the village shall
issue a license, unless one or more of the following is true:
      1.   Applicant has falsely answered a question or failed to provide
information or materials requested on the application;
      2.   Applicant is under the age of eighteen (18) years old;
      3.   The license is to be used for employment in, contract work at, or
work in connection with, a business which is prohibited by local, state, or
federal law, or otherwise prohibited by a provision of this chapter;
      4.   Any applicable license fee has not been paid;
      5.   Applicant's business has been out of compliance with this chapter;
      6.   Applicant's business is not in compliance with the village's zoning
ordinances;
      7.   Applicant has failed to comply with other county, state, or federal
regulations related to the conduct of the business or license;
      8.   Applicant is delinquent on a debt owed to the village;
      9.   Applicant has allowed criminal activity to occur on the premises.
If the adult oriented business employee license is denied, the temporary
license previously issued is immediately deemed null and void. Denial,
suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this subsection shall
be subject to appeal as set forth in section
3-17-12 of this chapter.
   B.   The village shall issue an adult oriented business operating license or
issue a written letter of intent to deny the license within thirty (30) days
from the date the completed application is filed. The village shall approve the
issuance of a license to an applicant unless one or more of the following is
true:
      1.   The applicant is under eighteen (18) years of age;
      2.   The applicant is overdue in payment to the village of taxes or any
other debt to the village, or owes fees, fines or penalties in relation to any
adult oriented business in any municipality or county;
      3.   The applicant has falsely answered a question or failed to provide
information requested on the application form;
      4.   The premises to be used for the adult oriented business have been
disapproved by the health department, fire department, and/or village building
official as being in violation of health, fire or building codes;
      5.   The license fee required by this chapter has not been paid;
      6.   The premises of the proposed establishment is in violation of or is
not in compliance with any of the provisions of this chapter; or
      7.   The applicant is ineligible for a village business license.
Denial, suspension or revocation of a license issued pursuant to this
subsection shall be subject to appeal as set forth in section
3-17-12 of this chapter.
   C.   The license, if granted, shall state on its face the name of the person
or persons to whom it is granted, the expiration date, whether it is for an
operator, manager, employee, entertainer or escort, the address of the adult
oriented business, and the classification of the business for which the license
is issued pursuant to section
3-17-3 of this chapter.
   D.   A license granted pursuant to this section shall be subject to annual
renewal upon the written application of the applicant, including an attestation
that there have been no acts committed that would constitute denial and that
the licensee has complied with all requirements of this act, and a finding by
the village that the applicant has not committed any act during the existence
of the previous license that would be grounds to deny the initial license
application. The renewal of the license shall be subject to the payment of a
fee as set forth in section
3-17-6 of this chapter.
   E.   The health department, fire department and the building official shall
complete a certification as to whether the premises is in compliance or not
within twenty (20) days of receipt of the application by the village. The
request for certification shall be made by the village. Failure to complete a
certification within such time shall not be a basis for denying a license.
   F.   An adult oriented business license shall be issued for only one
classification listed in section
3-17-3 if this chapter, except as otherwise provided in subsection
3-17-4F of this chapter. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-6: FEES:
   A.   The following annual fees shall apply to adult oriented business
licenses:
Adult arcades                                                   $1,625.00/year
Adult bookstores, adult novelty stores, and adult video stores, 500.00/year
or any combination thereof
Adult cabarets                                                  1,625.00/year
Adult entertainers                                              250.00/year
Adult motion picture theaters                                   1,625.00/year
Adult theaters                                                  1,625.00/year
Employee                                                        No fee
Escort agencies                                                 1,625.00/year
Escorts                                                         250.00/year
Nude model studios                                              500.00/year
 
   B.   In addition to the above annual fees, every initial application for the
issuance of an adult oriented business operating license shall be accompanied
by an investigation fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). (Ord. 09-1549,
9-22-2009)
3-17-7: ADDITIONAL DUTIES OF ALL LICENSEES UNDER THIS CHAPTER:
   A.   All adult oriented business licenses for operators, managers,
employees, entertainers and escorts shall be posted in a conspicuous place at,
or near, the entrance to the adult oriented business so that each one may be
easily read at any time. In addition, the adult oriented business license of
the manager on duty shall be conspicuously posted at all times in a way so that
the license for the manager currently on duty is easily ascertainable at any
given time.
   B.   Each licensee shall notify the village of Shorewood of any transaction
or formal proposal of a transaction which would transfer ownership or control
of an adult oriented business. (See section
3-17-2 of this chapter for the definition of "transfer of ownership or control
of an adult oriented business".) Licenses are not transferable to any other
person or entity.
   C.   Each licensee who is an operator or manager, or any other licensee who
oversees one or more employees, representatives or agents of an adult oriented
business, has a duty to monitor the premises at all times and exercise
reasonable prudence in the supervision of all employees and patrons on the
premises of the adult oriented business at all times, and shall not knowingly
or recklessly condone, allow, or fail to exercise available supervisory
authority to prevent a violation of this chapter by any employee or other
person contracted to work in the business, or any other person on the premises.
A violation of this chapter by an employee shall be deemed to also be a
violation by the operator, manager, and/or other employee who was authorized to
oversee the employee, if the violation occurred with his or her authorization,
encouragement, or approval, or if the operator, manager and/or other employee
with authority to oversee the conduct was negligent in his or her supervision
over that employee, and shall be considered during any investigation
determining whether to suspend or revoke his or her license.
   D.   No owner, operator, or employee shall engage in, or permit on the
premises, the occurrence of: solicitation for prostitution, prostitution,
masturbation, sexual intercourse, sodomy, or other contact stimulation of the
genitalia, or engage in, or permit the occurrence of, any act constituting the
offense of obscenity under the Illinois criminal code on the premises.
   E.   Each licensee has a duty to immediately report any criminal conduct
occurring on the premises of which he or she is aware, or becomes aware, to the
proper law enforcement agency.
   F.   The operator shall maintain a register of all employees, which are
required to be licensed under this chapter, showing each person's name, age,
birth date, date of employment or date when services were otherwise performed
at the business by the person, date of termination of employment or contractual
relationship, duties of each person, and a copy of each such person's adult
oriented business license. The above information on each employee,
representative, agent or contractor shall be maintained in the register on the
premises for a period of three (3) years following termination or other
discontinuation of employment or contractual relationship. The operator shall
make the register of employees available immediately for inspection by police
upon request by the village or other law enforcement agencies.
   G.   Each owner or operator of an adult oriented business must report to the
village any proposed activity or activities which would substantially enlarge
the business from the size it was when it was last granted a license (see
definition of "substantial enlargement of adult oriented business" in this
chapter). A new survey may be required to determine whether the proposed
substantial enlargement of the business will violate the required separation
from sensitive uses (as required by this chapter) or will violate any other
provision of this chapter or title 10, "Zoning", of this code. (Ord. 09-1549,
9-22-2009)
3-17-8: INSPECTION:
   A.   An applicant or licensee shall permit representatives of the police
department, health department, fire department, zoning department or other
village departments or agencies to inspect the public areas of an adult
oriented business for the purpose of ensuring compliance with this chapter at
any time it is occupied or open for business.
   B.   A person who operates an adult oriented business, his/her employee,
representative, agent, contractor or assign, commits a misdemeanor if he/she
refuses to permit such lawful inspection of the premises at any time it is open
for business. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-9: EXPIRATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Each license shall expire on December 31 of each year and may be
renewed only by making application as provided in section
3-17-4 of this chapter. Application for renewal shall be made at least sixty
(60) days before the expiration date, and when made less than sixty (60) days
before the expiration date, the expiration of the license will not be affected.
   B.   When the village denies renewal of a license, the license shall expire
on December 31 of the year when it was issued and applicant shall not be issued
a new license within one year from the date of denial, unless subsequent to
denial, the village finds that the basis for denial of the renewed license has
been corrected or abated, in which case, the applicant may be granted a license
if at least ninety (90) days have elapsed since the date of denial. (Ord. 09-
1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-10: SUSPENSION:
   A.   The village shall issue a written letter of intent to suspend the adult
oriented business license of an operator or manager for a period not to exceed
thirty (30) days if the licensee has knowingly or recklessly violated any part
of this chapter, or has knowingly or recklessly allowed an employee, or person
contracted to work in the business, to violate this chapter.
   B.   The village shall issue a written letter of intent to suspend the adult
oriented business license of an employee, entertainer, or escort if the
licensee has knowingly or recklessly violated this chapter.
   C.   The village may, at its discretion, immediately suspend an adult
oriented license if there exists probable cause that criminal violations have
occurred, or if public health or safety is in jeopardy. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-
2009)
3-17-11: REVOCATION:
   A.   The village shall issue a written letter of intent to revoke the adult
oriented business license of an operator, manager, employee, entertainer, or
escort if:
      1.   The licensee has knowingly or recklessly violated this chapter or
has knowingly or recklessly allowed an employee to violate this chapter; and
      2.   The licensee's license has been suspended or revoked within the
previous twelve (12) months.
   B.   The village shall issue a written letter of intent to revoke the adult
oriented business license of an operator, manager, employee, escort, escort
agency, or entertainer if:
      1.   The licensee knowingly or recklessly gave false information in the
application for the license;
      2.   The licensee knowingly or recklessly engaged in, or knowingly or
recklessly allowed the possession, use, solicitation or sale, of controlled
substances by anyone on the premises;
      3.   The licensee knowingly or recklessly engaged in, or knowingly or
recklessly allowed, prostitution, or solicitation for prostitution, by anyone
on the premises;
      4.   The licensee knowingly or recklessly operated an adult oriented
business, or engaged in managerial or other work, including entertainment or
escort services, during a period of time when his/her license was suspended or
revoked; or
      5.   The licensee knowingly or recklessly engaged in, or knowingly or
recklessly allowed, any specified sexual activity on the licensed premises.
   C.   The village may revoke an adult oriented business license if criminal
violations are occurring, or if public health or safety is in jeopardy.
   D.   When the village revokes a license, the revocation shall continue for
two (2) years, and the licensee shall not be eligible for an adult oriented
business license for two (2) years from the date when the revocation became
effective. A new application will be required. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-12: HEARINGS AND APPEALS:
   A.   When the village issues a written notice of intent to deny, suspend or
revoke a license, the village shall immediately send such notice to the
applicant or licensee (respondent) by personal delivery or certified mail. The
notice shall be directed to the most current business address or other mailing
address the respondent has made available on file at the village. The notice
shall state the specific grounds under this chapter upon which the denial,
suspension or revocation is based and shall specify a hearing date, not less
than ten (10) nor more than twenty (20) days after the date when the notice is
issued.
   B.   The hearing officer shall be a licensed attorney. The village president
shall appoint the hearing officer to adjudicate the merits of a particular
denial, suspension or revocation. Village officers, village employees, the
village attorney, and all members of the village attorney's firm, are
disqualified from serving as the hearing officer.
   C.   At the hearing, respondent shall have an opportunity to present
arguments, present evidence, call witnesses on his/her behalf, and to cross
examine the village's witnesses. Respondent may hire legal representation to
represent respondent at the hearing. The village shall be represented by legal
counsel. The village bears the burden of proving the grounds for the denial,
suspension or revocation of the license. The hearing shall take no longer than
two (2) days, unless one of the parties requests, and is granted, an extension
for good cause. A transcript of the hearing shall be made. The hearing officer
shall issue a written decision, including specific findings which are the basis
for the decision, to the respondent and the village within five (5) days after
the hearing.
   D.   If a hearing officer finds in favor of denial, suspension or revocation
of a license, respondent shall be advised of the right to appeal the hearing
officer's decision to a court of competent jurisdiction. If the hearing officer
finds that no grounds exist for denial, suspension or revocation of the
license, then the hearing officer shall, contemporaneously with the issuance of
the decision, order the village to immediately withdraw its intent to deny,
suspend or revoke the license, and order the village to notify the respondent
in writing by certified mail of such action. If the respondent is not yet
licensed, the village shall contemporaneously therewith issue the license to
the applicant.
   E.   If any court action is initiated to challenge a hearing officer's
decision, the hearing officer shall have a transcript of the hearing sent to
the court within ten (10) days after receiving written notice of the filing of
the court action. The hearing officer shall consent to, and may request,
expedited briefing and/or disposition of the action, shall comply with any
expedited schedule set by the court to the highest extent practicable, and
shall facilitate prompt judicial review of the proceedings. Upon receiving
notice of the filing of any court action to appeal, challenge, restrain or
otherwise enjoin enforcement of a denial of renewal, suspension, or revocation
of a preexisting license, the village shall immediately issue the respondent a
provisional license. The provisional license shall allow the respondent to
continue operation, management, employment or entertainment of or in, the adult
oriented business and will expire upon the court's entry of a judgment on the
respondent's appeal or other action which upholds or reverses the village's
licensing decision. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-13: LICENSE IS NOT TRANSFERABLE:
An adult oriented business license is not transferable to any other person or
entity. Likewise, no operator shall attempt to operate an adult oriented
business at any location other than the location at the business address as
described and designated in the application. Any attempt to transfer the
license, or any conveyance of ownership or management of the business
automatically revokes the license. Each new owner, operator or manager must
apply for, and qualify for, a new license. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-14: SEPARATION FROM SENSITIVE USES, COMPLIANCE WITH ZONING ORDINANCES, AND
CONTINUED PERMITTED USE:
   A.   Sensitive Uses: No adult oriented business shall be permitted, and no
person or business entity shall operate or cause to be operated, an adult
oriented business within three hundred fifty feet (350') of the property line
of any property containing any other adult oriented businesses, residences or
residentially zoned districts, religious institutions, schools, daycare or
childcare businesses, cemeteries or public parks or recreation areas, or any
other "sensitive uses" which may be defined in this chapter.
   B.   Measurement Between Properties: For the purposes of this section, the
measurement of distance between properties shall be made in a straight line,
without regard to intervening structures, objects or streets between the
subject properties. The measurement shall begin on the property line of the
property containing the proposed adult oriented business at the point where it
is nearest to the other property being measured for distance; the measurement
shall end on the property line of the property containing a sensitive use at
the point where it is nearest to the property containing the proposed adult
oriented business.
   C.   Zoning Compliance: Adult oriented businesses will only be permitted in
areas which comply with the village's zoning ordinances.
   D.   Preexisting Adult Oriented Businesses; Permitted Continuation And
Maintenance Of Business Operations: Any adult oriented business lawfully
operating prior to and on the effective date hereof ("preexisting adult
oriented business") shall be permitted to continue operation of the business as
a permitted use in the same manner as that which existed prior to the effective
date hereof, including the right to repair and maintain the existing facilities
in the same manner as would have been permitted prior to the enactment of this
chapter, provided however, that if any adult uses other than an adult
bookstore, adult video store or adult novelty store are created or added to the
business, if the business license is voluntarily terminated or voluntarily not
renewed by the licensee, if the business license is revoked or denied renewal
for failure to comply with the village of Shorewood's other ordinances
pertaining to business licenses in general, and/or if the operation is
otherwise discontinued for failure to comply with other laws or regulations of
other regulating bodies, then the use shall not continue thereafter; if there
is a change in ownership other than a transfer of ownership between a
preexisting adult oriented business and one of its parent companies,
affiliates, or subsidiaries, then the use permitted in this subsection shall be
permitted to continue if the new owner complies with the licensing provisions
of this chapter, and shall only be subject to the zoning ordinances which were
in effect prior to the effective date hereof as they may be amended from time
to time, except for zoning amendments which would prohibit the adult use as
permitted in this subsection. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-15: ADULT BOOKSTORES, ADULT NOVELTY STORES AND ADULT VIDEO STORES:
   A.   No adult bookstore, adult novelty store, or adult video store shall
admit persons under eighteen (18) years of age on the premises.
   B.   Proper measures shall be taken to ensure that sexually explicit media,
sexual advertising, and other sexual merchandise are not visible from the
public right of way, sidewalk, and/or street. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-16: ADULT ARCADES AND/OR THE EXHIBITION OF SEXUALLY EXPLICIT MEDIA OR LIVE
ENTERTAINMENT IN VIEWING ROOMS:
   A.   No business shall exhibit sexually explicit media or live entertainment
which depicts specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas on the
premises in a room of less than one hundred fifty (150) square feet of floor
space. Such rooms shall have no doors.
   B.   Any exhibition of sexually explicit media or live entertainment which
depicts specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas shall comply
with the following requirements:
      1.   The application for the adult oriented business license shall be
accompanied by a diagram of the premises which identifies the location of each
and every manager's station, the location of all overhead lighting fixtures and
any portion of the premises in which patrons will not be permitted. The
quantity and location of managers' stations must be sufficient so as to
facilitate prudent observation and monitoring of the entire store and all rooms
at all times. A manager's station may not exceed thirty two (32) square feet of
floor area. The diagram shall also designate the place at which the license
will be conspicuously posted, if granted. A professionally prepared diagram in
the nature of an engineer's or architect's blueprint shall not be required,
however, each diagram should be oriented to the north or to some designated
street or object and should be drawn to a designated scale or with marked
dimensions sufficient to show the various internal dimensions of all areas of
the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six inches (±6").
The village may waive the foregoing diagram for renewal applications if the
applicant adopts a diagram that was previously submitted and certifies that the
configuration of the premises has not been altered since it was prepared.
      2.   It is the duty of the licensee of the premises to ensure that at
least one licensed employee is on duty and situated in each manager's station
at all times that any patron is present.
      3.   The interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner
that there is an unobstructed view from a manager's station of every area of
the premises to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose, excluding
restrooms. Restrooms may not contain video, digital, or any other form of media
reproduction, or any other type of visual or audio equipment. If the premises
has two (2) or more manager's stations, then the interior of the premises shall
be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed view of each area
of the premises to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose from at
least one of the manager's stations. The view required in this subsection must
be by direct line of sight from the manager's station.
      4.   It shall be the duty of the licensee to ensure that the view
specified in subsection B3 of this section remains unobstructed by any doors,
curtains, partitions, walls, merchandise, display racks or other materials and,
at all times, to ensure that no patron is permitted access to any area of the
premises which has been designated on the application or in the diagrams
provided in connection with the application as an area in which patrons will
not be permitted.
      5.   No viewing room may be occupied by more than one person at any time.
      6.   The premises shall be equipped with overhead lighting fixtures of
sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which patrons are permitted
access at an illumination of not less than five (5) foot-candles as measured at
the floor level. It shall be the duty of the licensee to ensure that the proper
illumination is maintained at all times.
      7.   No person shall make or attempt to make an opening of any kind
between viewing booths or rooms. No licensee shall allow openings of any kind
to exist between viewing rooms or booths. The licensee shall, during each
business day, regularly inspect the walls between the viewing booths to
determine if any openings or holes exist. It shall be the responsibility of the
licensee to inspect the viewing rooms and take any steps necessary to ensure
that no such openings exist.
      8.   The licensee shall cause all floor coverings in viewing booths to be
nonporous, flat surfaces, with no rugs or carpeting. The licensee shall cause
all wall and ceiling surfaces in viewing booths to be constructed of, or
permanently covered by, nonporous, easily cleanable material. No wood, plywood,
composition board or other porous material shall be used within forty eight
inches (48") of the floor.
      9.   Live entertainment shall not occur in the same room as the viewing
room, it shall be contained in another room with a window which allows for
viewing and shall not feature or depict any specified sexual activities.
      10.   Any person with a duty prescribed in this section who knowingly or
recklessly commits a violation of this section, or knowingly or recklessly
allows an employee or contractor to commit a violation of this section, commits
a misdemeanor.
   C.   Proper measures shall be taken to ensure that sexually explicit media,
entertainment areas, sexual advertising, and other sexual merchandise is not
visible from the outside of the adult oriented business area. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-
22-2009)
3-17-17: ESCORTS AND ESCORT AGENCIES:
   A.   An escort agency shall not employ, or agree to employ, any person under
the age of eighteen (18) years.
   B.   Any person under the age of eighteen (18) commits an offense if he or
she acts as an escort, or agrees to act as an escort.
   C.   At no time shall an escort agree or offer or perform any act which
depicts or engages in any specified sexual activities. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-
2009)
3-17-18: NUDE MODEL STUDIOS:
   A.   A nude model studio shall not employ any person under the age of
eighteen (18) years old.
   B.   A nude model studio shall not have a bed, sofa or mattress in any room
on the premises, except that a sofa may be placed in a reception room open to
the public.
   C.   Proper measures shall be taken to ensure that no nudity, including nude
models and possible nudity on advertising, is visible from the outside. (Ord.
09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-19: PUBLIC NUDITY, ADULT ENTERTAINERS AND ADULT CABARETS:
   A.   It shall be a misdemeanor for a person to knowingly or intentionally
appear in a state of nudity in an adult oriented business.
   B.   It shall be a misdemeanor for a person to knowingly or intentionally
appear in a seminude condition in an adult oriented business unless the person
is an adult entertainer licensed by the village of Shorewood.
   C.   Any adult entertainer shall be at least ten feet (10') from any patron
or customer and shall be on a stage which is at least four feet (4') above the
floor at any and all times while seminude.
   D.   Providing adult entertainment or any other services in an adult cabaret
in a private room is prohibited.
   E.   In addition to subsection C of this section, there shall be no live
entertainment or sexually explicit media on the premises of an adult cabaret or
other adult oriented business in a room of less than one hundred fifty (150)
square feet of floor space.
   F.   The adult oriented business license issued by the village shall be
clearly displayed in the adult oriented business for each adult entertainer who
is presently working there.
   G.   It shall be a misdemeanor for any adult entertainer, who, while
seminude in an adult oriented business, solicits any amount of pay or gratuity
in any form from any patron or customer, or for any patron or customer to pay
or give any gratuity to any employee or entertainer, while said employee or
entertainer is seminude in an adult oriented business.
   H.   It shall be a misdemeanor for an adult entertainer, or any other
employee or contractor who regularly appears seminude in one or more adult
oriented business, to knowingly or intentionally touch a customer, even if
through the clothing of a customer, while seminude and/or otherwise working on
the premises of an adult oriented business.
   I.   Proper measures shall be taken to ensure that adult entertainers,
sexually explicit media, or sexual advertising is not visible from outside of
the adult oriented business area. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-20: ADULT MOTELS PROHIBITED:
   A.   Evidence that a sleeping room in a hotel, motel or a similar commercial
establishment has been rented and vacated two (2) or more times in less than
ten (10) hours creates a rebuttable presumption that the establishment is an
adult motel.
   B.   A person commits a misdemeanor if he or she is the owner, operator,
manager, or otherwise in control of a sleeping room in a hotel, motel or
similar commercial establishment, and he or she rents or subrents a sleeping
room to a person and, within ten (10) hours from the time the room is rented,
he or she rents or subrents the same sleeping room again, and/or if he or she
knowingly or recklessly allows an employee or contractor under his or her
supervision to rent or subrent a sleeping room more than once within ten (10)
hours.
   C.   As used in this section, the terms "rent" or "subrent" mean the act of
permitting a room to be occupied for any form of consideration. (Ord. 09-1549,
9-22-2009)
3-17-21: ADULT MASSAGE PROHIBITED:
A person commits a misdemeanor if he or she engages in adult massage, or is the
owner, operator, manager of an establishment in which adult massage is found to
have occurred and allowed it to occur either knowingly or recklessly. (Ord. 09-
1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-22: SEXUAL ENCOUNTER CENTERS PROHIBITED:
A person commits a misdemeanor if he or she engages in a public performance or
display of an actual or simulated sexual encounter at, or is the owner,
operator, manager of, a sexual encounter center. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-23: CHILDREN PRESENT ON PREMISES PROHIBITED:
A person who knowingly or recklessly allows a person under the age of eighteen
(18) years on the premises of an adult oriented business commits a misdemeanor.
(Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-24: HOURS OF OPERATION:
No adult oriented business may remain open at any time other than as follows:
 Open No Earlier Than Close No Later Than
          Open No Earlier Than Close No Later Than
Monday    10:00 A.M.           9:00 P.M.
Tuesday   10:00 A.M.           9:00 P.M.
Wednesday 10:00 A.M.           9:00 P.M.
Thursday  10:00 A.M.           9:00 P.M.
Friday    10:00 A.M.           10:00 P.M.
Saturday  10:00 A.M.           11:00 P.M.
Sunday    1:00 P.M.            5:00 P.M.
 
(Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-25: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES PROHIBITED:
The sale, use or consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises of an adult
oriented business is prohibited. A person who knowingly or intentionally sells,
uses, or consumes an alcoholic beverage on the premises of an adult oriented
business commits a misdemeanor. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-26: EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   It is a defense to prosecution under section
3-17-18 of this chapter that a person appearing in a state of nudity did so in
a modeling class operated:
      1.   By a proprietary school, licensed by the state of Illinois, or a
college, community college or university supported entirely or partly by
taxation;
      2.   By a private college or university which maintains and operates
educational programs in which credits are transferable to a college, community
college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation, a corporation
that qualifies as a tax exempt organization under section 501(c)(3) of the
internal revenue code; or
      3.   In a structure:
         a.   Which has no sign visible from the exterior of the structure and
no other advertising that indicates a nude person is available for viewing; and
         b.   Where, in order to participate in a class, a student must enroll
at least three (3) days in advance of the class; and
         c.   Where no more than one nude model is on the premises at any one
time. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-27: INJUNCTION AND PENALTIES:
   A.   A person who operates, or causes to be operated, an adult oriented
business without a valid license or in violation of the zoning ordinances of
the village of Shorewood is subject to license suspension, license revocation,
or a suit for injunction as well as prosecution for criminal violations. Such
violations shall be punishable by a fine that is neither less than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) nor more than that allowed by state law. Each day an adult
oriented business operates in violation of these ordinances or other laws shall
constitute a separate offense or violation. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
3-17-28: SCIENTER NECESSARY TO PROVE LIABILITY:
This chapter does not impose strict liability. For the purposes of this
chapter, an act by an employee that constitutes grounds for suspension or
revocation of that employee's license shall be imputed to the adult oriented
business licensee for purposes of finding a violation of this chapter, or for
purposes of license denial, suspension or revocation, only if an officer,
director or general partner, or a person who managed, supervised or controlled
the operation of the business premises, knowingly or recklessly allowed such
act to occur on the premises. It shall be a defense to liability that the
licensee, officer, director or general partner, or the person who managed,
supervised or controlled the operation of the business premises to whom
liability is imputed was powerless to prevent the act. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-
2009)
3-17-29: FAILURE OF VILLAGE TO MEET DEADLINE:
In the event that a village official is required to take any action or perform
any duty pursuant to this chapter within a prescribed time, and fails to take
such action or perform such duty within the time prescribed, said failure shall
not prevent the exercise of constitutional rights of an applicant or licensee.
If the act required of the village official under this chapter, and not
completed in the time prescribed, includes approval of condition(s) necessary
for approval by the village of an applicant's or licensee's application for an
adult oriented business license or an adult oriented business employee license
(including a renewal), the license shall be deemed granted and the business or
employee allowed to commence operations or employment the day after the
deadline for the village's action has passed. (Ord. 09-1549, 9-22-2009)
CHAPTER 18
VIDEO GAMING
SECTION:
3-18-1: License Required
3-18-2: License Application Fees
3-18-3: Application
3-18-4: Issuance
3-18-5: Posting
3-18-6: Revocation, Suspension And Fines
3-18-7: Transfer Prohibited
3-18-8: Restrictions On Operation
3-18-9: Number Of Video Gaming Licenses
3-18-10: Licenses Prohibited
3-18-11: Licenses Per Establishment
3-18-12: Penalty
3-18-13: Sign
3-18-14: Prior Licenses
3-18-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, either as owner, lessee, manager, officer or agent, or in any other
capacity, shall operate or permit to be operated any video gaming terminal as
defined by Title 3, Chapter 4A, Section 13-(A), at any premises within the
Village of Shorewood without first having obtained a license valid in that
calendar year. The license provided for in this chapter shall permit a licensee
to operate video gaming terminals in conformance with the Video Gaming Act
except as provided in this chapter. No license shall be issued for any premises
unless the applicant holds a valid Class A, A-1, or B-3 retail liquor license
for the premises. (Ord. 18-1872, 2-13-2018; amd. Ord. 19-1956, 11-26-2019; Ord.
2021-25, 10-12-2021)
3-18-2: LICENSE APPLICATION FEES:
The applicant for a license or a license renewal under this chapter shall pay
the Village Clerk, prior to filing the application, a nonrefundable fee of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) per video gaming terminal requested. (Ord. 18-1872,
2-13-2018)
3-18-3: APPLICATION:
An application for a license required by this chapter shall be made in writing
to the Village Clerk and shall set forth the following:
   A.   The name of the individual, partnership, corporation, association or
other entity applying for the license;
   B.   The residence, phone number and driver's license number of the
applicant or of each partner; or, if a corporation, association or other
entity, the residence, phone number and driver's license number of each
principal officer;
   C.   The location for which the license is requested;
   D.   A true and accurate photocopy of the State of Illinois license granted
to the applicant under the Video Gaming Act for the applicable premises; and
   E.   Whether the applicant, his or her partners or the principal officers of
the corporation, association or other entity have been convicted of a criminal
offense or ordinance violation (other than traffic or parking offenses) in any
jurisdiction and, if so, a list of such convictions with date and prosecuting
jurisdiction.
   F.   A floor plan depicting the interior of the premises, where terminals
will be located and further demonstrate how the licensee will demonstrate
compliance with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 18-1872, 2-13-2018)
3-18-4: ISSUANCE:
The Village President shall approve the license requested specifically for the
"licensed premises" under this chapter unless they shall find:
   A.   That the applicant is under the age of twenty one (21).
   B.   That the applicant or any principal officer therein has held a license
under this chapter or had an interest therein that was revoked for cause.
   C.   That the applicant or any principal officer therein has furnished false
or misleading information on the application.
   D.   That the applicant or any principal officer has ever been convicted of
a felony unless there is evidence presented to demonstrate that the person has
been rehabilitated.
   E.   That the applicant does not possess a valid Class A, A-1, or B-3 liquor
license for the premises where the license is required.
   F.   That the licensee or the proposed location does not meet the
qualifications of this chapter. (Ord. 18-1872, 2-13-2018; amd. Ord. 19-1956,
11-26-2019)
3-18-5: POSTING:
Every license issued under this chapter shall, at all times during the period
for which it is effective, be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the
principal entrance to the premises for which the license is issued. (Ord. 18-
1872, 2-13-2018)
3-18-6: REVOCATION, SUSPENSION AND FINES:
   A.   Any license issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked or suspended
for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days and/or the licensee be subjected to
a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per offense by the
Village President or his or her designee if the Village President or his or her
designee determines by a preponderance of the evidence:
      1.   That the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this
chapter, the laws of the State, or ordinances of the Village at or involving
the licensed premises.
      2.   That the licensee has knowingly furnished false or misleading
information or withheld relevant information on any application for a license
required by this chapter or any investigation into any such application.
      3.   That the licensee or the licensed premises no longer meet the
requirements of this chapter or the Video Gaming Act.
      4.   Any violation of Title 3, Chapter 4A of the Village Code of
Ordinances.
   B.   The licensee shall be responsible for the acts of his agents, servants
and employees in the operation of any licensed premises.
   C.   A license may be temporarily suspended in the event that circumstances
warrant immediate action. If the licensee desires a hearing on the emergency
suspension, a request must be made within forty eight (48) hours of receipt of
notice of suspension or fine.
   D.   Except as provided in subsection C of this section, prior to fining,
suspending a license or revoking a license, a hearing concerning the question
of whether a license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be revoked or
suspended, or a fine implemented, the Village President or his or her designees
shall give at least ten (10) days' written notice to the licensee setting forth
the alleged violations specifically. The licensee shall be given a reasonable
chance to present evidence at such hearing and cross examine witnesses. (Ord.
18-1872, 2-13-2018; amd. Ord. 21-2025, 10-12-2021)
3-18-7: TRANSFER PROHIBITED:
A license issued pursuant to this chapter may not be transferred, sold or
assigned to any other person, corporation, association or entity; nor shall
such license be transferred to any location other than that listed on the
application. (Ord. 18-1872, 2-13-2018)
3-18-8: RESTRICTIONS ON OPERATION:
   A.   Every licensee shall strictly comply with all of the conditions, rules
and regulations imposed by the State, and by the Village, and specifically
shall comply with the following:
      1.   Each and every video gaming terminal shall be licensed by the State
before placement or operation, and the license for each and every terminal
shall be maintained within the licensed premises where the video gaming
terminal is operated.
      2.   No video gaming terminal may be played except during the legal hours
of operation allowed for the consumption of alcoholic beverages at the licensed
premises.
      3.   No licensee shall cause or permit any person under the age of twenty
one (21) years to use or play a video gaming terminal.
      4.   Video gaming terminals located within any licensed premises must be
within an area of the establishment that is restricted to persons twenty one
(21) years of age and over, separated from other areas by a barrier of at least
thirty six inches (36") in height, the entrance to which restricted area is
within the view at all times of at least one employee of said establishment,
which employee must likewise be twenty one (21) years of age or over. The
physical barrier may consist of a partition, gate, rope, railing or other means
of separation. (Ord. 18-1872, 2-13-2018)
3-18-9: NUMBER OF VIDEO GAMING LICENSES:
Until further determination of the President and Board of Trustees only those
businesses which currently hold an eligible liquor license as set forth in
section
3-18-1 of this chapter within the Village are eligible to obtain a license for
video gaming. (Ord. 18-1872, 2-13-2018)
3-18-10: LICENSES PROHIBITED:
Notwithstanding anything in the Video Gaming Act, no license shall be issued
under this chapter for any premises which does not have a Village liquor
license classification as set forth above. Licenses are specifically prohibited
at "licensed truck stops" as defined by the Video Gaming Act. It is the
specific intent of this chapter that licenses not be issued for businesses
commonly known as gas stations, truck fueling centers, truck stops or at any
other location which does not have a Class A, A-1, or B-3 Village liquor
license which permits and where alcoholic liquor is actually drawn, poured,
mixed or otherwise lawfully served for consumption on the licensed premises.
(Ord. 18-1872, 2-13-2018; amd. Ord. 19-1956, 11-26-2019)
3-18-11: LICENSES PER ESTABLISHMENT:
A licensed establishment may operate up to six (6) video gaming terminals on
its licensed premises at any time. An annual fee of five hundred dollars
($500.00) per terminal shall be paid prior to issuance or renewal of a license.
The amount of the annual fee shall be determined using a prorated basis
determined by the month of issuance. (Ord. 18-1922, 12-11-2018; amd. Ord. 19-
1956, 11-26-2019)
3-18-12: PENALTY:
Any person found liable/guilty by a preponderance of the evidence of a
violation of any section of this chapter in judicial hearing shall be subject
to a fine of not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) nor more than
the amount permitted by law for each violation. Each day upon which a violation
occurs shall be considered a separate violation. (Ord. 18-1872, 2-13-2018)
3-18-13: SIGN:
Lighted or illuminated signs advertising video gaming are not permitted when
they are visible from outside the licensed premises. (Ord. 18-1872, 2-13-2018)
3-18-14: PRIOR LICENSES:
It is recognized that Video Gaming Licenses were previously issued pursuant to
this Chapter for holders of a Class B, B1 and B2 Liquor Licenses. Those
existing Video Gaming Licenses may be renewed by the original licensees
provided that all requirements of the Code are met except for the
classification of License. At such time that these Licenses expire, are not
renewed, or are otherwise terminated, this Section 3-18-14 shall automatically
be repealed. (Ord. 19-1956 11-26-2019)
CHAPTER 19
RAFFLES
SECTION:
3-19-1: Definitions
3-19-2: License Required
3-19-3: Application
3-19-4: Investigation
3-19-5: Issuance Or Denial Of License
3-19-6: Eligibility And Restrictions
3-19-7: Limitations
3-19-8: Raffles Manager - Bond
3-19-9: Conduct Of Raffles
3-19-10: Records
3-19-11: Licenses Not Assignable; Unlawful Use
3-19-12: Suspension Or Revocation
3-19-13: Limited Application
3-19-14: Non-Liability Of Village
3-19-15: Persons Under Eighteen
3-19-16: Geographic Limits
3-19-17: License Fee
3-19-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the terms defined in this section have the
meanings given them:
   CHARITABLE: An organization or institution organized and operated to benefit
an indefinite number of the public. The service rendered to those eligible for
benefits must also confer some benefit on the public.
   EDUCATIONAL: An organization or institution organized and operated to
provide systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by methods common
to schools and institutions of learning which compare favorably in their scope
and intensity with the course of study presented in tax-supported schools.
   FRATERNAL: An organization of persons having a common interest, the primary
interest of which is to both promote the welfare of its members and to provide
assistance to the general public in such a way as to lessen the burdens of
government by caring for those that otherwise would be cared for by the
government.
   LABOR: An organization composed of workers organized with the objective of
betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such pursuit and the
development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective occupations.
   NET PROCEEDS: The gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less
reasonable sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable
operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
   NON-PROFIT: An organization or institution organized and conducted on a not-
for-profit basis, with no personal profit inuring to anyone as a result of the
operation.
   RAFFLE: A form of lottery conducted by an organization licensed under this
chapter in which:
   A.   The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance,
represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by
some other medium, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning
chance;
   B.   The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some
other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part
of persons conducting or connected with the lottery, except that the winning
chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting
contest.
   RELIGIOUS: Any church, congregation, society, or organization founded for
the purpose of religious worship.
   VETERANS: An organization or association comprised of members of which
substantially all are individuals who are veterans or spouses, widows, or
widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of
its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to
confer a public benefit. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Except for law enforcement agencies and Statewide associations that represent
law enforcement officials which have a valid license from another jurisdiction,
no person, firm, entity, partnership, limited liability company, corporation or
other entity shall conduct raffles or chances within the Village of Shorewood
without having first obtained a license therefor pursuant to this section. Such
license must specify the area or areas within the Village in which raffle
chances will be sold or issued, the time period during which raffle chances
will be sold or issued, the time of determination of winning chances, and the
location or locations at which winning chances will be determined. Such license
shall be good for only one raffle or for a specified number of raffles to be
conducted during a specified period not exceeding one year. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-
10-2017)
3-19-3: APPLICATION:
   A.   Application for raffle licenses shall be made to the Director of
Finance in writing on a form provided for that purpose. Application forms shall
be made available by the Director of Finance at Village Hall.
   B.   The application for a license must specify the area or areas within the
Village in which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the time period during
which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the time of determination of
winning chances, and the location or locations at which winning chances will be
determined. The application shall also contain a sworn statement attesting to
the not-for-profit character of the prospective licensee organization, signed
by the presiding officer and the secretary of that organization.
   C.   The application shall contain such other information as necessary to
determine eligibility. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-4: INVESTIGATION:
   A.   Upon the receipt of an application for a license, the Director of
Finance shall refer such application to the proper officer for making
investigation within five (5) days of the time of such receipt. The officer
charged with the duty of making the investigation or inspection shall make a
report thereon, favorable or otherwise, within ten (10) days after receiving
the application or a copy thereof.
   B.   Upon receipt of all related investigative and inspection reports, the
Director of Finance shall forward such reports, together with the application,
to the Village President for final determination. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-5: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF LICENSE:
   A.   If, after due consideration of the information contained with the
application and related investigative and inspection reports, the Village
President shall determine that the application is satisfactory, the application
shall be approved. Thereupon, the Village Clerk shall notify the applicant that
his or its application is approved. The license shall be signed by the
President, attested by the Clerk, and then issued to the licensee.
   B.   If, after due consideration of the information contained within the
application and related investigative and inspection reports, the Village
President shall determine that matters concerning the application are
unsatisfactory, the application shall be disapproved, indicating the reasons
therefor. Thereupon, the Village Clerk shall notify the applicant that his or
its application has not been approved and that no license will be issued. The
applicant may appeal the decision of the Village President, within ten (10)
days of receipt thereof, by submitting a petition for appeal, in writing, to
the Board of Trustees. The Board of Trustees may, by vote of a majority of the
Trustees, reverse the decision of the Village President.
   C.   The Village President shall act on a license application within thirty
(30) days from the date of application. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-6: ELIGIBILITY AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Licenses shall be issued only to bona fide religious, charitable,
labor, fraternal, educational or veterans' organizations that operate without
profit to their members and which have been in existence continuously for a
period of five (5) years immediately before making application for a license
and which have had during that entire five-year period a bona fide membership
engaged in carrying out their objectives or to a non- profit fundraising
organization that is organized for the sole purpose of providing financial
assistance to an identified individual or group of individuals suffering
extreme financial hardship as the result of an illness, disability, accident or
disaster.
   B.   A license may not be issued under this chapter to:
      1.   Any person who has been convicted of a felony;
      2.   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling
promoter;
      3.   Any person who is not of good moral character;
      4.   Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection B1,
B2 or B3 of this section has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest, or in
which such a person is active or employed;
      5.   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection B1, B2 or
B3 of this section is an officer, director, or employee, whether compensated or
not;
      6.   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection B1, B2 or
B3 of this section is to participate in the management or operation of a raffle
as defined in this chapter. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-7: LIMITATIONS:
   A.   The maximum aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise awarded
by a license in a single raffle shall be one hundred fifty thousand dollars
($150,000.00) unless the applicant follows the procedure as established in
subsection E of this section.
   B.   The maximum retail value of each prize awarded by a licensee in a
single raffle shall be one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) unless
the applicant follows the procedure as established in subsection E of this
section.
   C.   The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance issued or
sold shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
   D.   The maximum number of days during which chances may be issued or sold
for any raffle shall be three hundred sixty four (364) days.
   E.   Any applicant requesting a license for a raffle in which the maximum
aggregate retail value of all prizes or the maximum retail value of each
individual prize will exceed one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00)
must receive prior approval of the Village Board of Trustees. The application
for a raffle in which prizes exceed the value of one hundred fifty thousand
dollars ($150,000.00) shall be made and investigated as outlined in this
chapter. Following the investigation the Village President shall cause the
application to be placed on the meeting agenda for action by the Board of
Trustees prior to the issuance of said license. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-8: RAFFLES MANAGER - BOND:
   A.   All operation of and conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision
of a single raffles manager designated by the organization. The manager shall
give a fidelity bond in the sum of the aggregate retail value of all prizes or
merchandise to be awarded by the licensee in the raffle, conditioned upon his
honesty in the performance of his duties. Such bond shall be given before the
issuance of a license under this chapter, shall be in the name of the licensee,
and shall be in a form and with a surety acceptable to the Village.
   B.   Terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing
to the Village not less than thirty (30) days prior to its cancellation.
   C.   The Mayor shall be authorized to waive the bond requirement and to
include a waiver provision in the license issued to an organization under this
chapter, provided that: 1) all the requirements of this chapter have been met
by the applicant; 2) the applicant has complied with the provisions of 230
Illinois Compiled Statutes 15/5 (section 5 of the Illinois Raffles Act); and 3)
the organization provides a resolution adopted by a unanimous vote of its
Governing Body requesting such a waiver. An appeal of the decision of the Mayor
with regard to waiving bond may be made to the Board of Trustees within five
(5) days of said decision. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-9: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
Raffles licensed by this chapter shall be conducted subject to the following
restrictions:
   A.   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to
the lawful purpose of the organization permitted to conduct that raffle.
   B.   No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may
participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
   C.   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in
the management of the raffle.
   D.   A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the winning chance
or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under
this chapter. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-10: RECORDS:
   A.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep
records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each raffle. All
deductions from gross receipts for each raffle shall be documented with
receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the purchased
item or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient. The
distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and
date of payment.
   B.   Gross receipts from the operation of raffle programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of the organization. Each organization shall
have separate records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross
receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be
the same person who accounts for other revenues of the organization.
   C.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report monthly to
its membership, and to the Village its gross receipts, expenses and net
proceeds from raffles, and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as
required by this section.
   D.   Records required by this section shall be preserved for three (3)
years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to
operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places.
(Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-11: LICENSES NOT ASSIGNABLE; UNLAWFUL USE:
   A.   No license may be assigned, sold, loaned, transferred, used as
collateral or otherwise encumbered.
   B.   No person, firm or corporation shall alter, deface, forge or
counterfeit any license issued by the Village. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-12: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION:
   A.   A raffle license issued under the provisions of this chapter may be
revoked or suspended by the Village President if the licensee or raffle manager
has:
      1.   Violated any of the provisions of this chapter;
      2.   Violated any ordinance of the Village or any State law of the State
of Illinois, or any Federal law of the United States, the violation of which
reflects unfavorably on the fitness of the licensee or raffle manager to
continue to conduct the licensed raffle within the Village; or
      3.   The licensing requirements are no longer met.
   B.   Prior to suspension or revocation, the licensee shall be given notice
of the proposed action to be taken and shall have an opportunity to be heard by
the President and Board of Trustees. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-13: LIMITED APPLICATION:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to authorize the conducting or
operating of any gambling scheme, enterprise, activity or device other than
raffles as provided for herein. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-14: NON-LIABILITY OF VILLAGE:
The Village of Shorewood expressly assumes no responsibility or liability
whatsoever with regard to the collection of monies, the conduct of, the results
of, or any matter relating to, any raffle conducted pursuant to this chapter.
(Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-15: PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN:
A person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the conducting
of raffles or chances only with the permission of a parent or guardian. A
person under the age of eighteen (18) years may be within the area where
winning chances are being determined only when accompanied by his parent or
guardian. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-16: GEOGRAPHIC LIMITS:
Licenses issued pursuant to this section only permit the sale of raffle tickets
within the corporate limits of the Village of Shorewood, except when the
license is issued for a law enforcement agency or a Statewide association that
represents law enforcement officials and the "key location" (as defined by the
"Act") is situated within the Village of Shorewood. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
3-19-17: LICENSE FEE:
The fee for a raffle license is ten dollars ($10.00) and shall be paid at the
time of application. (Ord. 17-1860, 10-10-2017)
CHAPTER 20
MUNICIPAL CANNABIS RETAILER’S OCCUPATION TAX
SECTION:
3-20-1: Municipal Cannabis Retailer’s Occupation Tax
3-20-1: MUNICIPAL CANNABIS RETAILER’S OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
selling cannabis at retail in the Village, other than cannabis purchased under
the Illinois Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Pilot Program Act, 410 ILCS
130/1, et seq., at the rate of three percent (3%) of the gross receipts from
such sales made in the course of that business. Retailers may reimburse
themselves for their tax liability hereunder by separately stating the tax as
an additional charge, which charge may be stated in combination, in a single
amount, with any State tax that retailers are required to collect.
   B.   The imposition of the tax imposed by this Section is in accordance with
the provisions of Section 8-11-23 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-
11-23), as amended, and is in addition to any and all other taxes and charges.
   C.   The tax imposed by this Section and all civil penalties that may be
assessed as an incident thereto, shall be remitted to, collected by and
enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue in accordance with the
provisions of Section 8-11-23 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-
23), as amended. The Illinois Department of Revenue shall have full power to
administer and enforce the provisions of this Section.
   D.   The failure to timely collect or remit all taxes due pursuant to this
Section is a violation of this Code, and may be subject to the penalties
hereunder. (Ord. 20-1967, 3-10-2020)
CHAPTER 21
MOBILE FOOD VENDING
SECTION:
3-21-1: Mobile Food Vending License Required
3-21-2: Definitions
3-21-3: Types Of Mobile Food Vending Licenses
3-21-4: Application For Mobile Food Vending License
3-21-5: Mobile Food Vendor Location
3-21-6: Restrictions On Use
3-21-7: Sanitation And Inspections
3-21-8: Investigation Of Operators
3-21-9: Insurance Required
3-21-10: License Fees And Terms
3-21-11: Granting And Issuance Of Mobile Food Vending License
3-21-12: Right To Appeal
3-21-13: Revocation Or Suspension Of License
3-21-14: Enforcement
3-21-15: Violation And Penalty
3-21-1: MOBILE FOOD VENDING LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate within the Village a Mobile Food
Vending Unit, as defined in this Chapter, without first having obtained a
license for that purpose. (Ord. 22-2040, 4-26-2022)
3-21-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply.
MOBILE FOOD VENDING UNIT: A vehicle establishment that is designed to be
readily moveable from which food is sold, cooked, or served, including
motorized vehicles, trailers, push carts, and tricycle carts. Food trucks, food
trailers, canteen trucks, ice cream trucks, ice cream trailers are examples of
mobile food vending units.
MOBILE FOOD VENDOR: A person or business that owns or operates a Mobile Food
Vending Unit. (Ord. 22-2040, 4-26-2022)
3-21-3: TYPES OF MOBILE FOOD VENDING LICENSES:
Mobile Food Vending Licenses shall be divided into the following types.
   A.   Type A Mobile Food Vending Licenses are designed to accommodate Mobile
Food Vending Businesses that participate in Special Events, such as private
parties, block parties, company picnics, and visits to local businesses.
      1.   Type A1 Licenses are valid for a calendar year.
      2.   Type A2 Licenses are valid for a single day.
   B.   Type B Mobile Food Vending Licenses are designed to accommodate Mobile
Food Vending Businesses that visit multiple locations throughout the day, such
as ice cream trucks and job site canteen trucks.
      1.   Type B1 Licenses are valid for a calendar year.
      2.   Type B2 Licenses are valid for a single day. (Ord. 22-2040, 4-26-
2022)
3-21-4: APPLICATION FOR MOBILE FOOD VENDING LICENSE:
All applications for Mobile Food Vending License, shall be made, to the Zoning
Officer on a form provided for that purpose. Each application should be made
ten (10) business days before the same is required to allow a period for proper
examination and investigation of whether the Mobile Food Vending License should
be granted. (Ord. 22-2040, 4-26-2022)
3-21-5: MOBILE FOOD VENDOR LOCATION:
   A.   A mobile vending unit and all accessory equipment must be located so
that:
      1.   It does not obstruct a public way;
      2.   It does not impair the movement of pedestrians or vehicles;
      3.   It does not pose a hazard to public safety;
      4.   It does not violate any parking regulations;
      5.   It does not cause traffic congestion;
      6.   It does not block a fire hydrant or other public safety equipment;
      7.   It does not block an intersection; and,
      8.   The weight of the unit that can be supported by the paving or street
surface.
   B.   A mobile food vendor may not operate on private property without the
written authorization of the property owner.
   C.   A mobile food vendor may not operate on property owned by the Village
of Shorewood or another government entity without the written authorization of
the Village or entity.
   D.   A mobile food vendor may not operate within 300 feet of a school
without the written authorization of the school administration or school
district.
   E.   A mobile food vendor may not operate within 300 feet of a public park
without the written authorization of the Village.
   F.   A mobile food vendor, with a Type A License, may not operate on public
or private right-of-way without the written permission of the Village. The
Village may grant such permission when mobile food vendors have been invited to
participate in a special event such as a festival or block party. They may be
required to enter into a special event agreement with the Village.
   G.   A mobile food vendor, with a Type B License, may stop briefly on public
or private right-of-way to serve patrons. Stops on right-of-way are only
permitted when conditions are safe and may not exceed a period of fifteen (15)
minutes.
   H.   Mobile food vendors shall obey any lawful order of a police officer to
move to a different location to avoid congestion or obstruction of a public way
or remove the vehicle entirely from the public way if necessary to avoid such
congestion or obstruction. (Ord. 22-2040, 4-26-2022)
3-21-6: RESTRICTIONS ON USE:
The following standards shall apply to mobile food vending units.
   A.   Mobile food vendors may operate between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 9:00
p.m. in residential zoning districts and between the hours of 6:00 am and 9:00
pm in non-residential zoning districts.
   B.   Mobile food vendors shall have all of the necessary health department
permits.
   C.   Mobile food vendors, operating under Type A Mobile Food Vending
Licenses, may sell alcohol pursuant to State and Village liquor licensing
requirements.
   D.   No alcohol may be sold from a mobile food vending unit operating under
a Type B Mobile Food Vending License.
   E.   No mobile food vending units shall be left unattended on a public way.
   F.   No mobile food vending unit shall be parked on a right-of-way or in a
private residential parking space unless it has stopped to sell food in
accordance with the regulations of this chapter. For example, overnight parking
on a street or in a residential driveway is prohibited.
   G.   No mobile food vendor, driver or operator shall drink any alcoholic
beverages, shout or call to prospective customers, or to disturb the peace in
any manner while on duty.
   H.   No mobile food vendor shall install any signs other than those which
are contained within or attached to the vehicle, except with the written
permission of the Village and the property owner.
   I.   No mobile food vendors shall install any tables, chairs, or other
equipment, except with the written permission of the Village and the property
owner.
   J.   No lighting shall be mounted to the mobile food vending unit that may
spill onto adjacent residential property as measured from the property line.
   K.   No mobile food vendor shall use utilities drawn from or across the
public right-of-way, except with the written permission of the Director of
Public Works.
   L.   No mobile food vending unit shall operate a drive-through.
   M.   Mobile food vendors shall prominently display the county health
department permits and the Village of Shorewood Mobile Food Vending License.
   N.   Mobile food vendor shall be responsible for paying all applicable
Illinois retailers taxes.
   O.   Mobile food vendors with Type A Licenses may not operate for more than
10 consecutive days on any property.
   P.   Mobile food vendors with Type A Licenses may operate for a maximum of
52 total days during any calendar year.
   Q.   Certain provisions of this chapter may be waived for mobile food
vendors operating under the terms of a special event agreement with the Village
of Shorewood. (Ord. 22-2040, 4-26-2022)
