with sound suppression devices that limit total machine noise in accordance
with noise pollution standards established pursuant to the Environmental Protec
tion Act of the State of Illinois 1 . (Ord. 90-535, 4-24-90, eff. 5-1-90)
 
Notes
1 2. S.H.A. 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
40/5-1.   OPERATION GENERALLY:
It is unlawful for any person to drive or operate any snowmobile in the
following ways:
   (a)   At a rate of speed too fast for conditions, and the fact that the
speed of the snowmobile does not exceed the applicable maximum speed limit
allowed does not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed as may be
necessary to avoid colliding with any person or vehicle or object within legal
requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care.
   (b)   In a careless, reckless or negligent manner.
   (c)   While under the influence of intoxicating beverages or narcotic or
dangerous drugs.
   (d)   At any time without at least one lighted headlamp and one lighted
taillamp on the snowmobile.
   (e)   Within five hundred (500) yards of any nature preserve.
   (f)   On the tracks or right of way of any operating railroad.
   (g)   In any tree nursery or planting in a manner which damages or destroys
growing stock or creates a substantial risk thereto.
   (h)   On private property without the written consent of the owner or lessee
thereof. Any person operating a snowmobile upon lands of another shall stop and
identify himself upon the request of the landowner or his duly authorized
representative and, if requested to do so by the landowner, shall promptly
remove the snowmobile from the premises.
   (i)   An owner, lessee or occupant of the premises owes no duty to keep the
premises safe for entry or use by others for snowmobiling or to give warning of
any unsafe condition or use of or structure or activity on such premises. This
subsection does not apply where permission to snowmobile is given for a
valuable consideration other than this State or any political subdivision or
municipality thereof.
   (j)   An owner, lessee or occupant of
premises who has given permission to another to snowmobile upon such premises
does not thereby extend any assurance that the premises are safe for such
purpose or assume responsibility for or incur liability for any injury to
person or property caused by an act of persons to whom the permission is
granted. This subsection shall not apply where permission to snowmobile is
given for a valuable consideration. (Ord. 90-535, 4-24-90, eff. 5-1-90)
40/5-2.   OPERATION ON HIGHWAYS:
It is unlawful for any person to drive or operate any snowmobile on a highway
in this Village except as follows:
   (a)   On highways other than tollways, interstate highways, and limited-
access highways, snowmobiles may make a direct crossing provided:
      (1)   The crossing is made at an angle of approximately ninety degrees
(90°) to the direction of the highway and at a place where no obstruction
prevents a quick and safe crossing; and
      (2)   The snowmobile is brought to a complete stop before crossing a
highway; and
      (3)   The operator yields the right of way to all oncoming traffic which
constitutes a hazard.
   (b)   On highways other than State highways, tollways, interstate highways
and limited-access highways, snowmobiles may be operated not less than fifteen
feet (15') from the roadway and in the same direction as traffic.
   (c)   On highways other than State highways, tollways, interstate highways
and limited-access highways, snowmobiles may be operated on roadways when it is
necessary to cross a bridge or culvert or when it is impracticable to gain
immediate access to an area adjacent to a highway where a snowmobile is to be
operated. (Ord. 90-535, 4-24-90, eff. 5-1-90)
40/5-3.   YOUTHFUL OPERATORS:
It is unlawful for any person without a valid motor vehicle driver's license to
operate a snowmobile on a highway as provided in section 40/5-3 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code, Illinois Compiled Statutes, chapter 625. No person under ten (10)
years of age may operate a snowmobile. Persons at least ten (10) and less than
twelve (12) years of age may operate a snowmobile only if they are either
accompanied on the snowmobile by a parent or guardian or a person at least
eighteen (18) years of age designated by a parent or guardian. Persons at least
twelve (12) and less than sixteen (16) years of age may operate a snowmobile
only if they are either accompanied on the snowmobile by a parent or guardian
or a person at least sixteen (16) years of age designated by a parent or
guardian, or such operator is in possession of a certificate issued by the
Department of Public Safety of the State authorizing the holder to operate
snowmobiles. Violations of this Section done with the knowledge of a parent or
guardian shall be deemed a violation by the parent or guardian and punishable
under Section
6-1-2 of this Title. It is unlawful for any person under sixteen (16) years of
age to operate a snowmobile on a public highway in this Village. (Ord. 90-535,
4-24-90, eff. 5-1-90)
40/5-6.   OTHER PROHIBITIONS:
   (a)   No person, except persons permitted by law, shall operate or ride any
snowmobile with any firearm in his possession, unless it is unloaded and
enclosed in a carrying case, or any bow, unless it is unstrung in a carrying
case.
   (b)   No person shall operate any snowmobile emitting pollutants in
accordance with standards established pursuant to the Environmental Protection
Act of the State 1 .
   (c)   No person shall deposit from a snowmobile on the snow, ice or ground
surface, trash, glass, garbage, insoluble material or other "offensive matter".
(Ord. 90-535, 4-24-90, eff. 5-1-90)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
7-1-1: Uniform Street Name And Address Numbering System
7-1-2: Culvert Construction
7-1-3: Uncovered, Unguarded Sewers, Wells And Drains; Drainage Regrading Or
Reconstruction
7-1-4: Owners And Occupants Shall Maintain Parkways
7-1-5: Penalty
7-1-1: UNIFORM STREET NAME AND ADDRESS NUMBERING SYSTEM:
   A.   Address Numbering System:
      1.   Responsibility For Address Number Assignments And Reassignment:
         a.   Whenever a building has been numbered or renumbered in accordance
with this section, such number shall not be changed or altered unless upon the
direction of the village of Shorewood or those authorized by the same to assign
addresses.
         b.   In all cases where numbers have been assigned on any street, it
shall be the duty of the village of Shorewood to adjust and reassign such
numbers as the same may be required from time to time. In all cases where there
is a mistake or conflict in numbers, the village of Shorewood shall direct and
make proper adjustment of the same. The village of Shorewood shall not be held
liable for any expenses incurred as a result of said address assignment or
adjustment.
         c.   At all times, the village of Shorewood shall keep an up to date
list of the current address for each parcel and property assigned an address
pursuant to this section and located in the village.
         d.   It will be the responsibility of the individual property owner,
renter, lessee or other person(s) having possession or control of the property
to notify all appropriate agencies (post office, fire protection district,
telephone company, electric company, etc.) of the most current assigned address
issued by the village of Shorewood.
      2.   General Information: The village of Shorewood uniform street name
and address numbering system is divided into two (2) separate address areas.
The village address system boundary is shown on exhibit A, attached to
ordinance 03-1179, that incorporates the existing village of Shorewood
surrounded by the five digit address system.
         a.   Village Address System:
            (1)   The numbering system that is currently in use for the village
address system will remain. Given the unique nature of the addressing system in
place, the parcels not addressed within the village address system will be
determined by following the current trends for numbering in that area.
            (2)   Numbers will be assigned sequentially from determined
starting points with even numbers being on the north and east sides and odds
being on the south and west sides.
            (3)   The numbering of the village address system begins at the
intersection of Route 52 and Route 59. The east and west numbering will
increase from Route 59 as being 0 and the north and south numbering will
increase from Route 52 as being 0.
         b.   Five Digit Address System:
            (1)   The numbering for the five digit address system shall begin
at State Street and Madison Street in the city of Chicago and extend outwardly.
The number system shall increase southerly, and westerly beginning with the
corporate limits of the village of Shorewood, as it may change from time to
time with annexations.
            (2)   In cases where an address shall be changed, property owners
shall receive official notification of the new address assignment in advance of
the change. These notices shall state the old and new addresses, effective date
of the change, and penalty for not displaying the new address number.
Notifications of number changes are usually sent thirty (30) days before the
effective date of the change.
            (3)   North and west sides of the street shall have even numbers.
South and east sides of the street shall have odd numbers.
            (4)   The system defines eight (8) blocks equal to one mile. Each
block is approximately six hundred sixty feet (660') long. In addressing there
are sixty six (66) possible numbers per block. They consist of thirty three
(33) odd numbers and thirty three (33) even numbers, being evenly spaced out
every twenty feet (20'). This is the method to be used to assign addresses for
the five digit address system.
            (5)   Every section in each township has a north/south and east/
west corresponding boundary. In each section, there are eight (8) blocks. The
numbers shall increase from north to south and east to west. (See exhibit A,
attached to ordinance 03-1179.)
            (6)   Street directions are designated as either S. for north/south
streets, or W. for east/west streets.
            (7)   Developers shall choose street layouts from the following
designs:
               (A) Crescent (Loop) Streets: A crescent is designed so that a
street has an entrance and exit at two (2) points on the same intersecting
street. Crescents are numbered consecutively from their beginning intersection
(either the north or east intersection) if they have one street name. Even
though crescent street configurations are north/south and east/west, the
numbers are dependent on the direction of the intersecting street if one street
name has been chosen. In addressing a crescent, addresses shall not be
alternated so that odd and even numbers are located on the same side of the
street. Addresses shall be assigned along the crescent continuously in the same
direction as the intersecting street. It shall depend on the length of the
street if more than one street name will be required. This will be left up to
the discretion of the village of Shorewood. Refer to the illustration attached
as exhibit B to ordinance 03-1179.
               (B) Cul-De-Sac Streets: A cul-de-sac is designed so that the
street does not follow through. There is only one common entrance and exit with
a turnaround at the end of the street. Cul-de-sacs shall be addressed in the
same manner as north/south and east/west streets with even numbers located on
the north and west sides of the street and the odd numbers on the south and
east sides of the street. Because of the shape of a cul-de-sac, the center lot
at the end (circular part of the street) of the cul-de-sac shall be the
dividing point for determining whether a lot will receive an even or odd
number. Refer to the illustration attached as exhibit C to ordinance 03-1179.
               (C) North/South - East/West Streets: A north/south or east/west
street is designed to provide vehicular access to abutting property in a grid
system. East/west streets can intersect north/south streets. The north and west
sides of the street shall be even numbers. The south and east sides of the
street shall be assigned odd numbers. Refer to the illustration attached as
exhibit D to ordinance 03-1179.
               (D) Trending Street: A trending street is designed to bend back
and forth with few straight areas. The street will be considered as trending in
the direction in which it covers the greatest distance being north/south or
east/west. Trending streets shall be addressed in the same manner as the north/
south or east/west streets. Refer to the illustration attached as exhibit E to
ordinance 03-1179.
               (E) Diagonal Street: A diagonal street is designed to extend as
a line on an angle. The street shall be addressed in the direction in which it
covers the greatest distance being north/south or east/west. Refer to the
illustration attached as exhibit F to ordinance 03-1179.
            (8)   If one structure has several units designed for individual
occupancy and each unit is accessed from outside of the structure, then each
unit shall have its own address. If individual units are accessed solely from
within the structure, then the structure shall have an address and each unit
within shall use the same address and have an individual sequential unit letter
or number. For structures having several main entrances, each leading to
separate groups of units, each main entrance shall have its own address and
units accessed from within that entrance shall use that address and have an
individual sequential unit letter or number. An exception to this subsection is
a motel/hotel where one address shall be assigned to each building and each
room for rent shall use the same address and have an individual sequential unit
letter or number.
            (9)   For private drives and interior parking bays and group
housing/commercial developments, generally numbers shall be assigned to all
dwelling units or structures facing a parking bay, private drive, or interior
courts, as if they were facing upon the main street to which the driveway
connects. The numbers shall remain in numerical sequence.
            (10)   On a corner lot, the address assigned shall be assigned
according to the direction that the principal building faces. The address
should correspond with the location of the primary entrance door. In some cases
the address shall be assigned by the location of the driveway due to site
design circumstances.
            (11)   When practicable, the continuation of an existing street
shall have the same name as the existing street.
            (12)   When a street makes a ninety degree (90°) turn at any point
and it is determined by the village of Shorewood that it is necessary to avoid
confusion in the delivery of emergency services, a change in street name shall
occur to eliminate confusion.
            (13)   The name of the new street shall not duplicate or mimic the
name of existing streets within the area served by the same post office, fire
department, or other emergency service organizations.
            (14)   In areas where there are numerous structures on a private
road and there are not enough numbers available in the appropriate range, the
village of Shorewood has the authority to increase the number range in that
particular area.
      3.   Procedure For Receiving Village Address:
         a.   Individual Address Assignment:
            (1)   The request shall be made to the village of Shorewood.
Addresses will be provided only with property identification numbers (PINs), or
in cases where it is not possible to obtain a PIN, a legal description and/or
plat of survey or annexation, or subdivision lot number shall be required.
            (2)   Once the request is made, the parcel shall be located on a
map, air photograph, subdivision plat, or other media suitable to determine the
correct address. Surrounding addresses will need to be reviewed to address
parcels based within the village address system.
            (3)   Once the address is assigned, the owners of the property and
the new address shall be listed in the official records of the village of
Shorewood. Said assigned address shall be the official address of the property
on the effective date shown on the notice pursuant to the requirements of this
section.
            (4)   For new structures, addresses shall be given out when a
building permit has been applied for and received if an address has not
previously been assigned to the parcel by the village of Shorewood. If the
parcel has an existing address assigned pursuant to the Will County street
numbering system, that number will be compared to the village system and the
village shall determine if the existing number conforms reasonably to the
village system, in which event, the existing number for the parcel shall be
used for the new structure. No certificate of occupancy will be issued until
the number has been assigned or accepted by the village of Shorewood, and is
permanently attached to the structure in the manner required by this section.
         b.   Residential Subdivision Address Assignments:
            (1)   Prior to final plat approval, two (2) copies of the proposed
plat of subdivision must be submitted to the village of Shorewood at a scale of
one inch equals one hundred feet (1" = 100') with each lot clearly identified.
The plat must include the legal description of the entire subdivision. These
copies of the plat are in addition to any other copies of the plat required by
the village as part of the review of an application for approval of a final
plat.
            (2)   Once the addresses are assigned, the developer will receive a
printout with the lot number with the corresponding address and one plat.
            (3)   Prior to final plat approval, the developer shall submit to
the village of Shorewood one address plat with the official addresses located
on it at a scale of one inch equals one hundred feet (1" = 100') and two (2)
reduced, reproducible copies of the plat for convenient dispersal to other
agencies. Developers shall distribute the addresses as lots are sold. The
developer shall provide the police, fire and ambulance services servicing the
subdivision and 9-1-1 with a copy of the address plat. The emergency services
entities will have two (2) weeks from the date of receipt of the address plat
to respond, in writing, to the village of Shorewood and the developer with any
objection(s) to the street names or addresses assigned.
            (4)   The village of Shorewood shall be furnished, by the
developer, with a copy of the subdivision plat with the addresses located on
the parcels, at the scale of one inch equals one hundred feet (1" = 100') and
one reduced, reproducible copy no larger than eleven inches by seventeen inches
(11" x 17").
            (5)   If changes in the plat of subdivision are made after the
addresses have been assigned the developer shall be required to repeat the
steps in subsections A3b(1), A3b(3), A3b(4) of this section.
      4.   Notification Of Number Change And Enforcement:
         a.   In all cases, property owners, tax assessees of record or person
(s) having use or control of the property shall receive official notification
of the change in address in advance of the change. These notices shall state
the old and new addresses, effective date of the change, and penalty for not
displaying the new number.
         b.   All property owners, tax assessees of record or person(s) having
use or control of the property shall display the address number assigned to the
property by the village of Shorewood within thirty (30) days of the effective
date of said address assignment in the manner provided in this section.
      5.   Display Of Address Numbers:
         a.   Principal Buildings Shall Be Numbered: All principal buildings in
the village of Shorewood shall be numbered with the address number assigned by
the village of Shorewood. It is the duty of the owner, agent, tax assessee or
person in possession or control of every principal building in the village to
display this number prescribed in this section.
         b.   Numbers:
            (1)   The numbers shall be displayed so as to be easily located and
read from the nearest common roadway by emergency personnel (numbers shall not
be placed on doors, gates or other movable objects),
            (2)   For multiple-building facilities which have a common mailing
address, the number should be on the street side of the building nearest the
street or roadway, or
            (3)   For buildings too distant from the street to permit easy
legibility from the street, or for buildings not clearly visible from the
street for whatever cause, numbers shall be affixed to any reasonable,
permanent, freestanding object, readily legible from the street and so located
as to clearly identify the applicable building. Numbers shall not be placed on
doors, gates or other movable objects.
         c.   Number Specifications: Such numbers shall be in Arabic numerals
no less than six inches (6") high and one-half inch (1/2") stroke. Colors
should be of a contrasting color with the surface on which they are mounted.
Industrial and warehouse buildings shall have numerals no less than six inches
(6") high.
         d.   Removal Or Defacement Of Building Numbers Prohibited: No person
shall remove or deface any building number placed upon any building in
accordance with the provisions of this section.
         e.   Display Of Numbers Other Than Address Numbers Prohibited: No
person shall retain any number on his building other than the number provided
by the provisions of this section.
         f.   Conformity Required: No owner, agent, tax assessee, or person in
possession or control of any building shall refuse or neglect to have numbered
such building or permit the same to be numbered not in conformity with this
section.
   B.   Street Signs:
      1.   Design Of Street Signs:
         a.   All street signs located in the village of Shorewood shall:
            (1)   Be erected at all street intersections regardless of other
route marking that may be present.
            (2)   Be lettered with lettering at least four inches (4") high.
Supplementary lettering to indicate the type of street (e.g., street, avenue,
road, etc.) or section of the village (e.g., N., W.) may be in smaller
lettering, but must be at least two inches (2") high. Abbreviations shall not
be used for the street name itself.
            (3)   Have a reflective surface or be illuminated.
            (4)   Have a legend and background of contrasting colors and shall
have a green message (including village name and logo) and border on a white
background.
            (5)   Be placed at least on diagonally opposite corners so that
they will be on the far right hand side of the intersection for traffic on the
major street in business districts and on principal arterials. Signs naming
both streets shall be erected at each location. They shall be mounted on their
faces parallel to the streets they name.
            (6)   Be mounted at each intersection in residential districts.
         b.   On intersection related approaches, a supplemental street name
sign may be erected separately or below an intersection warning sign. When
combined with a yellow diamond sign, the color should be a black message on a
yellow background.
         c.   Street signs for designating street names shall be of the formats
as specified in this section or as near to that format as practicable. The sign
shall tell the common street name and the address boundary for that
intersection.
   C.   Street Names:
      1.   Street Names:
         a.   The continuation of an existing street shall have the same name
as the existing street.
         b.   When a street makes a ninety degree (90°) turn at any point and
it is determined by the village of Shorewood that it is necessary to avoid
confusion in the delivery of emergency services, a change in street name shall
occur to eliminate confusion.
         c.   The name of the new street cannot duplicate, mimic, or resemble
the name of existing streets within the area served by the same post office,
fire department, or other emergency service organizations.
         d.   Unacceptable names: Numerical names (1st, 2nd, etc.);
alphabetical letters (A, B, C, etc.); frivolous, complicated, or undesirable
names; unconventional spellings; compound names. A numerical name, however, can
be used if the street name number is consistent with the adopted address grid
system.
         e.   Names shall not include "east", "west", "north", and "south", as
part of the name, except as they are used in the directional title of the
street by the village of Shorewood.
         f.   The following will be the standard abbreviations for signs:
            Drive -    DR
            Road - RD
            Circle - CIR
            Court - CT
            Street - ST
            Lane -    LN
            Place - PL
            Square - SQ
            Terrace - TERR
            Parkway - PKWY
            Avenue - AVE
            Boulevard - BLVD
            Way -    WAY
            Junction - JCT
            Loop -    LOOP
      2.   Subdivisions:
         a.   It is the responsibility of the developer to propose street names
to the village of Shorewood. The village will in turn verify all street names
to eliminate duplicate or similar names in emergency service areas.
         b.   The developer of all new subdivisions shall furnish the initial
road sign and signpost and ensure the installation of the road signs to
standard specifications. All signs shall be installed prior to the construction
of buildings and shall be maintained by the developer at all times until the
dedication of the streets is accepted by the village of Shorewood.
   D.   Address Map: A map, entitled "The Village Of Shorewood Official Address
Base Map", is attached to ordinance 03-1179 as exhibit A, and made part of this
section. This map shall delineate the address base grid, and indicate all areas
of the village subject to the provisions of this section. In the event that a
parcel or parcels of land become annexed to the village, this section and map
shall be used to assign addresses and to name streets within the area annexed.
   E.   Implementation: The assigning of address numbers and street names under
the provisions of this section shall be a continuing process.
   F.   Penalty: Any person, firm, or corporation who violates, disobeys,
neglects, or refuses to comply with any provision of this section, shall be
subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Each day a violation is permitted
to exist after notification thereof shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord.
03-1179, 8-26-2003)
7-1-2: CULVERT CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Permits Required; Expiration: Before commencing with the erection,
enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal of any culvert or
similar structure or any part or parts thereof in the village, a permit for
such erection, enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal shall
first be obtained by the person desiring to do the same, or his agent, from the
village public works supervisor and it shall be unlawful to proceed with such
erection, enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal unless such
permit shall first have been obtained, and if after such permit shall have been
granted, the operations called for by said permit shall not be commenced within
ninety (90) days after the date thereof or if such operations are not completed
within a reasonable time, then such permit shall be void and no operations
thereunder shall be commenced or completed until a new permit shall be issued
and fees as herein fixed for the original permit shall be paid for such new
permit.
   B.   Application For Permit; Fee:
      1.   Application for such permits shall be made by the persons desiring
the same, or their agents, to the village public works supervisor. When such
application is made, plans and specifications shall be submitted for
examination and approval by said village official who shall then issue or cause
to be issued a permit and shall file such application.
      2.   The fee for the issuance of each such permit as herein provided for
shall be the sum of five dollars ($5.00).
   C.   Agreement To Correct Deficient Work: When such application is made, the
applicant shall sign a written agreement with the village to perform all labor
and furnish all materials at the applicant's expense as may be required by the
village public works supervisor to correct or complete any erection,
enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal of any culvert not
done or existing in reasonable compliance with the application at the time of
any inspection of the same as provided for in this section, which agreement
shall remain in full force and effect until and unless the work performed
pursuant to the permit is accepted on behalf of the village at the final
inspection thereof provided for in subsection E of this section, and the
applicant shall so correct or complete such work within sixty (60) days after
notification that the same is in need of correction or completion. The
applicant, in said written agreement, shall further grant to the village the
power, right and authority to do or cause to be done the required correction or
completion in the event the applicant shall fail to correct or complete the
same within said sixty (60) day period, all at the applicant's expense, and the
applicant shall, upon notification of the expense of the same, immediately
remit the same to the village.
   D.   Requirements And Specifications:
      1.   Number Of Culverts: The permits which may be granted hereunder shall
be limited to one driveway or entrance culvert for each residential dwelling
building or commercial establishment.
      2.   Specifications: The culverts may not exceed twenty four feet (24')
in length, must be of at least fourteen (14) gauge galvanized iron and have a
diameter of not less than fifteen inches (15"). (Ord. 0-125, 11-10-1970)
      3.   Ends Protected:
         a.   From and after the effective date hereof, all driveway culverts
and culverts installed under and across streets, roads and highways shall be
protected at the ends thereof with suitable concrete structures which shall
conform to the state of Illinois, department of public works and buildings,
construction standard nos. 1564 and 2262, true and correct copies of which are
attached to ordinance 0-145 on file in the office of the village clerk and made
a part hereof by reference.
         b.   The provisions of this section providing for permits for the
construction of entrance culverts shall apply to the construction of the
concrete structures provided for in this subsection D3. (Ord. 0-145, 2-22-1972;
amd. 1994 Code)
   E.   Inspections: The village public works supervisor or his delegate shall
make an inspection of the site of the culvert to be erected, enlarged, altered,
constructed, repaired or removed prior to the issuance of the permit herein
provided for and shall make such additional inspections as may be necessary and
reasonable during the operations for which the permit is issued and shall make
a further inspection of the same after the erection, enlargement, alteration,
construction, repair or removal provided for in the permit shall be completed
and shall make a final inspection of the same as near as conveniently possible
to one year after the date of the completion of the work for which the permit
was issued. In the event that such erection, enlargement, alteration,
construction, repair or removal of any culvert is not done in reasonable
compliance with the application in a good and workmanlike manner so that the
same shall operate properly, the person to whom such permit is issued shall
make such alterations as may be required to cause conformance with the
application so that the same exists in good operating condition, all as
provided for in the written agreement mentioned and set out in subsection C of
this section.
   F.   Variations: Any variations from the provisions provided for in this
section may be granted only by the Village Board of Trustees upon proper
application to it made. (Ord. 0-125, 11-10-1970; amd. 1994 Code)
7-1-3: UNCOVERED, UNGUARDED SEWERS, WELLS AND DRAINS; DRAINAGE REGRADING OR
RECONSTRUCTION:
   A.   No person shall construct, repair or allow to remain or exist any
cesspool, cistern, hydrant, pump, culvert, drain, sewer, well or similar or
related facility in a manner or method so as to permit the same or any
excavation made or constructed in conjunction therewith to remain open,
uncovered, unfenced, unattended or unguarded so that the same may constitute an
unsafe condition or hazard or danger to the safety, health or welfare of any
person. (Ord. 0-58, 5-10-1966; amd. 1994 Code; Ord. 01-1038, 3-13-2001)
   B.   Prior to regrading or reconstructing any drainage swale, the
contractor/owner shall submit to the Village a site plan showing elevations of
property together with the intended improvements. The grading and
reconstruction shall be completed such that the property will properly drain
without adversely affecting other adjacent properties; and
   C.   If the intended improvement requires the contractor/owner to work on an
adjacent property the permit applicant shall obtain the written consent of such
other property owner. This written consent shall accompany the building permit
application; and
   D.   The applications shall be submitted to the Village of Shorewood
Building Department for their review. If in the opinion of the Building
Department the expertise of the Village Engineer is necessary in order to
properly evaluate the application, the applicant shall be responsible for the
reimbursement of those professional fees.
   E.   Fees for the building permit shall be based on the renovation and
remodeling fees as listed in section
8-1A-9 of this Code. (Ord. 01-1038, 3-13-2001)
7-1-4: OWNERS AND OCCUPANTS SHALL MAINTAIN PARKWAYS:
The owners, occupants, lessees and tenants of property abutting any public
streets, roads or ways shall maintain the area between the edge of pavement or
curb and their property line, commonly known as parkway, in a neat, clean and
orderly condition and free of any weeds, and grass or plants in excess of ten
inches (10") in height other than flowers not exceeding eighteen inches (18")
in height. (Ord. 24-2092, - -2024)
7-1-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1994 Code)
 
CHAPTER 2
EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
7-2-1: Approval And Permit Required
7-2-2: Application For Approval And Permit
7-2-3: Inspection Fee; Security
7-2-4: Issuance Of Permit
7-2-5: Access Requirement
7-2-6: Work Specifications
7-2-7: Emergencies
7-2-8: Excavations In Unpaved Property
7-2-9: Inspections; Restoration By Village
7-2-10: Penalties
7-2-1: APPROVAL AND PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall begin to construct, cut, alter, grade or excavate the
surface or support for the surface of any street, road, highway, parkway, curb
or curb cut within the village without first obtaining written approval from
the village board and a permit from the village administrator.
   B.   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the construction of
facilities in public rights of way, which is governed by chapter 4 of this
title. (Ord. 07-1437, 9-11-2007)
7-2-2: APPLICATION FOR APPROVAL AND PERMIT:
   A.   An applicant seeking a permit to construct, alter, cut, grade or
excavate the surface or the support for the surface of any street, road,
highway, parkway, curb or curb cut shall file with the village board a written
application, on eight and one-half inch by eleven inch (81/2" x 11") paper,
which shall include:
      1.   Name and address of the owner or agent in charge of the party doing
the work.
      2.   Location of the work areas.
      3.   Explanation of why the proposed cut, alteration or excavation is
needed.
      4.   Explanation of alternatives considered with regard to the proposed
cut, alteration or excavation and why the alternatives were rejected.
      5.   Date the cut, alteration or excavation is proposed to occur and the
date on which the repair will begin and be completed.
      6.   The specifications of the cut, alteration or excavation proposed,
including the length, width and depth of the area.
      7.   A map of the work area, on eight and one-half inch by eleven inch
(81/2" x 11") paper, indicating the names of the surrounding streets, roads or
highways, the location of the proposed cut, alteration or excavation and an
arrow indicating which direction is north.
   B.   Each page of the applicant's written proposal shall be dated and signed
by the applicant. The village board may request such other information as it
determines reasonably necessary to the determination of whether approval should
be granted and a permit issued hereunder. (Ord. 88-476, 8-16-1988)
7-2-3: INSPECTION FEE; SECURITY:
   A.   Fee: The applicant shall pay a nonrefundable inspection fee of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) to accompany the written application for a permit
hereunder.
   B.   Security: The following shall accompany the written application for
permit hereunder:
      1.   Performance Bond: The village administrator shall require a
performance bond to be filed with the application for permit hereunder in an
amount to be determined by the village administrator and conditioned that such
work shall be performed in accordance with this chapter. In lieu of a
performance bond, the applicant may post an irrevocable letter of credit, in a
form acceptable to the village, or cash in an amount deemed sufficient by the
village administrator.
      2.   Indemnity Bond: The village administrator shall have the authority
to require the applicant hereunder to file a bond conditioned to protect and
save harmless the village from all claims for damages or injury to other
persons by reason of the work performed. (Ord. 88-476, 8-16-1988)
7-2-4: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
A permit for the proposed work shall be issued by the village's administrator
or his designee upon review by the village administrator and shall be in the
following form:
   VILLAGE OF SHOREWOOD STREET CUT APPROVAL
   Where cut will be made                                        
   When cut will be made                                       
   Cuts Length            Width              Depth                  
   When will cut be repaired                      
   Date of approval                      Expires                           
   Inspected by                 Approved                  Not
Approved                  
   Date of inspection                     
   Permit Approved by                     Date                      
(Ord. 02-1131, 10-22-2002, eff. 10-22-2002)
7-2-5: ACCESS REQUIREMENT:
No person shall construct, cut, alter, grade or excavate the surface or the
support for the surface of any street, road, highway, parkway, curb or curb cut
within the village in such a manner as to isolate any portion of the village
from vehicular access over said street, road, highway or curb cut or other open
streets, roads or highways. In such cases where the excavation or other work of
the entire width of a road, street or highway would cause such isolation of any
area from vehicular traffic, such excavation or other work shall be performed
in such a manner as to leave one lane of traffic open at all times. (Ord. 88-
476, 8-16-1988)
7-2-6: WORK SPECIFICATIONS:
The following specifications shall be adhered to for work performed pursuant to
a permit issued hereunder:
   A.   Notice Of Excavation: The public works department of the village shall
be notified one working day prior to the commencement of the proposed work.
   B.   Pavement Cuts: The existing pavement shall be removed so that the
interior angles at the inside corners of breaks are not less than forty five
degrees (45°) and so that angle of the pavement being removed (or the remaining
pavement for other types of removal) is not less than sixty degrees (60°). The
end of the patch shall be hand trimmed. The general plane of the cut face shall
not deviate more than one and one-half inches (11/2") from vertical.
   C.   Backfill: The trench shall be backfilled with fine aggregate, gradation
FA 6 (Illinois standard specifications) to the subgrade elevation. Trench
backfill with fine aggregate shall be constructed within two feet (2') of the
edge of the proposed pavement. In all other areas, the trench shall be
backfilled with select materials and leveled to grade.
   D.   Restoration And Repair:
      1.   All repairs shall be made within five (5) working days after the
date on which the cut, alteration or excavation was made.
      2.   The pavement replacement shall consist of eight inches (8") of
crushed stone, CA-6 gradation compacted to one hundred percent (100%) proctor
and two inches (2") of compacted thickness of bituminous concrete surface
course, class 1. The subbase shall be bonded to the surface course by one-tenth
(0.1) gallon per square yard of prime RC-70.
      3.   All landscaping within the public right of way shall be restored by
the contractor.
   E.   Traffic Restrictions:
      1.   Traffic shall be permitted on patches for at least three (3) days
prior to resurfacing if complete resurfacing is planned.
      2.   During construction, the contractor shall furnish, erect and
maintain all traffic control devices as specified by the village.
   F.   Variations: Any alteration in the written proposal shall be submitted
to the village board for a new approval.
   G.   Expiration Of Permit: The proposed cut shall be made within thirty (30)
days of the date indicated on the village board's written approval. If the
proposed cut is not made within said period, the applicant shall submit a new
application to the village board for approval. (Ord. 88-476, 8-16-1988)
7-2-7: EMERGENCIES:
In emergency situations requiring immediate excavation, alteration or cut of a
street, road, highway, curb or curb cut, in order to restore essential
utilities or other such immediate necessity, authority to permit such
excavation is vested in the village president, village administrator, foreman
of the public works department of the village or the utilities superintendent
of the village. (Ord. 88-476, 8-16-1988)
7-2-8: EXCAVATIONS IN UNPAVED PROPERTY:
Written permission is not required for the excavation of unpaved portions of
village rights of way. However, any excavation of such unpaved public property
must be properly backfilled, restored and landscaped so as to be left in its
original condition or better. Failure to restore the excavation site
satisfactorily shall cause the person who directs that the excavation be
performed to be liable for a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00),
plus the cost of restoration of the site by the village. (Ord. 88-476, 8-16-
1988)
7-2-9: INSPECTIONS; RESTORATION BY VILLAGE:
The village administrator shall make or cause to be made such inspections as he
deems necessary during and after the performance of the work for which such
permission is granted. Should he determine that the work area which was
excavated has not been satisfactorily restored in accordance with this chapter
within thirty (30) days after the excavation was begun, he will make a claim on
the security posted and, using the proceeds, cause the excavation to be
properly restored. (Ord. 88-476, 8-16-1988)
7-2-10: PENALTIES:
Any person convicted of violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code; provided, that any person convicted of violating section
7-2-8 of this chapter shall, additionally, be liable for the cost of
restoration of the work area. (Ord. 88-476, 8-16-1988; amd. 1994 Code)
CHAPTER 3
WATER AND SEWER USE AND SERVICE
ARTICLE A. PUBLIC AND PRIVATE WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS
SECTION:
7-3A-1: Utilities Division Created; Enforcement
7-3A-2: Definitions
7-3A-3: Extension of Water Mains
7-3A-4: Connection Required, Wells and Private Water Supply Restrictions
7-3A-5: Supplying Other Premises
7-3A-6: Auxiliary Water Supply Restrictions
7-3A-7: Private Water Wells
7-3A-8: Water Service Connection Permit Procedure; Fees
7-3A-9: Water Connection Design Criteria
7-3A-10: Installation and Maintenance of Service Pipes
7-3A-11: Water Meters; Installation and Maintenance
7-3A-12: Access to Premises
7-3A-13: Access to Water Meter and Remote Reader
7-3A-14: Unauthorized Activity
7-3A-15: Interference Prohibited
7-3A-16: Waiver of Liability
7-3A-17: Conservation of Water
7-3A-18: Authority of Village
7-3A-19: Disconnection of Water Service; Fees
7-3A-20: Owner Liability; Damage to Village Utilities or Other Property
7-3A-21: Penalty
7-3A-1: UTILITIES DIVISION CREATED; ENFORCEMENT:
   BOCA CODE: The Building Officials and Code Administrators National Building
Code.
   BOARD: The Board of Trustees of the Village of Shorewood.
   CHAIRMAN OF PUBLIC WORKS COMMITTEE: The Village Trustee appointed by the
Village President to the position of chairman of the Public Works Committee of
the Village of Shorewood.
   CHIEF BUILDING OFFICIAL: The Chief Building Official of the Village of
Shorewood Building Department.
   CURB STOP: A valve installed at the end of a water service connection with a
riser pipe to give access to the valve from ground level. The curb stop is used
by Village employees to turn a water service on or off.
   EASEMENT: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by
others.
   FINANCE DIRECTOR: The Finance Director of the Village of Shorewood.
   IEPA: The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency.
   MUNICIPAL UTILITIES: The Municipal Utilities Division of the Village of
Shorewood.
   MUNICIPAL UTILITIES SUPERVISOR: The Supervisor of the Municipal Utilities
Division of the Village of Shorewood.
   PLUMBING CODE: State of Illinois Plumbing Code (latest edition).
   PLUMBING INSPECTOR: The Chief Building Official of the Village of Shorewood
Building Department or his or her designee.
   SHALL: Shall is mandatory.
   VILLAGE: The corporate authority of the Village of Shorewood and its
officers, employees and agents.
   VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR: The Village Administrator of the Village of
Shorewood.
   VILLAGE ENGINEER: The Village Engineer of the Village of Shorewood.
   VILLAGE LIMITS: The corporate boundaries of the Village of Shorewood.
   VILLAGE PRESIDENT: The President of the Village of Shorewood.
   VILLAGE TREASURER: The Treasurer of the Village of Shorewood.
   WATER METER: A device used to measure the quantity of water flowing through
a water service extension.
   WATER SERVICE CONNECTION: Consists of a service pipe extending from the
water main to and including a shutoff valve or curb stop.
   WATER SERVICE EXTENSION: Service line from the water service connection
shutoff valve to the water meter located on the premises being served. (Ord.
93-715, 11-9-93; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
7-3A-3: EXTENSION OF WATER MAINS:
No water main dedicated or to be dedicated to the Village shall be built, laid
or extended except upon approval by the Village President and Board, directing
the laying or extension of such main or pipe, fixing the location thereof, the
size to be used and, if applicable, the method of financing the cost of the
same. (Ord. 93-715, 11-9-93)
7-3A-4: CONNECTION REQUIRED, WELLS AND PRIVATE WATER SUPPLY RESTRICTIONS:
All existing buildings using domestic water on property in the Village which
are within two hundred feet (200') of a Village water main shall be connected
thereto within one year after notification to connect by the Village Board
unless, in the sole determination of the Village Board, there is insufficient
transmission capacity in the Village water distribution system to properly meet
the needs of the proposed usage or if the proposed usage is such that allowing
the connection would impair the distribution system capacity to other parts of
the Village. At such time as Village water mains are extended to a point
adjacent to properties within the Village limits not served by the Village
water system, said properties shall connect to the Village water system within
one year after date of official notice to do so. (Ord. 93-715, 11-9-1993)
7-3A-5: SUPPLYING OTHER PREMISES:
No persons receiving water through the water system of the Village shall supply
water to other persons or premises unless a permit to do so has been applied
for and obtained from the Village. (Ord. 93-715, 11-9-1993)
7-3A-6: AUXILIARY WATER SUPPLY RESTRICTIONS 1 :
   A.   Interconnection Prohibited: Whenever an auxiliary water system which
receives its supply from any well, cistern or other sources apart from the
water system of the Village is installed or maintained inside or outside of any
building or structure or in any public way or other public or private property,
such private water system shall be kept entirely separated from and not
connected, directly or indirectly, with any pipe or system of pipes receiving
water from the water system of the Village.
   B.   Limitations On Use: Except as provided herein, no auxiliary or other
non-Village operated water supply system shall be installed to serve any
premises or property within the Village limits if those premises or property
are within two hundred feet (200') of the water system of the Village.
   C.   Properties Served By Village Water System And Auxiliary Water System:
      1.   If a property with an auxiliary water system connects to the Village
water supply system, the auxiliary water system may be maintained for outside
water uses and fire sprinkling system purposes only. Once connection is made to
the Village water supply system, the property owner will be required to use
Village water for all domestic and potable water purposes. The Village will
allow the auxiliary water system to be maintained only if it is used on a
regular basis and only if the property owner meets one of the following
requirements:
         a.   The piping from the auxiliary water system must be disconnected
before the piping enters the building foundation. The location where the piping
entered the building foundation must be sealed. Appropriate yard hydrants must
be connected to the auxiliary water system. No pipe or system of pipes from the
auxiliary water system may enter any building being served by Village water
supply.
         b.   A reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device (RPZ)
must be installed in the Village water service connection at the point where
the water service connection enters the building being served. The RPZ must be
installed and maintained in accordance with the Village regulations for cross-
connection control devices.
      2.   If these requirements are not met within thirty (30) calendar days
from the date of connection to the Village water system, the private well is to
be properly sealed and abandoned in accordance with all applicable permits and
in conformance with the requirements of the Will County Water Well and Water
Supply Ordinance and the Illinois Water Well Construction Code of the Illinois
Department of Public Health, within thirty (30) days from the date of
connection to the Village water supply.
   D.   Access To Property: The property owner shall provide the Village access
to the property for the purpose of annual cross-connection control inspections.
(Ord. 93-715, 11-9-1993)
   E.   Supplemental Wells: When a residential property is connected to the
Village water supply system, it shall be permissible to install a well on the
property subject to the following conditions:
      1.   The well shall only be used for outdoor purposes such as vegetation
irrigation and vehicle washing; and
      2.   The well must be installed in conformance with all laws and
regulations applicable thereto including the receipt of all applicable permits
from the Will County Health Department or other agencies; and
      3.   Prior to operation of the well, the Village Utilities Department
must be notified in writing. The Village will then inspect the well to ensure
compliance with applicable ordinances. If the well is not in compliance, it
shall not be operated. The owner shall pay a twenty five dollar ($25.00)
inspection fee to the Village; and
      4.   No pipe or system of pipes from the well may enter any building
being served by the Village water supply. Further, there shall be no inter- or
cross-connection with the Village water supply. Appropriate yard hydrants must
be connected to the well and used to distribute the water; and
      5.   At the request of the Village, the property owner shall provide the
Village access to the property and the structures located thereon for the
purpose of cross-connection inspections.
      6.   The well may only be used to serve the property upon which it is
located and no other properties. (Ord. 96-855, 10-22-1996)
 
Notes
1 1. See Article C of this Chapter for cross-connection control.
7-3A-7: PRIVATE WATER WELLS:
   A.   Permit: No water well shall be constructed or deepened, except pursuant
to all applicable permits and in accordance with the provisions of, and with
permits of, Village ordinances, the Will County Water Well Permit and Water
Supply Ordinance, the Illinois Water Well Construction Code and Illinois Water
Well Pump Installation Code of the Illinois Department of Public Health. Proper
permits from the Environmental Division of the Will County Health Department
must be obtained.
   B.   Application For Permit: Applications for a permit for the construction
or deepening of a well shall be in writing on a form prescribed by the Village
and other applicable governmental entities. Each application shall be
accompanied by a plat showing the location of all wells, septic tanks,
subsurface tile systems and privy vaults constructed, or to be constructed,
upon the lot or premises.
   C.   Testing Of Water: Newly constructed water wells shall be disinfected,
and the owners thereof shall have the water analyzed and approved by the Will
County Health Department and other applicable governmental entities before the
well is placed in service.
   D.   Well Abandonment: When a private water well is abandoned, the work
shall be done in accordance with Will County water well permit and water supply
ordinance and the Illinois Water Well Construction Code of the Illinois
Department of Public Health. The owner of the well shall then provide the
Village with a completed water well sealing form from the Will County Health
Department. (Ord. 93-715, 11-9-1993)
7-3A-8: WATER SERVICE CONNECTION PERMIT PROCEDURE; FEES:
   A.   Connection Permit Application:
      1.   Any person desiring to make any connection with the water system of
the Village, or to use the water therefrom, shall first make application to the
Village upon such form as may be furnished for that purpose. There shall be two
(2) classes of building water connection permits: a) for residential water
connection (including multi-family structures), and b) for commercial,
institutional/governmental or industrial water connection. Each applicant shall
state, among other things:
         a.   The location for the premises for which such service is sought.
         b.   The type of improvement thereon.
         c.   The purposes for which the water is to be used.
         d.   The size of the water and sewer service lines requested.
         e.   The size of the water meter needed for the proposed service.
         f.   The number of water meters that will be required for the service.
         g.   The method of metering usage pursuant to this article.
         h.   Whether building will have a landlord/house meter and service
line.
         i.   The number of cross-connection devices.
      2.   The Village will calculate the fees required for such connections,
including tap-on fees, water meter charges and any other applicable fee or
charges. These fees shall be paid at the time of the issuance of a permit.
   B.   Tap-On Fees: The following fees shall be paid to the Village by the
applicant:
      1.   Residential Buildings: A residential building water connection
permit and inspection fee of three thousand eight hundred thirty four dollars
($3,834.00) for each single-family (attached or detached) residential building
or each dwelling unit (in a multi-family residential building) shall be paid to
the Village at the time the application is filed.
      2.   Institutional/Governmental, Commercial And/Or Industrial Buildings:
In addition to water meter fees, a building water connection permit and
inspection fee for each proposed institutional/governmental, commercial or
industrial water connection for any building or portion thereof shall be paid
to the Village at the time of the issuance of a permit. The amount of the water
connection and inspection fee shall be based upon a base fee and a line size
charge. In buildings where the water service extension is branched to separate
units within the building, the water connection and inspection fee shall be
based upon a base fee and a line size charge for each branch serving a unit.
All water connection, and inspection fees and water meter fees shall be paid
for at the issuance of a building permit for the "shell" of a multi- tenant
building. The charges are as follows:
 
a. Base fee                    $ 4,834.00
b. Water and line size charges per unit:
 1 inch                       $ 750.00
 11/2 inch                    1,000.00
 2 inch                       1,250.00
 Per additional inch          250.00
c. Fire sprinkler service line 3,000.00
 
   C.   Liability For Costs: All costs and expenses incident to the
installation and connection of the building water service connection and
extension shall be borne by the owner of the premises being served. The owner
of the premises being served shall indemnify the Village from any loss, claims,
liability or damage that may be directly or indirectly occasioned by the
installation of the building water service connection and extension.
   D.   Right To Refuse Service: The Village reserves the right to refuse
connection if, in its sole determination, there is insufficient transmission
capacity in the Village water distribution system to properly meet the needs of
the proposed usage or if the proposed usage is such that allowing the
connection would impair the distribution system transmission capacity to other
parts of the Village.
   E.   Sewer And Water Capital Improvement Account: All funds collected from
sewer and water tap-on/connection fees shall be accounted for in a separate
account of the Village known as the sewer and water system capital improvement
account (hereinafter sometimes referred to as the capital improvement account).
The designated funds of the capital improvement account may only be expended
for the construction of capital improvements related to the sewer and water
systems including, but not limited to, the construction and/or extension of
sewer/water mains, lines, valves, hydrants, wells, well houses, sewer treatment
facilities, lift stations and other related infrastructure improvements,
together with the acquisition of property and/or easements necessary therefor.
   F.   Retained Earnings - Capital Improvements Account: The balance remaining
in the capital improvement account at the end of each fiscal period will be
held in a restricted retained earnings account. This account, retained earnings
- capital improvements, will only be available for capital improvement spending
as defined in subsection E of this section.
   G.   Pre-Existing Service: In the event of the changes to a non- residential
building, the reconstruction of a building or the change in use of a building
on a lot that already has sewer or water service necessitates a larger service
tap size, the customer shall pay a connection fee equal to the difference
between the existing service fee and the new service fee. No credit will be
given in the event that the tap size decreases. (Ord. 17-1839, 3-28-2017)
7-3A-9: WATER CONNECTION DESIGN CRITERIA:
   A.   Water Connections:
      1.   All connections to the village water supply proposed for any purpose
shall be reviewed and approved by the village prior to construction. This work
will be performed by and at the owner's expense of the owner of the premises
being served and includes the tapping of the water main, insertion of a
corporation cock, installation of water service connection from the corporation
cock to the curb stop and providing materials necessary for such work.
      2.   A separate and independent building water service extension shall be
provided for every building.
   B.   Application For Water Service: Water supply lines shall be turned on at
the water connection point only by authorized village employees and only if the
following conditions have been met:
      1.   No water service shall be turned on until the water meter charges
and any other fees owed to the village have been paid.
      2.   No water shall be turned on for service in any premises in which the
plumbing does not comply with the provisions of the plumbing regulations of the
village and state plumbing code. Water may be turned on for construction uses
in unfinished buildings subject to the provisions of these regulations.
      3.   No individual, contractor, corporation or other entity shall be
eligible to have water turned on for any use whatsoever, if at the time of
application it has any outstanding indebtedness for past water use.
      4.   No water service shall be turned on until the water service
extension has been inspected and approved by the village and a water meter has
been installed.
   C.   Service Pipe Specifications:
      1.   Water service pipe materials shall meet applicable American water
works association (AWWA) specifications and shall be either class K copper or
ductile iron pipe. All water lines shall be not less than five feet (5') below
average grade and protected from frost. Water service connections and water
service extensions less than two inches (2") in diameter shall be one piece,
class K copper with no joint in sections less than the length of one full roll
of class K copper pipe (100 feet for 3/4 inch or 1 inch, 60 feet for 11/2 inch
or 2 inch).
      2.   Connection to any water main or water supply system of the village
shall be made with brass or bronze clow or Mueller Corporation stopcock,
approved by the village.
      3.   A curb stop and riser box (commonly referred to as a buffalo box or
B-box) shall be installed in every water service connection. The shutoff valve
or curb stop shall be located on the street side of the right of way line and
not more than seven and one-half feet (71/2') therefrom and shall be installed
with a valve vault or valve box (B-box). All work and materials shall be in
conformance with village requirements and approved specifications. In no case
shall the curb stop and riser box be installed under a driveway, sidewalk or
other paved area. The riser box shall be a Minneapolis type, one and one-half
inch (11/2") diameter, and shall be adjusted with the top of the riser box at
final grade.
   D.   Proximity Of Water Extensions To Sewer Lines: Sanitary sewer and water
service extension shall comply with all governmental regulations.
   E.   JULIE Notification Requirements: No water service connection will be
allowed unless proper notification (minimum 48 hours) has been given to the
JULIE (joint utility location information for excavators) systems and a JULIE
dig number has been issued. (Ord. 93-715, 11-9-1993)
   F.   Water Main Flushing And Sampling; Charges: For all new subdivisions,
the initial flush, fill and chlorination of a newly installed water main is
routine and will incur no water charge, however, there will be a laboratory
fee. All subsequent water usage will be subject to rates based on estimated
usage with a minimum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per incident and/or tap.
All bacteriological testing will be done through the village of Shorewood. An
outside laboratory will be used by the village for testing. The applicant shall
reimburse the village for its cost associated with such testing. The water main
being tested will be tested as a unit. There will be no partial approval. If
any sample fails, every sample must be resampled, subject to village review.
There will be adequate sample taps installed as determined by the village
sample collector, including a tap at the source of the water main. (Ord. 01-
1072, 10-23-2001)
7-3A-10: INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SERVICE PIPES:
   A.   Entrance Of Connections, Extensions, Into Buildings: All service
connections or extensions shall be laid in streets, alleys or public grounds
adjacent to the premises so as to enter the building to be served by the most
direct route from the main.
   B.   Persons Authorized To Make Connections: All water service connections
shall be supervised by the village.
   C.   Licensed Plumber To Install Extensions At Owner's Expense: Water
service extensions shall be installed by a licensed plumber at the sole expense
of the owner of the premises being served. The licensed plumber shall, among
other things, have filed with the village a certificate of insurance, in an
amount acceptable to the village, which names the village as an additional
named insured. The village shall be indemnified by such plumber and the
property owner from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be
caused by such installation. The connection shall be made in the presence of
the authorized village representative.
   D.   Guarding Excavations: All excavations for a building water service
connection shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights in compliance
with all applicable standards established for excavations by the state of
Illinois department of transportation, so as to protect the public from hazard.
   E.   Traffic Control Coordination: During any construction which will stop
or impede the normal flow of traffic on any right of way, the contractor or
property owner shall provide any necessary traffic control. The traffic control
shall be coordinated with the village.
   F.   Extensions To Be Inspected: Each service extension shall be inspected
prior to backfilling in the presence of an authorized village representative
and shall show no leakage under full water pressure. No extension shall be
covered until such inspection is completed and found satisfactory. When such
work has been approved, the trench or excavation shall be immediately refilled
with suitable material and properly compacted to prevent settling and the
flagging and sidewalk restored to as good a condition as previous to the
excavation. If said service covered is backfilled prior to inspection, the
village reserves the right to require the contractor to expose the entire
service extension for inspection before service may commence. A service
connection shall be air tested with one hundred (100) psi for fifteen (15)
minutes when temperature is at freezing or below.
   G.   Request For Inspection Of Service Connection: The village requires
twenty four (24) hours advance notice before inspections can be given.
Inspections will not be made outside of the normal working hours of the water
division. It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to ensure that
proper notice is given.
   H.   Restoration Of Public Property: If the installation of the water
service connection or water service extension requires the excavation of any
street, road, parkway or other publicly owned property, the property owner
shall apply for a permit for such excavation, pay fees and post bonds or other
security as required by the village. Such permit must be issued prior to any
excavation. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other publicly owned property
disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory
to the village. The village shall solely determine if the street should be open
cut or bored.
   I.   Maintenance Of Extensions: Water service extensions, including the
connection to the water service connection, are the property of and shall be
maintained at the sole expense of the owner of the property served.
   J.   Reconstruction Of Existing Connections: Where an existing property is
served by a water service connection extending past adjacent property, such
service connection shall be reconstructed at the expense of the owner of the
property served by such service connection within one year after the placing in
service of a village water main adjacent to said property or, if such main
already exists, within one year following the passage of this article.
   K.   Construction Of Connection, Extensions To Adjoining Premises
Prohibited: No consumer will be permitted to construct a water service
connection or extension across a lot to adjoining premises.
   L.   Repair Of Leaks Or Defects; Owner's Responsibility: Any leaks or
defects in water service extensions shall be promptly repaired by and at the
sole cost of the property owner and water customer. If leaks develop in an
existing service extension not meeting the requirements of this article it
shall be replaced in such a manner and with such materials as to meet the
requirements of the village.
   M.   Failure Of Owner To Repair: In case any leak in a water service
extension is not promptly repaired, the water supply shall be shut off by the
village and not turned on again until such leak has been repaired and any
expense incurred by the village in connection therewith has been paid.
   N.   Compliance Required: All connections to the water system of the
village, whether inside or outside the village corporate limits, shall be
subject to state, county and village rules and regulations. (Ord. 93-715, 11-9-
1993)
7-3A-11: WATER METERS; INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE:
   A.   Water Meter Requirements, Residential: Each residential dwelling unit
shall have a separate water meter. The village reserves the right to determine
the nature of the installation and the location of meters to be installed and
the same will be determined by the village.
   B.   Water Meter Requirements; Governmental/Institutional, Commercial Or
Industrial: In governmental/institutional, commercial or industrial buildings
with multiple units, the water meter installation shall conform to one of the
following standards:
      1.   Individual Water Meters: Individual water meters shall be installed
in each individual building unit. A separate water service extension shall be
installed for each building unit, including an accessible service shut-off
valve (B-box) located outside the building. If this option is chosen, a
separate village utility billing will be issued for each individual unit.
      2.   Water Meter Room:
         a.   In buildings with multiple units, one water service extension
shall be installed for no more than twelve (12) individual units. The water
service extension shall be of adequate size to provide proper water pressure
and volume to each unit served. The water service extension shall include an
accessible single shut-off valve (B-box) located outside the building in the
parkway. (Ord. 93-715, 11-9-1993)
         b.   The water and utility meter room shall be constructed at the
point where the water service extension enters the building. The water and
utility meter room shall be heated and used solely for this purpose and of
adequate square footage to provide ample room for the location, reading and
servicing of all such water and utility meters. Access to the water and utility
meter room shall be secured and fully restricted so that it shall be accessible
from the outside with entry to such room restricted to persons authorized to
read and service such water and utility meters. The door shall have a
nonbattery push button lock for the water and utility meter room for the
purpose of the village municipal utilities department entry to read and service
water and utility meters. (Ord. 14-1723, 2-25-2014, eff. 4-1-2014)
         c.   Branch plumbing shall be provided from the water service
extension such that each unit is served by a separate water service line from
the water and utility meter room. Each branch line shall be labeled as to which
line feeds which building unit. Each branch line shall include a water meter
and couplings, an approved tamperproof/tamper resistant locking ball valve
installed on the inlet side of the water meter, and a ball valve installed on
the outlet side of the meter. Space shall be provided for the installation of
any backflow prevention device that may need to be installed in the future.
      3.   Master Meter: One master water meter shall be installed in each
building, with branch plumbing to the individual units. If the master meter
option is chosen, the owner of the building shall be responsible for all
village utility billing.
   C.   Water Meter Location: All water meters shall be installed in a location
that will be readily accessible and have easy access for routine meter reading
and/or service or replacement. All existing installations which do not comply
with these provisions shall be changed at the property owner's or water user's
expense within thirty (30) days after the date of notice from the village.
(Ord. 93-715, 11-9-1993)
   D.   Supply And Maintenance Of Water Meters: Upon submittal of an
application for service, the property owner shall pay a water meter charge
based upon the size, type and quantity of water meters needed, and the village
will supply and own said water meters. The village will maintain, at its own
expense, residential and commercial water meters. (Ord. 14-1723, 2-25-2014,
eff. 4-1-2014)
   E.   Water Meter Installation Hardware:
      1.   Ball Valve: Two (2) full flow ball valves (Mueller series 300) shall
be provided by the village and shall be installed by a licensed plumber at the
expense of the property owner. Said valves are to be installed in the service
line, one immediately prior to the water meter yoke and within two feet (2') of
the point at which the water service extension enters the premises, and one
foot (1') immediately following the water meter yoke. (Ord. 93-715, 11-9-1993)
      2.   Water Meter: A water meter shall be provided by the village, after a
water meter fee has been paid by the property owner. In all cases, the village
shall specify the size and type of water meter to be installed. The water meter
is to be installed at the owner's cost by an authorized representative of the
village or a licensed plumber. The meter shall be installed in a horizontal
position.
Meter Prices
Meter Prices
3/4 inch  $ 550.00
1 inch    675.00
11/2 inch 1,800.00
2 inch    2,000.00
3 inch    2,400.00
4 inch    4,000.00
6 inch    6,500.00
 
(Ord. 14-1723, 2-25-2014, eff. 4-1-2014)
      3.   Water Meter Yoke: On water services with water meters up to and
including two inch (2") diameters, a water meter yoke (Mueller type H-1412)
shall be provided by the village. The water meter yoke shall be installed by a
licensed plumber, at the expense of the property owner; the water meter yoke
shall be installed immediately following the ball valve. (Ord. 93-715, 11-9-
1993)
      4.   Remote Reader: A remote reading device shall be provided by the
village. This remote reader shall be securely fastened on the front of the
building or on either side of the building within four feet (4') of the front
of the building. Installation of the remote reader shall be done by the
village. In no case is the remote reader to be installed in the rear of a
residential building. In the case of a commercial building, the village
reserves the right to specify the location of the remote reader on a case by
case basis. (Ord. 14-1723, 2-25-2014, eff. 4-1-2014)
      5.   Bypass Required: All water meters larger than one inch (1") shall be
provided with a bypass to allow water to bypass the water meter during
maintenance activities. The valve on the bypass shall be equipped with a
locking device to prevent unauthorized operation of the valve and shall be
approved by the village.
      6.   Conduit: One-half inch (1/2") EMT (thin wall) conduit shall be
installed from a point within twelve inches (12") from the water meter to a
point on the outside of the building where the remote reader is to be located.
The conduit will be provided and installed by the builder, complete with wire.
In any existing building with an existing service without conduit installed,
conduit must be installed before any remodeling is done that would make the
remote wire inaccessible.
      7.   Other Fittings: The village reserves the right to require such other
fittings and valves to be installed as the village deems necessary. Such
fittings may include, but are not limited to, locking ball valves, check valves
and backflow preventers. Said fittings shall be supplied by the property owner
and shall be of types approved by the village.
   F.   Maintenance Of Meter Installation: Should any part of the water meter
installation hardware be found to be faulty, the village may require the
replacement of some or all of the hardware. All materials used in the
replacement of water meter installation hardware shall conform to current
specifications for said hardware. With the exception of the water meter costs,
all material and labor costs for said replacement shall be at the expense of
the property owner and/or utility customer. (Ord. 93-715, 11-9-1993)
   G.   Testing Meters: In case of dispute over the amount of a bill or over
the accuracy of a meter, the village will, at the request of the consumer, test
the meter. If it is found, upon such test, that the meter registers a greater
amount of water than has actually passed through it, the bill will then be
adjusted to conform to the amount passing through the meter, and no charge will
be made for the test. If, however, the meter registers a lesser amount than
actually passes through it, the consumer will be required to pay, on the basis
of the amount passing through the meter, an additional charge of two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) and the meter will be reinstalled. (Ord. 14-1723, 2-25-
2014, eff. 4-1-2014)
7-3A-12: ACCESS TO PREMISES:
The village and its employees, including all water meter inspectors, shall be
given ready access to the premises wherein water meters are located for the
purpose of reading, examining, testing and repairing such meters and fixtures.
(Ord. 93-715, 11-9-1993)
7-3A-13: ACCESS TO WATER METER AND REMOTE READER:
The property owner shall not obstruct access to the water meter or remote
reader of any property served by the village water supply. Property owners will
be required to permanently remove any such obstructions within a reasonable
period of time. (Ord. 93-715, 11-9-1993)
7-3A-14: UNAUTHORIZED ACTIVITY:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall turn on or use water from the water
system unless so authorized by the issuance of a permit by the village to use
the water system.
   B.   Seals: It shall be unlawful for any person to break or cause to be
broken the seal on any water meter, valve, fitting or any other connection
