CHAPTER 2
DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Permit Requirements
8-2-2: Notice Prior To Demolition
8-2-3: Safety Precautions
8-2-4: Demolition Procedure
8-2-5: Supervision
8-2-6: Building Wrecking Contractors
8-2-7: Penalty
8-2-1: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required: Before proceeding with the demolition of any building
or structure, a permit for demolition shall first be obtained from the Chief
Building Official by the owner of the building or his agent, and it shall be
unlawful to proceed with the demolition of any building or structure or any
structural part thereof within the Village unless a permit required by this
subsection shall first have been obtained.
   B.   Application For Permit: An application for a permit required by this
section shall state the location of the building to be demolished and shall
also describe the building.
   C.   Permit Fees: The fees for a permit required by this section shall be as
provided in section
8-1A-9 of this title.
   D.   Bond And Insurance: Application for a permit required by this section
shall be accompanied by a certificate of insurance as required by subsection
8-2-6E of this chapter and a wrecking bond to the Village in the sum of fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00) conditioned upon the faithful observance of all
the provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the Village relevant to
the demolition, tearing down of the building, the transportation of material
obtained therefrom, the restoration and leveling the premises upon which the
demolition takes place and the removal of other hazards occasioned by the
demolition of the building, and shall bind the surety for a period of one year
from the date demolition is completed or until a new structure occupies the
entire site, whichever occurs first.
The Village Board shall have the discretion to allow a person who is wrecking
or tearing down any building or structure on premises owned by the applicant
for the permit to carry on the work without a wrecking bond. (Ord. 93-725, 12-
14-1993; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
8-2-2: NOTICE PRIOR TO DEMOLITION:
A notice stating the date on which the demolition work is to begin shall be
given to the Chief Building Official at least twenty four (24) hours before
beginning the demolition of any building or other structure. (Ord. 93-725, 12-
14-1993; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
8-2-3: SAFETY PRECAUTIONS:
   A.   Generally: During the removal, demolition or wrecking or tearing down
of any building or structure, proper provisions shall be made for the
protection of public sidewalks or other public thoroughfares in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   Buildings Exceeding Height Limits: Buildings or structures exceeding
two (2) stories or twenty five feet (25') in height and intended to be
demolished shall comply with the following protection requirements:
      1.   The owner or his agent shall submit a drawing indicating fences,
barricades, aprons, canopies and other safeguards which are to be used in
connection with the wrecking program. This drawing shall be approved by the
Chief Building Official before a permit is issued to wreck the building or
structure, and the safeguards indicated on the drawing shall be erected in
strict compliance therewith.
      2.   One apron shall be constructed for each three (3) stories above the
adjoining sidewalk grade, with the lowest apron located in this third story.
   C.   Construction Standards For Safety Devices: When required in this
chapter for the protection of sidewalks or other public ways, sidewalk sheds,
fences, barricades and aprons shall comply with the following requirements:
      1.   Sidewalk Sheds: Sidewalk sheds shall consist of a roof deck
extending over the entire sidewalk, together with its supporting structural
framework. The roof deck shall be constructed of not less than two (2) layers
of two inch (2") planking or of other approved materials of equal strength and
shall be designed to support a superimposed load of not less than two hundred
fifty (250) pounds per square foot.
      2.   Fences: Fences shall be not less than six feet (6') high of solid
construction, sheathed with one inch (1") lumber or other approved materials of
equal strength.
      3.   Barricades: Barricades shall consist of substantial railings or
other barriers which will effectively prevent public access to the barricaded
area.
      4.   Aprons: An "apron" is defined as a platform extending from the
exterior wall of a building at any level. Aprons shall be constructed of not
less than two (2) layers of two inch (2") planking or of other approved
materials of equal strength and shall be designed to support a superimposed
load of not less than two hundred fifty (250) pounds per square foot. Aprons
shall extend not less than six feet (6') from the building wall and shall slope
downward toward the building wall or shall be provided with a substantial curb
not less than twelve inches (12") high at the outer edge.
   D.   Sidewalk Shed Required; Exceptions: When a building to be wrecked is
located not less than twenty five feet (25') from the street line, a sidewalk
shed shall be provided, except under the following conditions:
      1.   When the height of the building does not exceed two (2) stories or
thirty feet (30'), a barricade located not less than ten feet (10') from the
building may be used in lieu of a sidewalk shed.
      2.   When the height of the building does not exceed three (3) stories or
forty feet (40'), a barricade located not less than fifteen feet (15') from the
building may be used in lieu of a sidewalk shed.
      3.   When the height of a building does not exceed four (4) stories or
fifty feet (50'), a fence located not less than twenty five feet (25') from the
building may be used in lieu of a sidewalk shed. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-1993; amd.
Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
8-2-4: DEMOLITION PROCEDURE:
   A.   Generally: In the demolition of the structural elements of any building
or structure, the work shall begin at the top thereof, and each story shall be
completely razed or demolished and the material therefrom completely removed
before beginning work on the next lower story.
   B.   Removal Of Debris; Storage Of Salvaged Material: Debris caused from the
demolition of a building or structure in excess of that required to fill and
grade the site shall be removed from the site as wrecking progresses. Salvaged
material, if left on the premises, shall be neatly stored and for a period of
not more than thirty (30) days.
   C.   Filling And Grading Of Demolition Site: On completion of demolition,
the site shall be filled where necessary with clean soil, cinders or other
inorganic material and graded to a level not lower or more than twelve inches
(12") above or below the level of sidewalks, alleys or adjoining property, with
proper allowance for settlement.
   D.   Time Limitation On Operations: All demolition operations shall be
completed within the time set by the Chief Building Official. (Ord. 93-725, 12-
14-1993; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
8-2-5: SUPERVISION:
Upon the issuance of permits required by this chapter and the notice required
by section
8-2-2 of this chapter, the building for which the permit was issued may be
wrecked or torn down. All work done under the permits shall be subject to the
supervision of the Chief Building Official and to such reasonable restrictions
as he may impose in regard to the elements of safety and health, and said work
shall be performed under the same requirements as govern the erection of
buildings. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-1993; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
8-2-6: BUILDING WRECKING CONTRACTORS:
   A.   Definition: The term "building wrecking contractor" is hereby defined
as every person engaged in the business of the removal, demolition or wrecking
or tearing down of any building or structure within the Village.
   B.   Permit Required; Posting: The removal, demolition, wrecking or tearing
down of any building or structure within the Village, shall only be performed
by a building wrecking contractor issued a permit under this section. The
building wrecking contractor shall make application for a permit to the Chief
Building Official who shall issue the permit if the applicant meets all the
requirements as provided by law/ordinance. The permit shall be posted in a
conspicuous place upon the exterior of the premises for which it is issued and
shall remain posted at all times until the work is completed.
   C.   Application For Permit: The application for a permit required by this
section shall be in such form as shall be prescribed by the Chief Building
Official. Every application for a permit required by this section shall state
the location and describe the building which it is proposed to wreck or tear
down.
   D.   Permit Fees: Fees for the issuance of permits required by this section
shall be paid to the Village and shall be as provided in section
8-1A-9 of this title.
   E.   Insurance Requirements:
      1.   Before any permit required by this section is issued, the person
engaged in the work of demolishing the building shall file with the Village
Clerk a comprehensive public liability insurance policy in an amount of not
less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injuries, including
accidental death, to any one person and in an amount of five hundred thousand
dollars ($500,000.00) for injuries, including accidental death, sustained by
two (2) or more persons as a result of any one accident and a property damage
insurance policy in an amount of not less than three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00), which policy shall note the Village as co-insured. The Village
Board of Trustees may, upon request, vary or waive the required insurance
coverages.
      2.   The policies of insurance required by the preceding subsection shall
be approved as to form by the Village Attorney prior to the issuance of a
permit and shall be in such form as to indemnify, keep and save harmless the
Village against any loss, cost, damage, expenses, judgment or liability of any
kind whatsoever which the Village may suffer or which may accrue against, be
charged to or be recovered from the Village or any of its officials from or by
reason or on account of accidents to persons or property during any demolition
operations and from or by reason or on account of anything done under or by
virtue of any permit granted for any demolition operations.
      3.   In case of accident or casualty in the progress of any demolition
operations carried on under any permit issued pursuant to this section or the
happening of any circumstances which might, in the findings of the Chief
Building Official, render the policies of insurance inadequate, the Village
Board may, in its discretion, require such additional insurance as it may deem
necessary to fully protect the Village from loss resulting from the issuance of
the permit before it allows the work to proceed or before any additional
permits are issued. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-1993; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
8-2-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be
subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-1993; amd. 1994 Code)
CHAPTER 3
MOBILE HOMES AND MOBILE HOME PARKS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Short Title; Scope
8-3-2: Definitions
8-3-3: License and Permit Requirements
8-3-4: Mobile Home Park and Mobile Home Lot Requirements
8-3-5: Sewage Disposal
8-3-6: Fire Protection
8-3-7: Mobile Home Requirements in Parks
8-3-8: Existing Mobile Home Parks
8-3-9: Office; Registration
8-3-10: Reserved
8-3-11: Enforcement; Inspections
8-3-12: Revocation or Suspension of License; Refusal of License or Permit
8-3-13: Exemptions from Provisions
8-3-14: Violation and Penalty
8-3-1: SHORT TITLE; SCOPE:
This Chapter shall be known and referred to as the SHOREWOOD MOBILE HOME PARK
ORDINANCE and covers the granting of annual licenses and permits to construct,
alter or add to planned developments of areas restricted to the location of
independent mobile homes and related facilities. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-93)
8-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the words and phrases set forth
in this Section shall have the meanings set forth herein when used in this
Chapter:
   CHIEF BUILDING OFFICIAL: The Chief Building Official is as defined in Title
1, Chapter 5, Article C of this Code.
   DEPENDENT MOBILE HOME: A mobile home which does not have a toilet and bath
or shower facilities. The mobile home park, as defined, excludes the dependent
trailer coach or dependent mobile home from the mobile home park.
   INDEPENDENT MOBILE HOME: A mobile home with self-contained toilet and bath
or shower with provisions for connection to sewer and water riser pipes as
defined in this Chapter.
   MOBILE HOME: As defined in Title 10, Chapter 2 of this Code.
   MOBILE HOME PARK: An area of land upon which two (2) or more occupied
independent mobile homes are harbored, either free of charge or for revenue
purposes, and shall include any building, structure, or enclosure used or
intended for use as a part of the equipment of such mobile home park.
   MOBILE HOME LOT: Any portion of a mobile home park designed for use or
occupancy of one mobile home.
   SCHOOL DISTRICT: Any district created or operated under the provisions of
the "The School Code" (105 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.). (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-93; amd.
Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
8-3-3: LICENSE AND PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   License and Permit Required:
      1.   No person shall establish, maintain, conduct or operate a mobile
home park after the effective date hereof without first obtaining a license
therefor from the Village. Such a license shall be issued for one year and
shall expire at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on December 31 of each year.
The license shall be renewed from year to year upon payment of the annual
license fee herein provided. Licenses shall be issued by the Chief Building
Official.
      2.   No person shall construct a mobile home park without first obtaining
a permit from the Chief Building Official.
      3.   Each mobile home park permit holder shall secure an annual license
on or before December 31 following the date on which the construction permit is
issued. Application for the annual license shall be made on forms supplied by
the Chief Building Official or, if no such forms are available, may be made by
letter containing all of the matters required by this Chapter.
   B.   Application for Permit or License: In order to obtain a permit to
construct or an original license to operate a mobile home park, the applicant
shall file with the Chief Building Official a written application on a form
setting forth:
      1.   The full name and address of the applicant or applicants or names
and addresses of the partners if the applicant is a partnership, of the names
and addresses of the officers if the applicant is a corporation and the present
or last occupation of the applicant at the time of the filing of the
application.
      2.   The location and legal description of the tract of land upon which
it is proposed to operate and maintain a mobile home park.
      3.   The proposed and existing facilities in the park for water supply,
sewage, garbage and solid waste disposal and fire protection.
      4.   The proposed method of lighting structures and land upon which the
park is located.
      5.   The plat plans of the park drawn on a scale of one hundred feet to
one inch (1" = 100'), building plans and specifications for existing buildings
and facilities and specifications for new buildings and facilities or the
proposed alterations in existing facilities, all showing compliance with the
provisions of this chapter, the plat plans to be drawn on a scale of one
hundred feet to one inch (1" = 100'), and shall contain, among other things,
the following:
         a.   The date on which such plat plans were prepared.
         b.   An arrow indicating north.
         c.   All mobile home lots shall be properly numbered on plat plans.
         d.   Complete information regarding storm sewers.
         e.   Stormwater runoff shall be shown on a separate plat.
         f.   Contour lines at two foot (2') intervals shall be shown on a
separate plat and United States Geological Survey data shall be used for the
preparation of such plat.
         g.   Grades of driveways and all ditches shall be shown on a separate
plat.
         h.   All maps and plans must be signed by and bear the seal of a
registered professional engineer.
      6.   A statement of the firefighting facilities, public or private, which
are available to the mobile home park.
An affidavit as to the truth of the matters contained in the application shall
be attached thereto. Where a permit to construct as well as an original license
to operate is sought by the applicant, request therefor shall be made in the
same application. Each application for a permit to construct or for an original
license shall be made in the same application and shall be accompanied by an
application fee and shall be paid to the Village in the amount of the
application fee.
   C.   Investigation Of Applicants; Approval Or Disapproval Of License Or
Permit; Issuance:
      1.   The Chief Building Official shall examine the application for a
permit to construct or an application for a license to operate and maintain a
mobile home park, and the Chief Building Official shall, if the park is, or the
proposed mobile home park will be, in conformity with this chapter, Title 10 of
this Code (Zoning Ordinance) and other applicable ordinances as determined by
the Chief Building Official, issue a permit to construct or an original
license, as the case may be.
      2.   If the application for a permit to construct or a license to operate
and maintain is declined, the Chief Building Official shall give the reasons
therefor, in writing, to the applicant, and if the deficiencies can be
corrected, the applicant may amend his application and resubmit it for
approval.
      3.   If a permit to construct a mobile home park has been issued, the
applicant shall, upon completion thereof, notify the Chief Building Official.
The Chief Building Official shall then inspect the mobile home park, and if
completion is in accordance with the accepted application, the Chief Building
Official shall issue a license to operate and maintain said mobile home park.
      4.   Such a permit does not relieve the applicant from complying with the
Village Zoning Ordinance, Building Codes 1  and the sewerage treatment and
disposal provisions of the Village and other applicable bodies. No mobile home
park permit shall be issued if such mobile home park is in violation of the
Zoning Ordinance.
      5.   A permit to construct or a license to operate and maintain or the
yearly renewal of a license to operate and maintain such mobile home park shall
not be issued by the Chief Building Official until evidence exists to
demonstrate adequate facilities and services that pertain to the disposal of
sewage, water supply and system, garbage and solid waste storage and final
disposal and any other health related facilities or conditions at the mobile
home park site.
   D.   License Fees: In addition to the application fee provided for herein,
the licensee shall pay the Village on or before January 1 of each year an
annual license fee, which shall be as follows:
For mobile home parks with:
 
1 to 10 lots      $150.00 plus $10.00 a lot
11 to 50 lots     $250.00 plus $10.00 a lot
51 to 100 lots    $500.00 plus $10.00 a lot
101 to 500 lots   $750.00 plus $10.00 a lot
501 to 1,000 lots $1,000.00 plus $10.00 a lot
 
Each license for a mobile home park shall be paid to the Village in the amount
of the license fee, and any license fee or any part thereof, once paid to and
accepted by the Village, shall not be refundable.
   E.   Construction Alterations And Modifications:
      1.   In the event the licensee of a mobile home park wishes to add on or
change whatsoever in the mobile home park as covered by the construction permit
or license, a new application for construction permit is required. This
application shall be accompanied by a fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for
each mobile home lot. This fee is not refundable.
      2.   The Chief Building Official shall not issue a construction permit to
make any alterations, modifications, add ons or changes whatsoever in the
mobile home park if the issuance would violate this chapter, the Zoning
Ordinance, or other applicable ordinances.
   F.   Conditions of Licenses and Permits:
      1.   Display of License or Permit: Each permit to construct, each license
to operate and each permit to make alterations therein shall be prominently
displayed in the office of the mobile home park for which the same was issued.
      2.   Separate Permit and License for Each Location: Each permit or
license shall apply only to the premises described in the application and in
the license issued thereon, and only one location shall be so described in each
license.
      3.   Nontransferability of License: A license which has been issued to a
person may not be transferred without the written consent of the Chief Building
Official. However, the Chief Building Official may not withhold such consent
where the provisions of this Chapter have been met. A license which has been
issued for a particular premises may not be removed or made to apply to any
other premises. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-93; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 1 of this title.
8-3-4: MOBILE HOME PARK AND MOBILE HOME LOT REQUIREMENTS:
Except as provided in Section
 8-3-7 of this Chapter, every mobile home park licensed or to be constructed
under the provisions of this Chapter shall comply with the following
provisions:
   A.   Park Attendant: Every mobile home park shall be in the charge of a
responsible attendant or manager at all times whose duties shall be to maintain
the park, its facilities and equipment in a clean, orderly and sanitary
condition and be answerable with the licensee for any violation of the
provisions of this Chapter.
   B.   Park Drainage:
      1.   All such parks shall be well drained and shall be located in areas
free from ponds, swamps and similar places in which mosquitos may breed.
      2.   All sewage from mobile homes shall be discharged into a sanitary
sewer system.
   C.   Maximum Density of Units Per Acre shall be in accordance with Title 10,
Chapter 5, Article I.
   D.   Mobile Home Lots:
      1.   Minimum Area: The minimum area for each mobile home lot shall be in
accordance with Title 10, Chapter 5, Article I.
      2.   Mobile Home Stand: That part of an individual lot reserved for the
placement of the mobile home shall be called the mobile home stand and shall
conform to the following standards:
         a.   Placement: The mobile home stand shall be so placed as to provide
for the practical placement on the site of both the mobile home and its
appurtenant structures and the retention of the mobile home on the site in a
stable condition and in satisfactory relationship to its surroundings.
         b.   Size: The size of the mobile home stand shall be suitable for the
mobile home to be served by the individual park and suitable to fit dimensions
of the mobile home anticipated, including mobile home appurtenant structures or
appendages.
         c.   Location: The location of each mobile home stand shall be at such
elevation, distance and angle in relation to the access street and the mobile
home lot driveway that placement and removal of the mobile home is practical.
         d.   Construction Specifications: Concrete slab or concrete runways.
         e.   Gradient: There shall be a minimum of two percent (2%)
longitudinal and adequate crown or cross-gradient and surface drainage.
         f.   Base Enclosure: All mobile homes which are placed on piers shall
have the entire perimeter enclosed. The enclosure shall be of a material
approved by the Village. Panels manufactured specifically for mobile home
enclosures shall be considered to meet these requirements.
      3.   Minimum Width: The minimum width for each mobile home lot shall be
in accordance with Title 10, Chapter 5, Article I.
      4.   Minimum Distance Between Mobile Homes: No mobile home shall be
placed closer than permitted in Title 10, Chapter 5, Article I.
      5.   Yards Abutting Common Areas: Every mobile home shall be setback from
common areas, park boundary line and lot lines in accordance with Title 10,
Chapter 5, Article I.
      6.   Site Specifications: Every mobile home lot shall be clearly defined
on the ground by permanent markers. There shall be posted and maintained in a
conspicuous place on each site a number corresponding to the number of each
site as shown on the plot plan submitted, as required by this Chapter, so that
each lot may be easily identified. Each mobile home lot shall have provided
thereon a patio and adequate storage conforming to Title 10, Chapter 5, Article
I.
   E.   Streets and Walks:
      1.   Streets:
         a.   The construction of all private streets shall conform to the
requirements of the Title 11 of this Code.
         b.   For private streets provided within the mobile home park, a
right-of-way width of fifty feet (50') shall be required. A minimum of twenty
four feet (24') in width of pavement, back- to-back of curbs, shall be provided
in the center of such right of way. All private streets shall have unobstructed
access to a public street or highway.
         c.   All arterial streets constructed in connection with a mobile home
park, no matter where the park may be located within the Village, shall be
designed and laid out in accordance with the provisions of Title 11 of this
Code, except as may be modified by this Chapter.
      2.   Walks: Walks shall be provided for safe, convenient, all season
pedestrian access, of adequate width for intended use, durable and convenient
to maintain and shall be designed and laid out in accordance with the
requirements of Title 11 of this Code except as may be modified by this
Chapter. There shall be:
         a.   Individual walks to each mobile home stand from a paved driveway
or parking space connecting to a paved street.
         b.   Common walks in such locations required by the requirements of
Title 11 of this Code and in locations where pedestrian traffic is
concentrated; for example, at the park entrance to the court office and other
important facilities.
         c.   Width, alignment and gradient of walks shall be appropriate for
safety, convenience and appearance and shall be suitable for use by both
pedestrians and for the circulation of small wheeled vehicles such as baby
carriages and service carts.
         d.   Walks shall be constructed of concrete in accordance with the
specifications of the requirements of Title 11 of this Code as modified by this
Chapter. Widths shall be at least four feet (4') for common walks. Private
walks on mobile home lots shall be two feet (2') minimum width. Sudden changes
in alignment and gradient shall be avoided. Required walks are not to be used
as drainageways.
      3.   Parking Spaces: Required parking spaces for each mobile home lot
shall be provided in accordance with Title 10, Chapter 8 of this Code and
parking may be in tandem. In addition, there shall be a sufficient number of
parking spaces in conveniently located parking bays to bring the total number
of parking spaces up to the two and one-half (21/2) car spaces per mobile home
lot. Each such parking space shall be designed and constructed in accordance
with Title 10, Chapter 8 of this Code.
   F.   Water Supply:
      1.   An adequate supply of water of safe, sanitary quality, shall be
furnished in each mobile home park. The water supply system of the park must be
connected to a public water supply if one is located within two hundred feet
(200') of a mobile home park. When a public water supply is not located within
two hundred feet (200') of a mobile home park, then a public water supply and
system shall be provided at the park site which complies with the requirements
of all applicable laws and administrative regulations.
      2.   The park water supply and system shall be provided with sufficient
storage and a rate of pumpage to deliver at least thirty seven (37) pounds'
pressure at all times. Each mobile home site shall be provided with a cold
water riser located at least four inches (4") above ground level. Each such
riser shall be located within or at the edge of the mobile home site which it
supplies and each such riser shall have at least thirty seven (37) pounds of
pressure at all times.
   G.   Sewers And Sewage 1 :
      1.   All sewage and other water-carried waste designated as sewage shall
be disposed of into a public sewerage system when one is located within two
hundred feet (200') of the mobile home park. When a public sewerage system is
not available, a park sewer system and sewage treatment works shall be provided
at the park site which complies with the requirements of the Village sewerage
treatment and disposal provisions 2  and the rules and regulations of the
Illinois Environmental Protection Agency.
      2.   When a water-carried system of sewage is used, each mobile home lot
shall be provided with a sewer connection for the combined liquid waste outlet
or outlets of each mobile home. It shall be the duty of the owner or operator
of said mobile home park to provide an approved type of water- and odor-tight
connection from the trailer water drainage to the sewer connection, and it
shall be the duty of said owner or operator to make such connection and keep
all occupied mobile home connection to said sewer while located in a mobile
home park. Sewer connections in unoccupied mobile home lots shall be so closed
that they will emit no odors or cause a breeding place for flies. No water or
waste shall be allowed to fall on the ground from a mobile home. All sewerage
shall comply with the Illinois Plumbing Code 3  and Village ordinances.
   H.   Garbage Removal; Insect And Rodent Control:
      1.   An adequate flyproof and watertight container shall be used for the
storage of garbage.
      2.   Garbage and rubbish shall be disposed of in a manner which creates
neither a nuisance nor a menace to health.
      3.   Adequate insect and rodent control measures shall be employed. All
buildings shall be flyproof and rodent-proof, and rodent harborages shall not
be permitted to exist in the park.
   I.   Electric Lighting And Outlets:
      1.   All street entrances, exits and driveways shall be lighted at night.
Not less than one hundred watt (100 W) or equivalent electric light shall be
provided for each two hundred (200) lineal feet of private streets and at each
entrance and exit to the mobile home.
      2.   Each mobile home lot shall be provided with a fused or breaker-
controlled disconnect with a minimum rating of one hundred (100) amperes, all
conforming to the Title 8 of this Code.
      3.   Street lighting on public streets shall conform to the Village
regulations.
      4.   All electrical distribution wiring shall be underground.
      5.   A cable TV antenna system with all cabling underground is required.
   J.   Storage Tanks: No individual storage facilities for gasoline, oil, gas,
liquefied petroleum or other fuel storage tanks or cylinders shall be installed
underground and shall not be located inside or beneath any mobile home or
structure or less than five feet (5') from any coach exit. A piping from such
tanks shall be permanently installed and have an earth cover of eighteen inches
(18").
   K.   Playgrounds: A recreational area shall be provided of a size not less
than eight percent (8%) of the gross site area generally provided in a central
location, including suitable landscaping, fencing and benches. In larger parks,
decentralization will be allowed. Recreation areas shall include space for
community use facilities such as adult recreation, child playgrounds and
natural open space.
   L.   Lot Coverage: The lot coverage of a mobile home shall be in accordance
with Title 10, Chapter 5, Article I.
   M.   Certificates Of Occupancy:
      1.   No mobile home park shall be occupied until a certificate of
occupancy shall have been issued by the Chief Building Official to the effect
that the mobile home park, or the portion thereof for which such certificate is
required, is in compliance with all applicable provisions of this chapter and
Title 10, Chapter 5, Article I of this Code.
      2.   Each mobile home occupied as a dwelling unit in a mobile home park
located in the Village after the effective date hereof shall meet the minimum
standards for plumbing, heating and electrical systems, as defined by Title 8
of this Code. Mobile homes that, upon initial installation, display the
official seal and register number of the Mobile Home Manufacturers' Association
will be considered to comply with the above Building Codes. Mobile homes that
do not meet these minimum standards for plumbing, heating and electrical
systems will not be issued a certificate of occupancy by the Chief Building
Official.
      3.   The minimum standards for plumbing, heating and electrical systems
as defined by the various accepted Building, Plumbing and Electrical Codes, as
amended and revised periodically, are hereby made a part of and incorporated by
reference into this chapter. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-1993; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-
2020)

8-3-5: SEWAGE DISPOSAL:
   A.   Each mobile home park shall be provided with a sanitary sewerage system
connected to a public sewerage system or park sewage treatment works. The
sanitary sewerage system shall comply with the Village sewerage treatment and
disposal provisions 1 , the Illinois Plumbing Code 2  and the rules and
regulations of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency as well as the
rules and regulations of the Chief Building Official as approved by the Board
of Trustees.
   B.   Septic tank sewerage disposal systems shall not be approved for use in
all mobile home parks established after the effective date hereof. (Ord. 93-
725, 12-14-1993; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)

8-3-6: FIRE PROTECTION:
Fire hydrants shall be provided in accordance with the National Fire Protection
Association Fire Code (NFPA 1) and any other applicable codes as adopted by the
Village or the Troy Fire Protection District. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-1993; amd.
Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
8-3-7: MOBILE HOME REQUIREMENTS IN PARKS:
Every park licensed, to be constructed or to be modified under the provisions
of this chapter in a proper zoning district shall comply with the following
provision: no dependent mobile home, as defined in Section 8-3-2 of this
chapter, shall be allowed in any licensed mobile home park . (Ord. 93-725, 12-
14-1993; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
8-3-8: EXISTING MOBILE HOME PARKS:
   A.   Requirements for Mobile Homes Moved to Vacant Sites:
      1.   Whenever a mobile home is removed from an existing mobile home park,
the lot or space left vacant shall not again be occupied by another mobile
home; except, that the mobile home be made to meet the requirements of this
Chapter and Title 10, Chapter 5, Article I of this Code. Permits may be issued
for alterations of existing structures or installations which tend to make the
mobile home park conform with this Chapter.
      2.   When the Chief Building Official has approved an application for a
permit to construct or make alterations upon a mobile home park or the
appurtenances thereto or a license to operate and maintain the same, it shall
retain the original and keep a file thereof, and one copy shall be returned to
the applicant or his agent.
      3.   The Chief Building Official shall draft and supply all forms and
specify the number and detail necessary to obtain permits to construct or make
alterations upon mobile home parks and for a license to operate and maintain
such a park according to this Chapter.
   B.   Records Kept: The Chief Building Official shall keep a record of all
mobile home parks, said records to show the names and addresses of the
licensees, number of mobile home lots in each park, source of water supply,
system of sewage and garbage disposal and any other information deemed
essential by the Chief Building Official.
   C.   Requirements for Existing Parks: The following provisions shall be
applicable to all mobile home parks licensed under the provisions of this
Chapter:
      1.   Streets and Driveways: All streets and driveways in every mobile
home park must be maintained in a passable and reasonably dustproof condition
at all times, and all streets and driveways in every mobile home park
established after the effective date hereof shall have the minimum width
required by this Chapter 1 .
      2.   Health and Safety Provisions: The management of every mobile home
park shall assume full responsibility for maintaining in good repair and
condition all sanitary and safety appliances on said park and shall promptly
bring such action as is necessary to prosecute or eject from said park any
person or persons who willfully or maliciously damage such appliances or any
persons who fail to comply with the regulations of this Chapter. (Ord. 93-725,
12-14-93; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  8-3-4E of this Chapter.
8-3-9: OFFICE; REGISTRATION:
   A.   Office and Register Required: Each mobile home park shall be provided
with a custodian's office where each mobile home entering such mobile home park
shall be assigned to a lot location, given a copy of the mobile home park rules
and registered according to the prescribed form. Said registration shall
include the name and address of every occupant of said mobile home, the license
number of all units, the state issuing such licenses and a statement indicating
the exact location at which such mobile home was parked, including the state,
city, town or village where such parking occurred. The licensee shall keep a
registry of all children of school age occupying a mobile home in the mobile
home park.
   B.   Signature and Information Required on Register: The abovementioned
register shall be signed by an occupant of the mobile home lot. Any person
furnishing misinformation for purposes of registration shall be deemed guilty
of a Village ordinance violation. The registration records shall be neatly and
securely maintained, and no registration records shall be destroyed until six
(6) years have elapsed following the date of registration. The register shall
be available at all times for inspection by law enforcement officers. (Ord. 93-
725, 12-14-93; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
8-3-10: RESERVED:
 
8-3-11: ENFORCEMENT; INSPECTIONS:
   A.   The Chief Building Official shall enforce the provisions of this
Chapter, and the Chief Building Official or his designees shall inspect, at
least once each year, each mobile home park and all the accommodations and
facilities therein.
   B.   The Chief Building Official, or his designees are hereby granted the
power and authority to enter upon the premises of such mobile home parks at any
time for the purposes herein set forth. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-93; amd. Ord. 20-
1982, 8-25-2020)
8-3-12: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE; REFUSAL OF LICENSE OR PERMIT:
   A.   Revocation of License Generally:
      1.   Each mobile home park shall be inspected during construction and
operation by the Chief Building Official to determine compliance with the
provisions of the construction permit and the annual license. Any violation of
this Chapter shall be an ordinance violation and subject to revocation of
license plus a fine. Revocation of license requires a new construction permit
and inspection to determine compliance with the permit and this Chapter before
the mobile home park may be occupied.
      2.   Any mobile home park must vacate all mobile homes from the park on
revocation of license or permit. No mobile home may be returned to a mobile
home park before a new construction permit is issued by the Chief Building
Official. Applications for this new construction permit will be made on forms
obtained from the Chief Building Official or, if no such form is available, may
be made by letter containing all of the matters required by this Chapter.
   B.   Notice of Revocation or Suspension:
      1.   Any license granted hereunder shall be subject to revocation or
suspension by the Chief Building Official. However, the Chief Building Official
shall first serve or cause to be served upon the licensee a written notice in
which shall be specified the way or ways in which such licensee has failed to
comply with this Chapter.
      2.   Said notice shall require the licensee to remove or abate such
nuisance, unsanitary or objectionable condition specified in such notice within
a reasonable time. If the licensee fails to comply with the terms and
conditions of said notice within a reasonable time, the Chief Building Official
may take such action to cause revocation or suspension of such license.
   C.   Hearing:
      1.   Authority: Any person refused a permit to construct or alter a
mobile home park or a license or whose license may be suspended or revoked
shall have the right to a hearing before the Village Administrator who shall
have full power to conduct such hearing, issue subpoenas, administer oaths and
affirmations and all other powers necessary to such hearings.
      2.   Notice of Hearing: No hearing shall be held before the Village
Administrator until notice of the time and place of the hearing have been
published in a newspaper of general circulation in the County at least fifteen
(15) days prior to the hearing date and to the Applicant by certified mail,
said notice to contain the particular location of the mobile home and a brief
statement as to the reason the hearing is being held.
      3.   Open to the Public: All hearings shall be open to the public.
      4.   Minutes: The Village shall keep minutes of the proceedings showing
its determination and shall also keep records of its other official actions.
      5.   Expenditures: In the performance of its duties under the provisions
of this Chapter, the Village Administrator may incur such expenditures as shall
be authorized by the Village Board of Trustees.
      6.   Rules of Procedure: The Village Administrator shall establish rules
by which to conduct the hearing. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-93; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-
25-2020)
8-3-13: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
Trailers in Campgrounds: This Chapter shall not apply to any mobile home used
as a travel trailer located in an approved overnight campsite, the patrons of
which have other permanent residences.
   A.   State Parks, Forest Preserves, Farm Labor Camps, etc.: Nothing in this
Chapter shall be construed to include the State Parks of Illinois or the forest
preserves of the Forest Preserve District of Will County, and the term "mobile
home park" shall not be construed to include housing maintained by any
individual or company on his own premises and used exclusively to house his own
farm labor, or any real estate owned by the United States or of this State
wherein a mobile home may be located or harbored, or any park on State or
County fairgrounds for a period during, immediately prior to and immediately
subsequent to the holding of the fair, not to exceed a total of two (2) weeks
in all, or the area of premises on any farm upon which are harbored mobile
homes occupied by persons employed upon such farm for not more than one hundred
eighty (180) days in any calendar year in the production, harvesting or
processing of agricultural or horticultural products on such farm. However, any
mobile home park owned or operated by any municipality shall meet sanitary and
safety provisions of this Chapter, shall be inspected as herein provided, shall
pay or cause to be paid to the Chief Building Official the respective
application and license fees provided by this Chapter and keep a register and
make all reports as herein required of a licensee. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-93; amd.
Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)

A violation of any provisions of this Chapter shall, upon conviction, be
subject to penalty as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-93; 1994 Code)

8-4-2: GARAGE SALE SIGNS:
   A.   Regulations:
      1.   No more than three (3) signs may be erected advertising any such
sale.
      2.   No sign shall be erected more than one-fourth (1/4) mile distance
from the site of the sale.
      3.   No sign shall exceed twenty four inches by thirty six inches (24" x
36") in size.
      4.   No sign shall be erected on private property without the permission
of the property owner.
      5.   No sign shall be erected on any public right of way, nor attached to
any public utility pole.
      6.   No sign shall be allowed to remain for a duration of more than seven
(7) days.
      7.   The person or persons holding such sale shall remove all signs
advertising such sale at the end of the sale.
   B.   Penalty: Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this
section shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 93-725, 12-14-1993; amd. 1994 Code)
CHAPTER 5
PRIVATE RESIDENTIAL SWIMMING POOLS
SECTION:
8-5-1: Definitions
8-5-2: Compliance With And Application Of Provisions
8-5-3: Permit Requirements
8-5-4: Plans And Contracts Required
8-5-5: Fences Required
8-5-6: Reserved
8-5-7: Inspections
8-5-8: Penalty
8-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
   PERSON: Includes any individual, occupant of a residence, lessee or property
owner, as well as any individual, partnership, corporation or business entity
engaged in the business of constructing private residential swimming pools.
   PORTABLE SWIMMING POOL: A temporary receptacle of water or an artificial
pool of water with a maximum diameter of eighteen feet (18') and a maximum
water depth of eighteen inches (18") intended to be used for wading and
requiring no water filtration, pumping or water treatment systems and intended
to be emptied daily or after use.
   PRIVATE RESIDENTIAL SWIMMING POOL: A receptacle of water or an artificial
pool of water, whether aboveground or level with the ground, having a maximum
depth of over eighteen inches (18") and all appurtenant equipment which is used
or intended to be used for swimming by the owner or lessee thereof and family
and guests without payment of any fee for such use.
   TEMPORARY SWIMMING POOL: A temporary receptacle of water or an artificial
pool of water with a maximum depth of over eighteen inches (18") with any
equipment for water filtration, pumping or water treatment, which is used or
intended to be used for swimming by the owner or lessee thereof and family and
guests without payment of any fee for such use, and is not intended to be
emptied daily. (Ord. 14-1749, 10-28-2014)
8-5-2: COMPLIANCE WITH AND APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or allow the
construction, maintenance, installation or enlargement of any private
residential swimming pool or temporary swimming pool in the Village except in
compliance with all of the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   This chapter shall not apply to portable swimming pools, which are
emptied daily. (Ord. 14-1749, 10-28-2014)
8-5-3: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Construction Permit 1 : It shall be unlawful for any person to commence
or proceed with the construction, installation, enlargement or alteration of
any private residential swimming pool in the Village, until the plans and
contracts for construction and a letter of credit, cash or certified check, as
bond, have first been submitted, filed with and approved by the Building
Division of the Village, and a construction permit has been issued to such
person from the Building Division of the Village. The permit application shall
be signed by the property owner, lessee, if any, and property occupant and
shall specifically allow the Village the remedies provided in this chapter if
the pool and fence are not constructed in accordance with this chapter.
   B.   Final Inspection: It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate
or maintain any private residential swimming pool in the Village unless a final
inspection has been approved by the Building Division of the Village. No
inspection shall be approved by the Village, until the private residential
swimming pool is filled with water, and the fencing required herein is
constructed pursuant to ordinances 2 . (Ord. 14-1749, 10-28-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  8-1A-9 of this title for fees.
2 2. See section
  10-3-13 of this Code.
8-5-4: PLANS AND CONTRACTS REQUIRED:
Plans and contracts for construction of private residential swimming pools, as
heretofore required to be submitted to the Village prior to the issuance of a
construction permit, shall comply with the following requirements:
   A.   Plans shall be drawn to scale indicating all dimensions, including
length, width and depth. (Ord. 14-1749, 10-28-2014)
   B.   Plans shall indicate the location of the pool and fencing in relation
to all lot and setback lines, with such minimum setbacks from lot lines being:
      1.   Rear yard: Six feet (6').
      2.   Side yard: Six feet (6').
      3.   No pool shall be built or installed within ten feet (10') of a
foundation wall or accessory building.
      4.   No pool shall be built within any easement regardless of the above
minimum setbacks. (Ord. 16-1826, 11-8-2016)
   C.   The following parts of pools shall not be placed under existing service
drop conductors or any other open overhead wiring nor shall such wiring be
installed above the following:
      1.   Pools and the area extending ten feet (10') horizontally from the
inside of the walls of the pool.
      2.   Diving structure.
      3.   Observation stands, towers or platforms.
   D.   Underground wiring shall be in accordance with chapter 1 of this title.
   E.   Plans shall show the grade for the location where the pool is to be
constructed and the actual preconstruction grade for the location. The
postconstruction final grade must be within three inches (3") tolerance of the
grade established in the final subdivision plat for the lot.
   F.   Plans shall indicate kind, number and size of filters and heaters and
the location and size of any electrical or gas service lines.
   G.   All plans shall show all pools are grounded and all electrical devices
protected with ground fault interrupters.
   H.   Copies of the construction contract for the construction of the private
residential swimming pool and fencing shall be submitted which shall indicate
the cost to complete the construction of the private residential swimming pool
and fencing and the date of completion for each.
   I.   All pools shall be constructed in accordance with all village codes,
including chapter 1 of this title. The more restrictive provisions shall
prevail. (Ord. 14-1749, 10-28-2014)
8-5-5: FENCES REQUIRED:
   A.   Temporary Fence During Construction: During the construction of an
inground pool and when no work is being performed, the excavation and
construction site must be completely surrounded by a temporary fence not less
than four feet (4') in height, of sufficient strength to prevent access to the
construction area. This temporary fence shall be removed upon completion of the
permanent enclosure required in subsection B of this section.
   B.   Permanent Fences For Inground And Aboveground Pools:
      1.   Swimming Pools: All outdoor private residential and temporary
swimming pools shall be completely surrounded by a fence of not less than four
feet (4') in height, separated at least six feet (6') from the pool and of
sufficient strength to prevent access to the pool. This fence shall be
constructed so as not to have any openings, holes or gaps larger than four
inches (4") in any dimension except for doors and gates. A dwelling house or
accessory building may be used as part of such fence. All gates or door
openings through the required fence shall be designed to permit locking and
shall be kept locked when the pool is not in actual use or when the pool is
unattended. All such gates or doors shall be designed to be self-closing and
self-latching. The latches shall be placed at least four feet (4') above the
ground elevation or otherwise made inaccessible to small children. An approved
pool cover shall be installed during those periods when use of the pool is
discontinued.
      2.   Aboveground Swimming Pools: Aboveground private residential swimming
pools with self-provided fencing standing at least three feet (3') above the
pool deck will be allowed without separate additional fencing; provided, that
the self-provided fencing is of sufficient strength and required height to
prevent access other than through a gate or door. Aboveground private
residential swimming pools having stationary ladders, stairs or ramps shall be
equipped with locking devices to prevent unauthorized access. All fencing
required herein shall be subject to all other ordinances of the village
relating to the installation and maintenance of fences 1 . (Ord. 14-1749, 10-
28-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  10-3-13 of this code.
8-5-6: RESERVED:
(Ord. 14-1749, 10-28-2014)
8-5-7: INSPECTIONS:
The Chief Building Official of the village shall inspect or cause to be
inspected all private residential swimming pools within the village at such
times as may be deemed necessary for protection of the public health, safety
and welfare and to ensure compliance with the provisions hereof. (Ord. 14-1749,
10-28-2014; amd. Ord. 20-1982, 8-25-2020)
8-5-8: PENALTY:
In addition to all such other remedies as may be available at law, any person
convicted of violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine
of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day such violation shall continue
shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 14-1749, 10-28-2014)
